But what bureaucrats forget and what law-makers overlook is that this imposes a burden on small businesses which has become completely and utterly unacceptable.

This legislation before the House is a start. It is a small start. There are some improvements to the regulatory framework which, with respect, I wholeheartedly endorse and approve. Let us hope that it is the start of something bigger. Let us show that we trust small business men and women to go about their businesses and hope that the hard work, initiative and courage which are required to become a successful small business man or woman are encouraged by this parliament and promoted by the law-makers in every way possible. I support the legislation.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr BROUGH
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI thank the participants in tonight's debate on the Indirect Tax Legislation Amendment (Small Business Measures) Bill 2004. As the member for Wentworth said, small business personnel and people who enter into such ventures or enterprises do require courage and initiative. Without those two qualities, those enterprises would not exist. Quite frankly, without personnel with a little courage or initiative, this country would be a far weaker place.

speech.para: This bill gives effect to three measures that will assist the small business community which were announced in the 2004-05 budget and is part of a package of measures aimed at reducing small business compliance costs as outlined in the Prime Minister's Committed to Small Business package, which was announced on 6 July 2004. The first measure in the bill provides voluntary GST registered entities the option of reporting and paying their GST on an annual basis. The second measure enables eligible small businesses to undertake annual apportionment of input tax credits for acquisitions that are used partly for non-business purposes rather than do that each time they prepare their business activity statement. This will go a long way towards addressing some of the concerns that small business people have raised from time to time with people such as the Minister for Small Business and Tourism and the member for Wentworth amongst others.

The third measure simplifies the current GST instalment election rules. These measures reflect the government's commitment to reduce GST compliance costs for small business and not-for-profit organisations by providing them with greater flexibility in discharging their GST payment and reporting obligations. The member for Rankin made play of the opposition's record and what they propose to do, in their words, to `assist' the small businesses of this country. I remind the member for Rankin that, if he really wanted to assist small business in any way, shape or form, he as part of the Labor Party could: firstly, pass the unfair dismissal laws, which have now been through 40 times and been knocked back; secondly, remove their support of secondary boycott legislation; thirdly, remove the threat of a payroll tax at a federal level, which in my knowledge would be the first time that one has ever applied and which is a dampener on employment; fourthly, remove their proposition to abolish junior wage rates, which will also be a great disincentive for employers to put on young people; and, fifthly, cease their opposition to AWAs, which allow workers to have more freedom to negotiate with employers in the work force to the betterment of the individual, the business and the wider economy. Tonight, the member for Rankin once again opposed choice in superannuation for employees, which I find to be an extraordinary comment for him to be making. It is so out of touch with the needs of average Australians.

I will quickly contrast what we are offering to small business hereâthat is, certainty, a reduction in red tape and also an appreciation that, when they use goods that could be used for both business and private use, this could be proportioned annuallyâwith Labor's proposals, which are open to abuse and revenue leakage. That has big ramifications further down the track when the ATO attempts to regain what is rightfully part of the tax take. Under Labor, there would be no reconciliation of estimates and GST liabilities, thus the option would be open to abuse by businesses that know they will pay less tax under this option that the ALP is promoting.

Nothing upsets the genuine Australian taxpayer more than knowing that the business or individual down the road is doing the wrong thing. The Labor Party's proposal would do more to undermine the confidence that the small business community have in the fact that they are competing on an equal basis with their neighbour. Under the ALP's proposal, businesses would only have to keep records to justify their turnover. If audited, they would not have to justify their input tax credit claims or details of their sales. This again would increase the possibility of abuse, which is not something that this side of the House accepts as being good policy. Businesses previously in a refund situation would be allowed to apply previous ratios even though they may no longer be in a refund situation. This is ludicrous, and I am sure it is something that, in government, the opposition would have to overturnâand to what ramifications for small business? Businesses may also nominate an industry that is known to have a more favourable ratio.

All of these things undermine people's trust and faith in a just taxation system. What the government has proposed here and what I am sure will pass both in here and in the Senate are measures which will simplify the taxation system and will ensure that small business people have more time to spend on their businesses, generating profits and jobs, which is good for Australia. The Howard government and Minister Hockey in particular, who represents small business very ably, very professionally and with great dedication, will ensure that the interests of small business are always uppermost in the minds of the coalition government. I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Mr BROUGH (LongmanâMinister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (8.43 p.m.)âby leaveâI move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Mr ANDREWS (MenziesâMinister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service) (8.43 p.m.)âby leaveâI move:

motion.para: That consideration of government business order of the day Nos 3 to 8 be postponed until a later hour this day.

debateinfo.title: SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE (LEARNING TOGETHER-ACHIEVEMENT THROUGH CHOICE AND OPPORTUNITY) BILL 2004

cognateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Dr Nelson:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to move the second reading amendment being circulated in my name. The government has delayed the introduction of the Schools Assistance (Learning Together-Achievement Through Choice and Opportunity) Bill 2004 into this parliament, unfortunately leaving schools in a very uncertain funding position. Leaving debate on this bill until August, just four months before the end of the school year, means that schools, principals, students, teachers and parents are all in an uncertain and precarious position. Of course, we on this side of the House do know how schools work. We know that this is about the time when schools are making their decisions for 2005âstudents are choosing their subjects; principals are making decisions about staffâand they have to know what their funding will be for next year in order to make those decisions. Clearly the government really does not care about the havoc that funding uncertainty can cause for schools. It is blatantly irresponsible of the government to introduce this bill so late in the year. The delay is yet another case of this government playing politics with children's education.

speech.para: By contrast, Labor have outlined the principles on which schools should be funded, and these are in stark contrast to the government's unfair funding system. Labor stand by our commitment to needs based funding for all schools. We will increase funding to government schools and redistribute funding away from high-fee non-government schools to more needy Catholic and lower fee independent schools. The non-government sector as a whole will not lose any funding. We will fight the government's unfair funding system at the coming election. For me, this will be a very important fightâa critical fightâto get fairness back into schools funding. It is a fight that we certainly will not resile from. But Labor's determination to change the government's divisive funding system will not put at risk funding certainty for our schools now.

As I said, the government should be condemned for holding back on this bill until so late in the year. As you may know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the funding contained in this bill was actually announced back in March. It has taken months for the parliament to see the bill and even longer for it to come on for debate. Labor will allow this bill to pass for one reason onlyâthat is, to give schools and parents the certainty that they need for next year. Unlike the government, we will not play politics with children's education. But, on winning the election, Labor will introduce fairer, needs based funding legislation that will begin in 2006, and our first budget will contain additional funding for government schools.

Labor's education policy will have many elements, and will include establishing a national schools resource standard to make sure that all schools in Australia, whether they are government, Catholic or independent, have the resources to deliver a high standard of education. We want to fund all schools on the basis of need. We have negotiated a national schools agreement with state and territory governments and we will negotiate agreements with other non-government school authorities to deliver needs based funding. For Labor, at both a national and a state and territory level, significantly increasing the funding for government schools will be one of the priorities that this nation can be proud of. Ensuring a basic level of funding for all non-government schools and guaranteeing the overall funding level for the non-government sectorâthese are commitments that Labor have made. But we do intend to redistribute funding away from high-fee, wealthy schools to lower fee, needy Catholic and independent schools.

We want to provide incentives to make sure that the best teachers, the most experienced teachers, and school leaders are available to assist schools with concentrations of students with special needs. We have announced that we intend to pay the TAFE fees for secondary school students. We will employ 1,080 training mentors to make sure that young people are helped to stay on at school or to move into full-time jobs or further training. We will provide extra resources to improve school discipline. We will have a national action plan to get more male teachers into schools, and we will recruit more fathers and other menâwhether they are grandads, uncles or other leaders in our communityâto serve as role models in our schools. We have announced a Bright Futures program to support secondary school students from disadvantaged backgrounds to progress to university or TAFE.

The bill that we are debating here tonight will operate for only one year, 2005, if Labor win the upcoming election. We are supporting funding for 2005 as a transition year prior to the adoption of Labor's fairer, needs based funding policy. Labor do not support the government's unfair and divisive schools funding system, which has seen the largest funding increases go to the wealthiest schools in this country. Take the King's School in Parramatta in Sydney, for example. They received a 165 per cent increase in funding between 2001 and 2004 from this Howard government. By contrast, a couple of schools just around the corner from the King's School in Parramatta, Fairvale High School and Trinity Catholic College, have had to make do with a 20 per cent and a 25 per cent adjustment respectivelyâbarely enough to cover annual increases. Trinity Catholic College does not have anything like the facilities of King's. It is Trinity Catholic College and Fairvale Highâwhich certainly does not have the facilities of King'sâthat are in desperate need of more resources. Labor believeâso differently from the Howard governmentâthat every Australian child is entitled to a great standard of education. That means for us that every child at every school will get a basic level of funding for their education. But we believe that priority in funding above that basic level must be given to schools on the basis of educational and financial need.

I do not know how many people recognise that this is what has happened under the Howard government but I hope that every member of this parliament will stop for a moment and think about the figures that I am about to put on the parliamentary record. Under this bill, the Commonwealth government is providing more recurrent funding to the 12 per cent of students in non-systemic independent schoolsâ$7.6 billionâthan to the 2.25 million students, or 69 per cent of students, who are in government schools: $7.6 billion will go to the 12 per cent of students in non-systemic independent schools; $7.2 billion will go to 2.25 million students in government schools. This is the first time that this has ever happened in Australia's history. This is despite the fact that many independent schools operate at resource standards that are much higher than those on average in government schools.

The vast bulk of the funding contained in this bill is only that which is required of the Commonwealth government to meet the existing costs of education. That is in fact just indexation for all schools. The bill provides $31.3 billion in funding for government and non-government schools. That represents an increase of $8 billion over the current four-year period. But of this increaseâget thisâonly $405 million is new money. The bulk of the increase results from indexation and supplementation.

Of the $405 million, government schools will receive only $4 million for students with disabilities in government schools. Government schools will get five per cent of the new money, or 0.1 per cent of the $31.3 billion. That is how much extra on top of indexation is going to our government schools. In return for this, our government schools are now going to be required to meet new funding and accountability conditions for starting ages, curriculum testing, reporting to parents, staffing, and of course flagpoles. The Howard's government's policies are nothing short of outrageously unfair. They must be reformed so that every Australian childâevery single Australian childâgets a great education.

The government like to claim that all non-government schools are now in their SES funding scheme. Let us have a look at the facts. The minister's own department has testified that only half of non-government schools are actually being funded according to the government's own SES funding policies. Let us look at the details. Fifty per cent of non-government schools are funded on the basis of their SES score, nine per cent are funding maintained at year 2000 levels, 37 per cent are funding maintained at year 2004 levels and four per cent are funding guaranteed.

The government has established a funding system in which four schools with the same SES score receive four different levels of funding. It is also the case that the majority of Catholic schoolsâ60 per cent, in factâdo not have funding certainty after 2009 because they are funding maintained. For the future of all Australian children, a more sustainable and coherent funding system is needed: a fair system that actually delivers increased funding to government and needy non-government schools.

The minister for education has been heard to sayâjust last week, in factâthat school resources do not matter. He said on the ABC's AM program that it is ability not resources that determines a student's academic achievement. He has also said that high-fee schools perform well because they attract students with high ability. Why on earth is he therefore giving these high-fee schools the biggest funding increases in the countryâas much as 300 per cent? According to the minister's logic, these schools do not need additional resources because resources do not matter. I wonder what world this minister is living in?

Maybe it is like that up there on the North Shore in Sydney, but last week I visited three Aboriginal community schools in the Northern Territory. The things that struck me, first of all, were how extraordinarily poor the resources in the classrooms were and how hard it was for the teacher and the teacher's assistant to teach these children, because of language differences. It is an absolute tragedy to see the level of education that these children are receiving.

We cannot deny that the school in Oenpelli at Gunbalanya needs proper classrooms. It does not have proper classrooms. Yet this minister says that resources do not matter. Anywhere else in Australia it would not be acceptable to have children in these sorts of classrooms. They are tiny little classroomsâthey are almost sitting on the groundâand they are made of some sort of tin. It is totally unacceptable. This place is just one of the places in the Northern Territory that needs a new school. Yet this minister has the hide to say that resources do not matter while at the same time he gives millions upon millions of dollars to schools like the King's School, Trinity Grammar and Geelong Grammar while we have schools in the Northern Territory, for example, crying out for increased funding just to cover the basics; just so they can have a decent classroom to teach in.

Let us get real. The massive funding increases that have gone to the highest fee schools in Australia would be far better spent on helping poorer-performing children at needy schools. Some of them are like the ones I saw last week in the Northern Territory. Others are Catholic parish schools in many of our country towns. These are the policies that Labor will implement. We will make sure that children in these schools get the resources that they need so that they too get a great education.

The government wants to distract people away from these fundamental resource inequalities between schools, because not only does this bill do nothing to address them; it is going to make them worse. That is why we have seen this minister put an enormous effort into trying to muddy the waters by introducing a range of different issues that do not go to the central question of how much money is available to make sure that children in our schools are properly educated.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 9 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âTonight I draw the attention of members to the urgent need for the government and the community to support the one in 2,500 Australian boys who suffer from Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Just two weeks ago, I met with Anne Holland from Upper Mount Gravatt, who spoke with me about her 11-year-old son, Matthew, who was diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy in July last year.

speech.para: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked chromosome disorder which only affects boys. There is no known cure. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by abnormalities of the dystrophin gene that produces a protein needed to maintain healthy muscles. As affected boys grow, their muscles become weaker, they lose the ability to walk and many boys will also experience problems with their joints, spine, heart and lungs. In addition to these physical challenges, a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy causes ongoing psychological challenges for sufferers and their families as they deal with the deterioration of their mobility and muscle strength and the resulting decline in their quality of life. They have to reconcile themselves to the fact that boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy are generally not expected to live beyond their late teens or early 20s.

Understandably, the Holland family want to make sure that they have done everything they can to see that we in the federal parliament do everything in our power to help boys like Matthew enjoy a longer and more comfortable life and that researchers receive the support they need to improve treatments and to find a cure for this fatal genetic condition.

While Matthew has not completely lost his ability to walk, he does rely on a motorised scooter to get around at school or when family or social outings require a lot of walking. In an effort to slow the progression of the disease, Matthew has physical therapy and hydrotherapy to avoid the tightening of the muscles. When not using his scooter, he wears ankle-foot orthoses to assist with walking and takes a five millilitre dose of prednisolone, a cortico steroid. This medication has been found to successfully preserve heart and lung function and mobility.

Unfortunately, there is only one cortico steroid treatment available to young Australians with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. The alternative medication, deflazacort, is not available in this country. The Holland family and many in their position would welcome the introduction of this effective medication onto the Australian market. It would give them a choice of treatments, especially as deflazacort causes less weight gain in some patients, an important factor when trying to preserve their son's mobility for as long as possible.

We are fortunate that there is some excellent research into Duchenne muscular dystrophy being conducted in Australia. Dr Andrew Hoey leads a team of researchers at the University of Southern Queensland who are focusing on developing and testing new therapies for cardiac and skeletal muscle in Duchenne muscular dystrophy affected boys. Dr Robert Kaspa and Dr Andrew Kornberg from the University of Melbourne are developing a novel technique to treat genetic neuromuscular disease, with a focus on using it to improve the quality of life and the lifespan of boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Western Australian muscular dystrophy researcher, Dr Steve Wilton, has developed gene therapy which will effectively turn Duchenne into a much milder form of the disease, namely Becker muscular dystrophy.

In an interview with the ABC, researchers said, `With Becker's muscular dystrophy the severity ranges markedly. For example, there was one person who was not diagnosed till their mid-60s and was playing competitive sport till their early 60s. If we can convert Duchenne muscular dystrophy, where boys would normally die in their teens, into the much milder form, it has a considerable potential to improve the quality of life for both the boys and their families.' Human trials of this therapy are due to commence late this year or in early 2005.

We have impeccable intellectual resources in Australia, and they need our financial support if they are to advance their research and develop effective therapies and eventually a cure for this debilitating disease. By building the profile of Duchenne muscular dystrophy in Australia through forums such as this and creating greater awareness amongst our law-makers, our medical professionals and the general public, the Holland family and other families around the country who are living with this disease hope to gain wider support for their calls for increased investment in research and improved access to medicines and medical equipment such as suitable wheelchairs and respiratory equipment.

I am pleased to have had this opportunity tonight to advance their cause. It is estimated that the federal government spends approximately $3 million on each child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy throughout his short life. I support the Holland family, therapists and researchers and add my voice to their calls for more appropriately targeted government support to help them cope with and combat Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

talk.start.para: âTonight I speak in memory of Barry Douglas Simon, the member for McMillan from 1975 to 1980. Barry Simon's period as an MP was relatively short. His impact on a wide range of people and issues was considerable and sustained. Barry Simon was one of a new breed of high-profile local federal members who emerged at the beginning of the 1970s. He was a highly respected local lawyer, a visionary and the first mayor of the City of Berwick. He was never far from his local roots. He knew that all politics were local and he gave a great deal.

speech.para: He was a strong proponent of future planning for social and physical infrastructure for the outer eastern area of Melbourne. Much of the realisation of these ideas and concepts that exist today are a testimony to Barry Simon's vision and drive. Barry was initially trained as a teacher, but after three years he returned to university to complete a law degree. He entered local government and federal politics at the beginning of the 1970s. Barry was elected the member for McMillan in the great Fraser landslide of 1975. That was when I first met him. He lost his seat as the tide went out on the Fraser government in 1980.

The Liberal Party is a broad church, Mr Speaker, as you know. Barry was not part of the conservative chapel. This was exemplified by his opposition to the Lusher motion. He also attempted to have three-cornered contests in National Party seats, indeed, seats held by National Party ministers. His time in politics was both tempestuous in terms of party politics and in matters of broader public policy and, above all, it was marked by him taking positions of principle. His commitment to the principles of the Menhennitt ruling on abortion led to strong opposition against him in McMillan in the 1980 election, and in that election he lost his seat. However, I think it is worth noting that he did not believe that the campaign mounted against him by the Right to Life Association was responsible for his defeat.
A detached perspective of Barry's commitment to his constituency and to Australia was given by Phillip Adams in 1979, almost 30 years ago. Mr Adams wrote:

quote.para: In the professional pecking order the MP comes between the used car salesman and the insurance dealer, just above the advertising man and the leper.

speech.para: Adams went on to say:

quote.para: I'm all for a bit of healthy scepticism. But if democracy is not to go the way of the dodo and the dinosaur we need to remind ourselves that MPs are often thoroughly decent men who faithfully echo the limitations and the prejudices of their electors.
In the hope of putting politicians a little higher in the pecking order, say, on a par with plumbers or undertakers, I have recorded a typical working day by a private member ...

speech.para: Which private member's day did Mr Adams choose to record to promote a higher regard for politicians? The member for McMillan, Mr Barry Simon. I am sure that that was not an act of partisan bias.

Barry was a believer in egalitarianism. He was fundamentally committed to gender equality. He had the rare capacity of being able to speak to everyone, from Dick Pratt to the cleaning staff. After his defeat, Barry worked for Andrew Peacock as his principal private secretary. He participated in the leadership tension of those days. Even with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight, judgments today about that period are still divided. But in his role, Barry's qualities of personal loyalty and his work ethic stood out.

He resigned and subsequently worked as a business consultant. He never lost his passion for and commitment to the issues and the people that mattered to him. Andrew Peacock was overseas at the time of Barry's death. When I told him about it yesterday, on his return, he was deeply shocked. Andrew Peacock's admiration for Barry is clear in the following description of him:

quote.para: Barry was thoughtful and considerate and generous, but you were never in any doubt about where he stood on any political issue. Barry was politically principled. He faced issues squarely and fought resolutely.

speech.para: In his brave fight against cancer Barry was looked after by his former wife, Ruth. My condolences go to Ruth and his familyâhis sons, Paul, Michael and Johnâand his other loved ones.

talk.start.para: âI would like to deal with two related issues regarding the Alfred Hospital in my electorate. The Alfred Hospital is Australia's oldest and pre-eminent trauma hospital. Today it signed a memorandum of understanding with the Hadassah Medical Organisation, one of Jerusalem's oldest hospitals and a hospital that has treated more than 2,300 of Israel's 5,000-plus terror victims over the last four years. It is also the largest medical facility in Jerusalem, serving some 700,000 residents.

speech.para: In June Victorian Premier Steve Bracks toured the Hadassah hospital in Jerusalem and announced details of a formal agreement between the two university affiliated hospitals. The Premier said:

quote.para: We have a lot to learn from Hadassah.

speech.para: The signing of the MOU is the result of an initiative by Hadassah Internationalâthe fundraising arm of the hospitalâand takes into account the many parallels between the two institutions, including world-class research and educational facilities. Speaking in anticipation of today's signing, the Premier of Victoria said:

quote.para: I hope the skills learned by Hadassah's medical staff in dealing with bus and cafe bombings are skills the Alfred never has to use.

speech.para: I do not claim often to speak on behalf of all of the parliament, but I am sure that that is a sentiment reflected by everyone here.

Today's signing was between the Alfred Hospital's General Manager, Lea Pope, and Hadassah Medical Organisation Director-General Professor Shlomo Mor-Yosef, who is in Australia specifically for this signing. Present at the signing were state Minister for Finance John Lenders, representing the Premier, and Ron Finkel, the President of Hadassah Australia. Also in attendance were former Governor-General Sir Zelman Cowen, patron of Hadassah Australia; Dr Henry Pinskier, a board member of both the Alfred and Hadassah; Tony Lupton, the member for Prahran, who was with the Premier when they visited Hadassah in Israel; and Orna Sagiv, the acting Ambassador of Israel.

Speaking at the signing, Professor Thomas Kossmann, Director of the National Trauma Research Institute at the Alfred, said that the new institute, which opened at the Alfred last week, would be one way of exchanging research and education. He said that the Alfred would be able to learn from Hadassah's experience in large-scale traumas, while Hadassah will be able to learn from the Alfred's experience with road trauma and other smaller incidents.
Hadassah's Professor Mor-Yosef introduced the signing by saying:

quote.para: The MOU will be the springboard for collaborations between two well-matched hospitals of similar size, both of which are dedicated to state-of-the-art patient care and treatment. As well as trauma, we believe there will be many other clinical areas for the two hospitals to exchange expertise.

speech.para: Professor Mor-Yosef will be in Canberra next week. I am sure we will be happy to host him. I am sure the member for Wentworth will join me in doing that, and I look forward to seeing Professor Mor-Yosef here.

This MOU strengthens the Alfred's trauma expertise, following, as I mentioned, the launch of the National Trauma Research Instituteâwhich I attendedâon 23 July. Based at the Alfred, Professor Kossmann's National Trauma Research Institute is integrated with the largest and busiest trauma service in Australia, enabling laboratory research to be readily transferred to a clinical setting. The Alfred already has the best trauma survival rates in the country and equals the best in the world. There are currently 26 major traumas per week in Victoria, the majority being the result of road traffic accidents, followed closely by workplace accidents.

When I was there I learned a number of very interesting things about trauma in Australia. For instance, the institute's research is being integrated with all the other research in these areas that takes place at the Alfred Hospital. As I said, the current patient survival outcome for trauma victims at the Alfred is quite spectacular compared to other places. Road trauma is the leading cause of death in people under 40. It affects mostly males, with 73 per cent of major trauma patients being male. Sixty per cent of all major trauma cases occur on the road. Workplace accidents, as I said, fall slightly behind that.

As well as car and work injuries, both the National Trauma Research Institute and this memorandum of understanding with Hadassah will greatly assist Australia in the case of a major terrorist incident. Similarly, the Alfred will be able to share with Hadassah its world-leading skills with burns victims. This is an example of government and a major institution taking positive steps to deal with terrorist threats instead of simply announcing and re-announcing existing fundingâas this government often does.

I end by noting the passing of a very dear friend of my office, Mr Sonny Sanerive, a very lovely gentleman from the islands who has been a constant presence in my office over the last four years. After a recent film showing in my office he passed away. My condolences go to his friend Diane Boyd, to his son, Harry, and Vicky, who live in Melbourne. All of his friends in the office, in St Kilda and all over Melbourne Ports will miss him.

talk.start.para: âYesterdayâMonday, 2 AugustâI attended an important community meeting in my electorate at Hewlett Street, Bronte, at which there was a loud and vigorous protest, a cry from the people of that area, against the installation of a highly intrusive mobile telecommunications tower proposed at 69 Hewlett Street, Bronte, by Hutchison Telecommunications. The meeting was capably chaired by local councillor Ingrid Strewe. The local state member for Coogee, Mr Pearce, attended, as did I as the federal member. There was strong support from the community in the surrounding streets and from the many community organisations affected in that important part of my electorate, including Bronte Public School, the local child-care centre, the after care centre, the Waverley Council, the local precinct committees and residentsâespecially families with children.

speech.para: The concerns expressed by those present can be summarised as follows. The first and foremost concern of almost everyone present was the safety and welfare of children and that this ought to be put first in the consideration of placement of a mobile telecommunications tower and not placed second behind commercial convenience. The second issue that was focused on by speakers drawn from the residents and others was the importance of the avoidance of risk in relation to EME and the mobile telecommunications tower's electromagnetic output. The third was the need for action by governments to stop this outrageous incursionânot just at the local level, as had been previously tried, but also at the federal level, because this is a genuine federal issue. The fourth issue that was touched upon by one or two speakersâin particular me, because of previous experience in these issues, and a resident, Mr Noakes, who spoke strongly and fulsomely on the problemâwas the need for reform of the Telecommunications Act. In particular, the schedules to the act and the draconian provisions that were put in the act some 12 years ago by then Minister Lee under the Labor government illustrate the lack of reform since then and an urgent need for reform now.

My involvement in this matter arose because of several letters and emails I received from local residents, but initially it came from the owners of the shop adjacent to the proposed siteânamely the Lims of 6/33 Read Street, who conduct their business close by 69 Hewlett Street. I also received a very lengthy email from Mr Noakes and his partner, Ms Burke, which set out an admirable statement of the considerations involved in dealing with this particular problem. For my part, I have written to the minister and indeed spoken personally to her since that time and conveyed to her the concerns of local residents. I have also spoken to senior members of her staff and conveyed those concerns to Hutchison Telecommunications. As a result of those considerations being addressed, we initially obtained an extension of time on the question to ensure that this mobile tower is not placed in close proximity to a children's playground, a child-care centre and families with children in the adjacent area.

One speaker referred to his doubts about EME rather than expressing the real concern of residents. I want to strongly suggest that the views of the residents should be heeded on this matter. It is not just a question of listening to the World Health Organisation, which came out with a detailed report on the risks in its Establishing a dialogue on risks from electromagnetic fields handbook in 2002; there was also the Stewart report in the United Kingdom. I urge that this matter be dealt with immediately by the government. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee: Membership

talk.start.para: âAs the former Deputy Chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I wish to place on record tonight why I and the members for Barton, Denison and Bowman today took the unprecedented step of resigning from the committee. Prior to the appointment of the member for Mackellar, the Hon. Bronwyn Bishop, as chair, this committee was one of the most respected committees of the parliament, having a culture of constructive bipartisan consideration of complex and, at times, controversial issues including copyright legislation, embryonic stem cell research and overseas sexual crime offences.

speech.para: Since the committee first met some 2Â½ years ago to discuss the terms of reference for the crime inquiry, the chair has engaged in a scandalous politicisation of the committee. At the first meeting, the chair tabled a highly political set of terms of reference which led to all ALP members walking out of that meeting. Although we were able to have the terms of reference modified the chair has used the inquiry from day one to attack Labor state governments. The chair has kept her own counsel and delivered ultimatums to committee members and never had any intention of involving us properly.

We believe that she has made a mockery of the committee's inquiries and totally debauched the parliamentary committee process. Her behaviour is in sharp contrast to the gentlemanly approach adopted in the last parliament by the committee chair and my friend the member for Menzies, the Hon. Kevin Andrews, who I am pleased is sitting at the table tonight. For us, the last straw occurred when the chair called a meeting of the committee for 11 p.m. on Thursday, 22 July 2004 at the royal suite of the Stamford Plaza Hotel near Sydney airport to consider and sign off on her draft report relating to the inquiry into the exposure draft of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment (Anti-Avoidance and Other Measures) Bill 2004 and to also consider her draft report relating to the inquiry into crime in the community: victims, offenders and fear of crime.

We were given less than six hours notice of this meeting to be conducted in the dead of night and with no reasonable time to read her draft reports. When I left the chair at lunchtime on Thursday, 22 July when we concluded our public hearings relating to the bankruptcy inquiry, there was no indication to me at that time that she would be calling another meeting at such an absurd hour without reasonable noticeâall to save the hide of the Attorney-General, who, as Mrs Bishop subsequently advised me by telephone in the late afternoon of 22 July, had issued an embargoed media statement announcing that he was abandoning the bankruptcy bill.

Whilst all the ALP committee members agreed the bill should be ditched, we experienced the farcical situation during the late-night meeting of my receiving a telephone call on my mobile phone at 11.40 p.m. from a senior media adviser of a Carr government minister advising that radio 702 ABC had just broadcast to the world that on page 1 of the Australian Financial Review of Friday, 23 July 2004 there was a report that the Attorney-General had abandoned the bankruptcy bill. At the time of the ABC radio report, we had not even finalised the recommendations, let alone considered the draft report. I immediately brought this to the attention of the chair, who dismissed my concerns saying, `That's why we have to finalise the report tonight.'

At three minutes past midnight on Friday 23 July I withdrew from the meeting as the chair was determined to start discussing the first four chapters of her draft crime inquiry report. There was no justification for the chair's behaviour whatsoever on 22 to 23 July, and the member for Barton and I indicated the same to Mrs Bishop.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Lowe will refer to the member for Mackellar by her correct title.

âOkay. Despite the conduct of the chair over 2Â½ years, I want to record my deep appreciation of the hard work, professionalism and dedication of all the members of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee secretariat. They should all be canonised, in contrast to the chair, who should be sacked by the Prime Minister.

âIn reviewing this current parliament as we draw closer to the inevitable general election, I think it is worth putting on the record the last eight years in a precis form. Everybody will have their own particular list and measurement of this government's performance, particularly from 1996. But in my own determination, which reflects my regional background and that which is important to the export industries of Australia, I will put on the record some of those great steps forward which have made Australia's economy one ofâif not theâstrongest economies in the world.

speech.para: I will start with the reduction in transport taxes. When you have the distances that we need to traverse in this land to get our production to the ports and to wherever it needs to go, as well as the inputs that are needed to make that production, transport is a key factor in how we shape up to the rest of the world and get our products to the rest of the world. So keeping transport tax costsâthose government impostsâdown is very important. Reform of the railways is almost a distant memory. When we came to government in 1996 we inherited a mess. We had debt, we had loss-making enterprises, we had industrial relations which were unacceptably bad and we had a whole lot of issues relating to management of our railways, which had not known a proper private enterprise ethic for a very long timeâif ever. So reform of the railways is very significant in terms of my measurement of this government's performance. Of course who could forget, despite all the rhetoric, the reform of the waterfront? Apparently it was impossible to have more than about 16 or 17 crane liftsâit was just impossible for it to happen. But now we know we are sitting at 24, 26, 27 crane lifts an hour. So we will always remember `MUA here to stay', but we much prefer to recall the improvement in that industry over this short period.

One of the great cultural shifts in Australia was the acceptance of a program called Work for the Dole. It was a simple little program but let us compare it with what was there before: new work opportunities costing something in excess of $100,000 per real job, getting about a four per cent outcome for those who were on the unemployment lists, joining those too long unemployment queues that were part of the Keating regime. But for a modest cost of about $4,000 per Work for the Dole participant, we are getting in excess of 30 per cent real job outcomes. More importantly, we are giving dignity and opportunity to a lot of people who had lost sight of any positive employment outcome.

I can go on and on but I should mention the lower capital gains tax, the additional $1.4 billion of Roads to Recovery for local roads throughout Australia, much better treatment for self-funded retirees, a lower income tax, a lower wine tax and rural transaction centresâin excess of 240 centres throughout Australia, breathing new life and innovation into service delivery throughout regional Australia and which are being replaced by the regional partnership funding. Many of us throughout regional Australia are enjoying the beginnings of rural health schools where we hope to transform the way that our doctors and many of our health professionals are trained and develop a culture where they will become much more part of our rural communities. The emphasis on literacy and numeracy is also very important and of course native title reform cannot be forgotten.

That is the record on which I proudly stand here tonight and I look forward in the coming election to talking about that record. Just as importantly, if not more importantly, I look forward to talking about the future of those issues that will confront us, whether it be in infrastructure, water sustainability, age care issues or keeping those transport taxes down.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: to present a bill for an act to amend the Criminal Code Act 1995, and for related purposes. (Crimes Legislation Amendment (Telecommunications Offences and Other Measures Bill (No.2) 2004)
to present a bill for an act to amend the Criminal Code Act 1995, and for related purposes. (Criminal Code Amendment (Suicide Related Material Offences) Bill 2004)
to move:

motion.para: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Fitout of new leased premises for Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources in Civic, ACT.

talk.start.para: to move:

interjection.para: That this House:
(1) notes with concern:
(a) the ongoing humanitarian and human rights crisis in the Darfur region of Western Sudan; and
(b) the decimation of this area and the south of the country by Janjaweed and the ongoing civil war;
(2) commends the Government for:
(a) its recent commitment to provide a further $12 million in aid to the region in addition to the $8 million committed in May and June of this year; and
(b) its continued support for the establishment of a United Nations intervention in the area to ensure the delivery of aid; and
(3) urges the UN to emphasize to the al-Bashir Government the importance of intervention to the safety of Darfuris and the provision of assistance throughout the country.

talk.start.para: to move:

interjection.para: That this House:
(1) notes:

(a) the reports of many independent observers, including those sent by the African Union, that the so-called Janjaweed militias have carried out numerous massacres, summary executions, rapes, burnings of towns and villages, and forcible depopulations in the Darfur region of western Sudan;

(b) reports by Human Rights Watch that the Sudanese military regime has armed, supported and supervised the militias, and that Sudanese government forces have directly participated in some of these actions;

(c) estimates by reputable sources that at least 300,000 people have already been killed or died as a direct or indirect result of this campaign, that more than a million people have been made homeless, that more than 100,000 have been forced to seek refuge in Chad, and that an unknown but large number of women have been raped in the course of these attacks; and
(d) reports that the militias have destroyed mosques, killed Muslim religious leaders, and desecrated Qurans in the course of their attacks;

(2) condemns the military regime in Sudan for instigating a policy of forcibly depopulating areas considered disloyal to Khartoum and which has led to massive social dislocation and deaths of innocent civilians, in particular, the Fur, Masalit and Zaghawa ethnic groups in Darfur;
(3) holds the Sudanese regime responsible for the crimes committed by its armed forces and by the militias under its control;

(4) welcomes the decision by the Australian Government to allocate $20 million for relief in Darfur, but calls on the Government to make a significantly greater commitment to aid the people of Darfur through appropriate international agencies;
(5) notes that UN Security Council Resolution 1556 has imposed an arms embargo on Sudan and authorised the creation of an international protection force for Darfur; and
(6) calls on the Australian Government:

(a) in the event that this force does not succeed in preventing further armed attacks on the people of Darfur, to take immediate action at the United Nations to ensure that the UN force is given a mandate to disarm the militias, secure the withdrawal of Sudanese government forces from the area, protect the people of Darfur and enable all refugees to return to their homes;
(b) to make a contribution, proportionate with Australia's military capacity, of Australian forces to any peace-keeping force dispatched to Sudan under a United Nations mandate; and

(c) to take action at the United Nations to secure the prosecution for war crimes at the appropriate international tribunal of President Omar Bashir and other officials of the Sudanese military regime responsible for the massacres of civilians in Darfur.

talk.start.para: to move:

interjection.para: That this House:
(1) resolves that:

(a) in this Olympic year, in recognition of the historical return of the Olympics to Athens, and in recognition of the contribution of classical Greece to Western culture and society, the return of the Parthenon Marbles is a moral, cultural and historical imperative;
(b) the Parthenon Marbles are part of a unique cultural landmark and are an integral feature of the Parthenon in Greece; and
(c) the historical and artistic integrity of the Parthenon remains compromised as the Marbles cannot be viewed in close proximity to the Parthenon; and

(2) calls upon the United Kingdom, as a great gesture of good will, to facilitate the return of the Marbles, outright or on permanent loan to the people of Greece for placement in the New Acropolis Museum upon its completion.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 November 2003:

quote.para: Has the Treasurer's Committee taken any decisions in respect of national consistency in tort law reform; if so, (a) what are those decisions, and (b) to what extent have those decision been implemented by the Commonwealth and the States, respectively.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer represents the Australian Government on the Ministerial Meeting on Insurance Issues. At its meeting in Perth on 4 April 2003, Ministers agreed that further work should be undertaken with insurers to identify opportunities for further harmonisation of tort law reform. Officials representing the Australian Government, States and Territories are continuing to work together to progress harmonisation of reforms.

The Review of the Law of Negligence, chaired by Justice Ipp, was released on 2 October 2002. This review was jointly established with the States and Territories and reported on a range of issues including:

answer.para: professional negligence;
reform of the TPA;
limitation periods and reforms to assist not-for-profit organisations;
limiting the liability of public authorities;
self assumption of risk to override common law principles;
proposals to restrict the circumstances in which a person must guard against the negligence of others; and
the replacement of joint and several liability with proportionate liability.

quote.para: The recommendations of the Ipp Report provide all jurisdictions with a model for consistent reform. The Australian Government has introduced the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injury and Death) Bill 2003 and the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injury and Death) Bill (No. 2) 2004 into the Parliament to support state and territory reforms in a manner consistent with Ipp wherever possible. It is disappointing that the Opposition refused to support either of these bills in their original form and has not accepted the Ipp model. The Australian Government encourages the Opposition to pass the Trade Practices Amendment (Personal Injury and Death) Bill 2003 as soon as possible to help improve the cost and availability of public liability insurance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 10 February 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the acquittal guidelines provided with the answer to question No. 2654 (Hansard, 25 November 2003, page 22727), (a) why are the acquittal guidelines, in particular aspects of the Assessment Advice, not publicly available, (b) would this information be useful to community groups and regional Natural Resource Management (NRM) groups in devising suitable projects, and (c) are there any reasons why the Government should not disclose how it will account for almost one-third of all investments under the Natural Heritage Trust (NHT) Extension.

(2) Will he (a) explain the basis on which the environmental values of protected waterbodies are agreed under the guidelines, in particular, (i) whether those values or beneficial uses have been identified through State or Local Government water quality/resource planning activities, and (ii) whether the values have been identified under the draft or accredited regional NRM plan, or by another process; if it is by another process, what are the details, (b) provide a breakdown by State and NRM region of the investments to date acquitted against the $350m commitment, (c) provide a list of the waterbodies protected through investments in water quality improvement (other than for planning and monitoring purposes) for each NRM region, (d) indicate the proportion of funds acquitted to date against the $350m for (i) planning, (ii) management and (iii) monitoring activities, (e) provide for each relevant waterbody the agreed `beneficial uses' or environmental values, identify the public documentation that states these environmental values, and the relevant water quality objectives for those environmental values against which the acquittals against the $350m are being made; and (f) provide the title of each project against which acquittals have been made, for each waterbody and for each NRM region.

(3) Can he indicate the total investments to date against the following environmental values: (a) aquatic ecosystems, (b) recreational water quality and aesthetics, (c) raw water for drinking water supplies, (d) agricultural water use, and (e) industrial water use.

(4) In respect of paragraph 9 of the acquittal guidelines which states âWhile salinity targets may be established as primary water quality targets (eg instream salinity concentrations) where the primary process driving deterioration in this aspect of water quality is dryland (ie non-agricultural induced) salinity, a distinction has been made between the issues by the Prime Ministerâ, is the Government proposing that agricultural development, especially that associated with broadacre clearance of deeprooted vegetation, is not associated with dryland salinity; if so, on what scientific advice has it formed this view.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The acquittal guidelines provide assessment advice and other guidance to Australian Government officers on the management of the Natural Heritage Trust and the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality. The guidelines are not generally made publicly available as they are internal departmental working documents and are revised regularly. However, the guidelines were published in Hansard on 25 November 2003 as part of the answer to Question on Notice 2654.

(b) No. Natural Resource Management (NRM) groups are encouraged to develop projects with multiple integrated outcomes based on the priorities in their accredited NRM plans. The acquittal guidelines are designed to provide advice to departmental officers on financial acquittals, rather than to regional groups on the preparation of their investment proposals.
(c) The Australian Government will report on progress towards meeting the $350m water quality target in the annual report of the Natural Heritage Trust.
(2) (a) (i) The environmental values of protected water bodies have generally been identified through State water quality planning activities.

(ii) The basis on which the environmental values of protected waterbodies are agreed is through implementation of the planning and management framework set out in the Australian and New Zealand Guidelines for Fresh and Marine Water Quality (2000). These Guidelines, approved by the former Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council (ANZECC) and the former Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ), set out a series of agreed environmental values that may apply to all waters of Australia.
Environmental values, known as beneficial uses in some jurisdictions, have been determined in a number of State and Territory-managed planning activities. These activities are:

throughout New South Wales at the catchment scale as non-statutory interim water quality objectives. State-wide in Victoria as beneficial uses under the State Environment Protection Policy (Waters of Victoria) 2003; and at the waterbody or catchment scale under associated schedules for Port Phillip Bay, Western Port and catchment, Yarra River and catchment, Gippsland Lakes and catchment and Waters of the Latrobe and Thomson River Creeks and Merriman Creek Catchment;
State-wide in Queensland as `default' environmental values under the Environment Protection (Water) Policy 1997;
State-wide in South Australia as `default' protected environmental values under the Environment Protection (Water Quality) Policy 2003;

environmental values (beneficial uses) for some waters in Western Australia, being the Peel Inlet and Harvey Estuary, Groundwater of the Gnangara Mound, wetlands on the Swan Coastal Plain, and wetlands registered under the Environmental Protection (South West Agricultural Zone Wetlands) Policy 1998;
protected environmental values established at the catchment level for all Tasmanian waters under the State Policy on Water Quality Management 1997; and
for all waters in the Australian Capital Territory, under the Water Resources Management Plan 1999.

(2) (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) and (3) As of 31 May 2004, four national water quality projects with combined funding of $2,029,000 have been completed and specifically acquitted against the $350 million water quality target. As these projects are national in scope they are not assigned to a specific State or NRM region. The small number of projects acquitted to date reflects the fact that the accounting cycle for the overall water quality commitment is at an early stage.

As of 31 May 2004, the value of approved, but not fully acquitted, water quality management projects funded by the Natural Heritage Trust was $43,453,978. Of this amount, $14,586,431 related specifically to National projects that are not assigned to a specific State or NRM region. The remaining $28,867,547 related to Regional and Envirofund projects that are in the process of being assigned to NRM regions. The State and Territory breakdown for these projects is as follows:

All of these projects (National, Regional and Envirofund) are currently being reviewed by an expert group (as specified in clause 16 of the guidelines). The information relating to aquatic ecosystems, recreational water quality and aesthetics, drinking water supply and agricultural and industrial water use will be available after the review is completed.

(4) No. There appears to have been a typographical error in the acquittal guidelines. These guidelines should have stated â... where the primary process driving deterioration in this aspect of water quality is dryland (i.e. non-irrigation-induced salinity) ... rather than `non-agricultural induced'.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 February 2004:

question.para: (1) How long has he had the Australian Communications Authority's draft determination on premium rate services and when is the Government going to implement it.
(2) Is he able to say why the ACA's draft determination deals with domestic 190 premium rate services only and not 0011 overseas services.

(3) Can he confirm that under the draft ACA premium rate determination carriers will not be required to provide information to consumers relating to premium rate services until after they become customers; if so, why does not the draft determination require carriers to provide information to consumers on these services prior to them becoming customers.
(4) Will he consider the provision of optional credit limits for all consumer telecommunications accounts; if not, why not.
(5) What is the Government doing to solve the associated and growing problem of Internet dumping and will he consider regulations against Internet dialler technologies.
(6) What is the Government doing to solve the problem of massive unexpected telephone bills from people exceeding their data limits on Internet broadband accounts.

(7) Can he confirm that the Telephone Information Services Standards Council (TISSC) is reported to have 8,000 outstanding complaints; if so, does he propose to reform complaints handling processes in the premium rate services area and if he does not, why not.

(8) Is he aware that local companies Mediatel Services and Sound Advertising consistently figure prominently in complaints from consumers to the TISSC regarding premium rate services; if so, will he consider developing stronger regulations against Australian premium rate service companies that are preying on and profiting from vulnerable consumers without adequate disclosure of the cost of their services and if he will not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A draft Telecommunications Service Provider (Premium Services) Determination 2003 was released by the ACA for public comment on 8 April 2003. The draft determination was also provided separately to the previous Minister on 9 April 2003.

The main driver for the determination on the 190 call capping proposal was to address concerns that people were receiving unexpected high bills from âInternet dumpingâ. However, the urgency of the problem of unexpected high bills on the 190 range was removed when Telstra discontinued supporting Internet diallers on its 190 platform, with effect from August 2003. Under these new conditions, the draft determination was no longer an appropriate regulatory response to address the issue of unexpected high bills.
On 21 April 2004, I announced a new strategy for dealing with unexpected high bills for a wide range of telecommunications services, including mobile and broadband services.

I directed the ACA to report to Government within six months on credit management measures that the industry has in place or is developing, and whether the ACA considers the action and commitment of the industry to have been adequate. If industry fails to provide an adequate strategy, the Government will put regulations in place for the protection of consumers.

(2) The draft determination contained rules relating to call capping and information to customers. The rules in the ACA's draft determination which related to the provision of information to customers applied to premium rate services on the 0011 range as well as 190 services. I recently affirmed the previous direction to the ACA to implement these rules.

The draft service provider rule on call capping did not apply to premium rate 0011 services as Australian carriers cannot, at the time the calls are made, distinguish calls made to premium 0011 services from other 0011 calls. I have directed the ACA to report to Government within six months on the appropriateness of a service provider determination that requires carriage service providers to bar access to certain international numbers or number ranges which appear to have been used to provide premium rate services, such as Internet dialler services, causing unexpected high bills.

(3) The Telecommunications Service Provider Determination 2004 (No. 1), made by the ACA on 19 May 2004, requires service providers to supply their customers with information relating to premium rate services as soon as practicable after the person becomes a customer. The term customer is defined broadly, to include any person who is capable of accessing the relevant premium rate services, regardless of whether the person has accessed these services or intends to do so.

In addition, the Government is taking steps to ensure that telecommunications consumers in general are aware of the risks associated with premium rate services. The ACA provides this information, for example, through its `Internet Tool Kit'.

(4) The Government is giving the industry an opportunity to put in place credit management measures to protect consumers from unexpected high bills. The industry may consider it appropriate that optional credit limits for customer accounts be among these measures. If the Government considers that industry has failed to provide an adequate strategy, it will put regulations in place.

(5) Internet dialler services no longer operate on the 190 number range. The ACA has been directed to report to the Government within six months on the appropriateness of a service provider determination that would require carriage service providers to bar access to certain international numbers or number ranges which appear to have been used to provide premium rate services, such as Internet dialler services, causing unexpected high bills.

(6) The Government has directed the ACA to report within six months on credit management measures that are in place or being implemented by service providers to address unexpected high bills across all telecommunications services, including broadband services. The Government will put regulations in place for the protection of consumers if industry fails to develop an adequate strategy.

(7) The premium rate service providers industry is self-regulated by the Telephone Information Services Standards Council (TISSC) which has a customer complaints service called 190Complaints. In April 2004, TISSC advised that the number of outstanding complaints it has about premium rate services was 3,970. TISSC has advised that the outstanding complaints relate to 190 Internet dialler services, which were discontinued at the end of August last year, and that the vast majority of these complaints relate to services that were operated by Sound Advertising and Mediatel Services.

The Government considers TISSC to be the appropriate organisation to handle outstanding complaints about Internet dumping on the 190 number range. Consumers may also take their concerns to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, state and territory fair trading offices and the courts.
(8) See the answers to parts (1) and (7) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister able to say how much revenue Telstra derives annually from 190 numbers; if not, (a) can he explain why Telstra considers that the amount of revenue derived from 190 numbers should be commercial in confidence information, and (b) does he support Telstra in withholding this information from the public.

(2) Further to the answer to question No. 1319 (Hansard, 14 May 2003, page 14327), (a) on what basis does Telstra claim that it does not receive revenue from International 0011 premium rate services and (b) is it the case that Telstra automatically charges its consumers for all 0011 calls made on their accounts regardless of whether they are standard calls or calls for premium type services.

(3) Is he able to say whether Telstra currently has access arrangements or contractual agreements with (a) Mediatel Services, and (b) Sound Advertising for the supply of premium rate services; if this information is commercial in confidence, can he explain on what basis it is commercial in confidence.

(4) Can he confirm reports that Telstra recently withdrew from the 190 Internet dialler or similar market; if so, (a) what are the details of the services which Telstra ceased to provide, (b) on what date did Telstra cease to provide these services, and (c) why did Telstra cease providing these services.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Telstra has advised that revenue derived from 190 Premium services is not provided as a separate line item in Telstra's financial statements. Telstra considers the revenue data to be commercial-in-confidence as it is a premium product in a highly competitive market. Telstra considers that the disclosure of its revenue may cause Telstra commercial harm. (b) Telstra is an independent corporation, whose Board and senior management are responsible for the overall operation of the company, including any decisions relating to disclosure of revenue data.

(2) (a) Telstra has advised that it does not offer an âInternational 0011 Premium Rateâ product. All International Direct 0011 calls are charged in accordance with the applicable per minute rate for the relevant international destination as set out in Telstra's Standard Form of Agreement. In charging for International Direct calls, Telstra is unable to differentiate between calls dialled in the normal way by a human customer and calls dialled by a computer modem. (b) Telstra advised that where a 0011 International Direct call is made by a consumer, including a call dialled from a modem, the call will be charged to the consumer's account in accordance with the applicable per minute 0011 International Direct call rate.

(3) (a) and (b) Telstra has advised that it has contractual agreements with Mediatel Services. In relation to Sound Advertising, Telstra has advised that it terminated its provision of 190 services to Sound Advertising in August 2003 as part of its exit from the Internet dialler services market. However, Telstra continues to have a service provider arrangement with Gallery Global Networks, the parent company of Sound Advertising.

(4) (a) and (b) Telstra has advised that it ceased to provide Internet dialler access to premium 190 services on 25 August 2003. Telstra has advised that it took this course of action in response to community and government concern regarding Internet dialler services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 10 February 2004:

question.para: (1) For each year since 1995, how many vessels have been detected carrying firearms into Australia without the appropriate permits or other documents necessary for legal importation.
(2) What illegal firearms was each of these vessels carrying.
(3) What are the details of any successful prosecutions arising from the detection of these vessels and what were the sentences of those convicted of an offence.
(4) For each year since 1995, how many vessels have been detected carrying prohibited drugs into Australia.
(5) Where were these vessels detected and interdicted.
(6) What are the details of any successful prosecutions arising from the detection of these vessels.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) In 1995 detained firearms were not recorded separately in Customs records but were recorded as prohibited imports. The identification of recording of specific incidents relating to surrender or seizure during this time are extremely difficult and time consuming to locate as this requires the physical reviewing of each record to establish if the prohibited good detained was a firearm. The extraction of data for the last five years reveals that there have been no major seizures of firearms from commercial vessels during that period, and given the resources required to undertake research in earlier years the decision was taken to forego any further research into the earlier years.
(4) There have been three major drug detections on commercial vessels since 1995:

a. In October 1998, 389.74 kilograms of heroin was seized at Grant's Beach in NSW. The heroin had been offloaded via dinghy from the vessel MVUNIANA, a Belize registered vessel. Following detection of the drugs on Grant's Beach, the MVUNIANA was stopped and boarded off the Port Macquarie coast where Customs and Australian Federal Police (AFP) officers arrested the crew. The vessel was then delivered to Sydney.
b. In July 2001, 1117kg of cocaine was seized at Dulverton Bay on the Western Australian coast. Three persons, using a smaller inflatable vessel, were landing the cocaine from an ocean going tug.

c. In April 2003, 125 kilograms of heroin was seized in the Lorne area, Victoria. The heroin had been off loaded by dinghy from the vessel PONG SU. The PONG SU began to sail from the scene after detection of the drugs, and was intercepted by Special Operations Forces from the HMAS STUART who boarded the vessel 35 nautical miles South-East of Newcastle, NSW. The PONG SU was delivered to Sydney.
(5) The vessels were detected and interdicted as follows:
a. Grant's Beach, NSW.
b. Dulverton Bay, WA.
c. Lorne Area, VIC.
(6) The Australian Federal Police have provided the following information in respect of (4) above:
a. MV UNIANA:
ten (10) successful prosecutions resulting in the following sentences:
1 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 19yrs (Captain of the MV UNIANA)
2 x life imprisonment with no parole date
1 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 30yrs (syndicate principle)
2 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 24yrs
1 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 18yrs
2 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 20yrs
1 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 10yrs
b. Dulverton Bay:
two (2) successful prosecutions resulting in the following sentences;
1 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 18yrs
1 x life imprisonment with non-parole period of 26yrs
c. PONG SU: Prosecution of this matter has not yet concluded.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 17 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware that the Sinn Fein leader, Mr Gerry Adams, addressed the National Press Club in Canberra on Wednesday, 11 February 2004.
(2) Is he also aware that the ABC, which usually broadcasts the Wednesday addresses live, aired a repeat of an earlier speech rather than Mr Adams' address.
(3) Can he confirm that the decision not to show the program live was taken because the ABC was concerned about possible controversy that may have arisen as a result of Mr Adams' comments.
(4) Does the ABC reserve the right to censor contributions from political leaders who appear at the National Press Club; if so, why and under what authority.
(5) Who in the ABC made the decision to delay the broadcast.
(6) Was that person subject to any outside or Board influence; if so by whom.
(7) Does the ABC's decision constitute political censorship; if not, why not.
(8) How many times in the past twelve months has the ABC failed to broadcast a Press Club address live on a Wednesday and broadcast a repeat of an earlier address instead.

(9) Is he able to provide (a) the names of political leaders who have addressed the National Press club on a Wednesday in the last 12 months and the dates of their addresses, (b) a list of those leaders whose addresses were not broadcast live by the ABC, (c) the reasons for the decision in each instance an address was not broadcast live by the ABC.
(10) Will the Gerry Adams National Press Club address be broadcast at a later date; if so, (a) when, and (b) will it be aired unedited; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
The ABC has advised that the decision to delay broadcast was taken for reasons of scheduling and timeliness and not because of any perception of possible controversy.

The ABC has advised that it is not uncommon practice to record programs to fill later dates. For example, the National Press Club broadcast on 11 November 2003 featured George Savvides - Managing Director of Medibank Private, and Professor Ian Harper, Business School, University of Melbourne, discussing current private health issues. This address was recorded on 4 November 2003. The Executive Producer of the program has advised that he chose to schedule the broadcast of this address during a parliamentary sitting week when the issue of private health insurance was more likely to be of interest to the audience.

Also, on occasions when speakers cancel at late notice, the ABC is obliged by its agreement with the National Press Club to replay a first-run episode that has been recorded earlier in the year. For example, when the Thai Deputy Prime Minister, Suwit Kun Kitty, fell ill a few days before his scheduled address on November 19 2003, the Executive Producer scheduled an address by President of the Australian Conservation Foundation, Peter Garrett, recorded earlier in the year.
(4) The ABC has advised: âNo. Speakers are invited by the National Press Club Board, not the ABC.â
(5) The ABC has advised that the decision to record the address for later broadcast was taken by the Executive Producer, Eric Napper.
(6) The ABC has advised that there was no outside or ABC Board influence.
(7) The ABC has advised that the decision does not constitute political censorship, just standard broadcasting practice of ensuring an advance schedule of quality programs.

(8) The ABC has advised that the ABC's agreement with the National Press Club provides for 3 runs of any given address, so any Wednesday without a speaker must be filled with pre-recorded programs.
