It is standard practice to select programs with a long shelf life to pre-record for replay when the National Press Club cannot provide a live address.

On Wednesday, February 4, 2003 the ABC broadcast an address by Professor George Williams, from the University of NSW on the topic, âAustralian Values and the War Against Terrorismâ, recorded on January 29, 2003. The live speaker at the Press Club on February 4 was Lama Ole Nydahl, a western master of the Karma Kagyu School of Tibetan Buddhism whose scheduled address was titled âPhowa - Buddhist meditation on conscious dying, useful in Western society?â The address by Professor Williams was deemed more suitable for the TV audience.
The ABC has advised that it played pre-recorded first-run programs on a Wednesday on the following occasions during the past 12 months:

entry.para: Amin SaikalDir, Arab & Islamic Studies, ANU

answer.para: The ABC has provided the following list of political leaders whose National Press Club addresses have been used during the past 12 months - including the recording date and the broadcast date.
The ABC has advised that the Gerry Adams address was broadcast in its entirety on April 14, 2004, at 1pm, with an early morning repeat on Thursday, April 15 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What are the administrative arrangements underpinning the establishment and operation of Coastwatch.
(2) Pursuant to which legislation does Coastwatch undertake its responsibilities.
(3) Which client agencies used the services of Coastwatch during the 2003 calendar year.
(4) Which client agencies provided intelligence to Coastwatch during the calendar year 2003 and what was the source and nature of that intelligence.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Coastwatch is an operational Division of the Australian Customs Service (Customs), which was established under the Customs Administration Act 1985.
(2) Coastwatch derives its authority on the basis of Customs legislation.
(3) The following agencies used the services of Coastwatch during 2003:
Department of Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs
Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
- Australian Fisheries Management Authority
- Australian Quarantine & Inspection Service
Attorney-General's Department
- Australian Federal Police
- Australian Customs Service
Department of the Environment and Heritage
- Australian Antarctic Division
- Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority
- Bureau of Meteorology
Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources
Department of Transport and Regional Services
- Australian Maritime Safety Authority

(4) Intelligence from client agencies related to possible unauthorised entry of people, prohibited goods including guns and drugs and vessels in Australia's maritime zones; and possible illegal fishing activities in Australia's Fishing Zones.
The client agencies that provided intelligence to Coastwatch during the calendar year 2003 were:

Department of Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs, Australian Federal Police, Department of Defence, Australian Customs Service, Australian Fisheries Management Authority, Australian Antarctic Division, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio, and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Has an inquiry been undertaken by Coastwatch or any other Government agency in respect of the arrival of undetected suspect illegal entry vessels on the West and North coasts of Australia; if so, what was the outcome of those inquiries and are the reports from those inquiries publicly available.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: An enquiry is undertaken whenever an undetected suspect illegal entry vessel arrives in Australia. The reports are classified and not publicly available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) With which agencies has Coastwatch entered into a memorandum of understanding.
(2) Are those memoranda of understanding publicly available.
(3) With which agencies is Coastwatch negotiating a memorandum of understanding.
(4) When is it anticipated those memoranda of understanding will be finalised.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Customs Service has a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA). In addition, Coastwatch has bilateral Service Agreements which set out respective roles and service levels, with the Australian Federal Police (AFP), the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA), the Department of the Environment and Heritage (DEH), the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS), and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

Coastwatch has separate MOUs with AFMA in relation to the provision of Vessel Monitoring System data, and with the Department of Defence (Defence) in relation to the trial of High Frequency Surface Wave Radar in the Torres Strait.
(2) These documents are not available publicly.

(3) Coastwatch has commenced negotiations with AQIS in relation to an MOU for the provision of the Coastwatch Command and Support System (CWCSS) to that agency. Coastwatch is also negotiating MOUs with AFMA and with DEH in relation to use of Coastwatch mapping data.
Coastwatch has approached the Department of Defence and the United States Coastguard about concluding MOUs.
(4) Coastwatch has not set a deadline for completion of these MOUs, but expects them to be completed in 2004-05.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What effect will the decision by the Australian Navy to phase out the Fremantle Class patrol boats have on the operations of Coastwatch.
(2) What plans are being put into place to address the consequences of that decision in respect of the period from 1 January 2003 to date.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Australian Customs Service has liaised extensively with the Department of Defence in relation to the phasing out of the Fremantle Class Patrol Boats and their replacement by the Armidale Class Patrol Boats, including by providing input to the technical specifications for the new boats.

When fully operational, the Armidale Class will provide a faster, more technologically advanced surface response capability than the FCPB fleet. Defence will continue to provide the current level of support for the Civil Maritime Surveillance Program at the allocated rate of 1800 days per annum.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Has Coastwatch expressed to (a) the Australian Customs Service, and (b) the Minister's office concerns regarding cooperation received from Coastwatch's key client agencies; if so, what was the nature of those reports and what steps have been undertaken to improve the cooperation.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) Coastwatch is part of Customs.
(b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What assets are owned by Coastwatch.
(2) What assets are co-ordinated by Coastwatch and, in particular, what are the number and type of civilian contractor aircraft co-ordinated.
(3) What are the number and nature of Defence aircraft co-ordinated.
(4) What are the nature and number of marine vessels co-ordinated.
(5) What are the nature and number of Australian Customs Service marine vessels co-ordinated.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Coastwatch owns no major assets. Customs owns the equipment installed in the Coastwatch National Surveillance Centre, normal office furniture and some of the communications equipment installed on Coastwatch contracted aircraft.
(2) Coastwatch coordinates the following civilian contracted aircraft:
five Dash 8 aircraft
three Reims F406 aircraft
one Shrike aircraft
six Islander aircraft
one single engine helicopter
one twin engine helicopter

(3) Department of Defence allocates to the Coastwatch component of the Civil Maritime Surveillance Program up to 250 maritime patrol aircraft hours per annum. When a suitable Coastwatch asset is not readily available, Coastwatch may submit a tasking request for Defence assistance against these hours.

(4) Department of Defence allocates to the Coastwatch component of the Civil Maritime Surveillance Program up to 1800 Fremantle Class Patrol Boats (FCPB) per annum. When a suitable Customs asset is not readily available to undertake a surface response, Coastwatch may submit a tasking request for Defence assistance against these days.
(5) The Australian Customs Service has eight Bay class offshore patrol vessels in the Customs National Marine Unit which provide a platform for surface response. (See QoN 3077).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: What types of services were requested of Coastwatch during the calendar year 2003 and by which clients were those services requested.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The following Coastwatch clients requested surveillance services during 2003:

answer.para: Department of Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs
Australian Fisheries Management Authority
Australian Quarantine & Inspection Service
Australian Federal Police
Australian Customs Service
Department of the Environment and Heritage
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority
Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources
Department of Transport and Regional Services

quote.para: The following agencies requested coordination of responses:

answer.para: Department of Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs
Australian Fisheries Management Authority
Australian Quarantine & Inspection Service
Australian Federal Police
Australian Customs Service
Department of the Environment and Heritage
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority

quote.para: Client agencies and the Queensland State Police also requested that Coastwatch helicopters provide transport for officers and equipment in the Torres Strait.
The Australian Maritime Safety Agency requested support for search and rescue activities.
Coastwatch also conducted surveillance missions under Operation RELEX II, which is controlled by Head Quarters Northern Command (HQNORCOM).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) How many operational planning committees exist within the structure of Coastwatch.
(2) Have there been any changes to the (a) structure, and (b) method of operation of those committees in the past 3 years; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) There is one operational planning committee - the Planning Advisory Sub-Committee (PASC). It is the Coastwatch forum for engaging client agencies and public sector service providers in the planning of strategic surveillance and response operations.

(2) A review of PASC has caused a change in its focus. The meetings, held monthly, now review previous achievements, and consider, in detail, future tasking requests and asset availability. Meetings are attended by operational staff representing Coastwatch clients, public sector service providers and Coastwatch planners.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: What is the method or methods of communication used between Coastwatch and client organisations.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Communication between Coastwatch and its clients is almost constant and can be by telephone, facsimile, e-mail, video-conference or face to face.
The Coastwatch Command Support System (CWCSS) is the prime interface for Coastwatch clients in relation to operational activity.
Regular meetings of client groups provide more formal communication at both the regional and central office levels.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Which private sector contractors provided services to Coastwatch during the 2002-03 financial year and what was the nature and cost of those services which were provided.
(2) What private sector contractors will provide services to Coastwatch during the 2003-04 financial year and what will be the nature and cost of those services.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The following private sector contractors provided surveillance services to Coastwatch during 2002-03:

entry.para: Provision of satellite detection and tracking services.

answer.para: In addition there were a number of contractors providing auxiliary services relating to Coastwatch business and others providing consultancy services related to the provision of civil maritime surveillance beyond the duration of the current contracts.
(2) The following private sector contractors will provide surveillance services to Coastwatch during 2003-04:

entry.para: Provision of satellite detection and tracking services.

answer.para: In addition there will be a number of contractors providing auxiliary services relating to Coastwatch business and others providing consultancy services related to the provision of civil maritime surveillance beyond the duration of the current contracts.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Does Coastwatch apply a performance measurement system to private sector contractors; if so, with which private sector contractors was such a performance measurement system applied during the 2003 calendar year.
(2) Is Coastwatch revising any performance assessment systems that it applies; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. All Coastwatch contracts with the private sector contain measures of performance.
(2) Coastwatch is reviewing the performance management systems in the current contracts for inclusion in the new contracts for civil maritime surveillance beyond 2007.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Which agencies and private sector contractors provide marine services to Coastwatch and what services are so provided.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Australian Customs Service, through the National Marine Unit (NMU) provides the services of its eight Bay class offshore Australian Customs Vessels (ACV). Customs may also charter vessels from the private sector on a case-by-case basis to meet specific client agency requirements. An example of this will be the vessel that will be used for armed patrols in the Southern Ocean in the next two financial years.
Department of Defence provides the services of its Fremantle Class Patrol Boats (FCPB).

The ACV's and FCPBs provide a platform for surface response to, and interception of, possible breaches of Australian legislation as they relate to activity in the Australian Exclusive Economic Zone (AEEZ). This includes the exercise of powers of hot pursuit beyond the AEEZ.
These vessels also contribute to surveillance of the AEEZ.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Has any Government organisation or agency inquired into the adequacy of intelligence provided by client agencies to Coastwatch and whether that intelligence is provided in a timely manner; if so, (a) what was the nature of those reports, and (b) what steps have been taken to improve the quality and timeliness of that intelligence information.
(2) To what extent is Coastwatch reliant on intelligence provided by its national surveillance centre.
(3) To what extent is Coastwatch reliant on client agencies to gather and assess relevant intelligence.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) ANAO Report 38 of 1999-2000 examined inter alia the adequacy of intelligence provided by client agencies.
(b) The Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force of June 1999, identified concerns in relation to the adequacy and timeliness of intelligence provided to Coastwatch.
(b) Following these reports, the Government provided funding for the installation of the Coastwatch National Surveillance Centre (NSC) and for the development of the Coastwatch Analysis Unit (CWAU).
(2) The Coastwatch Analysis Unit provides intelligence support to Coastwatch surveillance and response activities including by:
maintaining the Intelligence Support Plan which informs the Coastwatch Risk Assessment Methodology;
providing timely warning of short-notice operational threats that may require re-deployment of Coastwatch assets;
maintaining working relationships with client agencies, in order to assist with their tasking development;
representing Coastwatch in national intelligence collection planning processes; and
providing a conduit for clients to task national agencies - such as Defence - for intelligence collection and analysis in support of client priorities.

(3) Coastwatch is not a designated intelligence collector, and therefore is dependent on the ability of clients and other intelligence agencies to gather information, through their respective intelligence sources and relevant to their individual area[s] of expertise. This information is passed to the Coastwatch Analysis Unit, which assesses the information against all-source intelligence holdings. These assessments are used to support Coastwatch's operational activity, and are distributed back to relevant agencies with Coastwatch's evaluation of the threat posed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What is the method by which Coastwatch ranks specified mission objectives or targets.
(2) Have there been any changes in Coastwatch tasking and priority settings during the past 3 years; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) See the answer to Question on Notice No 3093.

(2) Taskings and priority settings are reviewed and updated on a regular basis. In particular, during the extensive reviews undertaken with client agencies while developing and implementing the Coastwatch Risk Management Methodology, taskings and priority settings for each client agency were further refined extensively.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: How many operation staff did Coastwatch assess for technical skills during 2003 and what were the findings of the assessments.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: During 2003, 632 Coastwatch missions, involving a total of 1929 crew, were assessed by Coastwatch Check and Training Officers. All but four of the 632 missions were assessed at above the requisite level of 90 per cent.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Has any inquiry identified a potential conflict of interest between services provided by Coastwatch to the Australian Customs Service and other client agencies; if so, what steps have been taken to address potential conflicts of interest.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Prime Minister's Task Force on Coastal Surveillance examined the potential for perception of a conflict of interest between services provided by Coastwatch to the Australian Customs Service (Customs) and those provided to other client agencies, under the organisational arrangements that existed at that time. The Task Force recommended that the Chief Executive Officer of Customs retain control of Coastwatch as part of Customs. Recommendations, subsequently implemented to address the potential for perception of conflict of interest, included separating Coastwatch from the then Border Management Division to become an independent Division within Customs, and appointing a senior Australian Defence Force officer as Director-General Coastwatch.

Australian National Audit Office [ANAO] Audit Report No 38: Review of Coastwatch reviewed the revised organisational arrangements and noted that they would promote the perception of a semi-autonomous or independent Coastwatch. The ANAO also noted that Coastwatch derived benefits from being located with Customs. These benefits included access to Customs staff, and command and control structures designed for a law enforcement environment; and the achievement of savings by use of Customs information technology infrastructure.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) For which years has Coastwatch undertaken client surveys.
(2) Are those surveys publicly available; if not, will the Minister provide copies of those surveys.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Previous arrangements, whereby a formal bi-annual survey was sent to client agencies for completion, have been replaced by a more regular process of seeking client feedback during Operations and Program Advisory Committee; Planning Advisory Sub Committee, and Regional Operations and Program Advisory Committee meetings; and during post-operation evaluations. In addition, representatives of client agencies, flying on Coastwatch aircraft, are requested to complete a survey form and forward it to Coastwatch.
(2) Not available for operational reasons.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Does Coastwatch standardise its task ranking methodology.
(2) Has Coastwatch provided its clients with guides to enable those clients to assess the importance of their own tasking.
(3) During the year 2003 was there communication between Coastwatch and any other agency in respect of the assessment of the importance of tasking by Coastwatch or the agency.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Coastwatch standardises its task ranking methodology through the Coastwatch Risk Assessment Methodology (CRAM). Further information in relation to CRAM is in my answer to Question on Notice 3093.
(2) Yes. The CRAM process was developed and is being implemented in consultation with client agencies.
(3) Yes. See (2) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What performance information systems and indicators are available in respect of the operations of Coastwatch.
(2) To what extent do those systems reflect overall performance relevant to key client agencies.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Coastwatch Command and Support System (CWCSS) provides a comprehensive information management system, integrating operational planning and logistical support; and surveillance events into a common `restricted' level system. The data contained in the system is used to evaluate the effectiveness of the surveillance effort.

CWCSS is supported by databases that provide detailed information on surveillance activity and response and interception outcomes. It is anticipated that the information captured by these databases will be incorporated into CWCSS in a future release of that system.
Coastwatch's performance indicators are set out in the Australian Customs Service Annual Report 2002-03 and in the relevant Portfolio Budget Statement.

Additionally Coastwatch maintains a comprehensive performance measurement system in respect of delivery of surveillance service by private sector aerial surveillance contractors. The Department of Defence also provides data on the surveillance undertaken by its aerial assets.

(2) CWCSS provides the Australian Customs Service, the Department of the Environment and Heritage, and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with detailed information on surveillance activity, relevant to their individual tasks, through on-line post mission reports. Other agencies receive this information by e-mail or facsimile. CWCSS access for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and for the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs is being negotiated. No other client agencies have sought CWCSS access.

Each client agency attending an Operations and Program Advisory Committee or a Planning Advisory Sub-Committee meeting is provided with data on surveillance activity and response outcomes relevant to its tasks, allowing that agency to assess performance against their own indicators. Other data is provided to agencies in bilateral discussions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Has Coastwatch endeavoured to strengthen ties with the United States Coastguard.

(2) Has Coastwatch undertaken a comparison between the nature of surveillance and response functions undertaken by Coastwatch and the United States Coast Guard; if so what did that comparison reveal in respect of (a) surveillance functions, (b) response functions, (c) alternative delivery platforms, and (e) administrative systems.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Coastwatch has an ongoing dialogue with the United States Coast Guard, which is strengthened by liaison visits by each agency, the exchange of relevant intelligence, the sharing of information in relation to emergent technology, and operational experience in relation to surveillance infrastructure and planning.

(2) Coastwatch has not prepared a comparison of the nature of surveillance and response functions undertaken by Coastwatch and the United States Coast Guard. The organisations are so different in size, structure and operational environment that a side by side comparison would not be a useful exercise.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: What was the total cost of services provided by Coastwatch during the financial year ending 30 June 2003 and what was the Defence component of that cost.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The total cost of services provided by Coastwatch during the financial year ended 30 June 2003 was $96.773 million. In addition there were $55.666 million of resources received free of charge from the Australian Defence Force. This is separate from the cost of Operation RELEX II, which is reported by Department of Defence.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: What has been the response of (a) Coastwatch, and (b) the Australian Customs Service to the report of the Australian National Audit Office into Coastwatch dated 6 April 2002.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) Coastwatch did not make a separate response to the ANAO Report dated 6 April 2002.
(b) The ANAO Report contained 15 separate recommendations. Customs agreed with all recommendations made by the Audit Office, but qualified its agreement in relation to three recommendations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: What internal and external reports into Coastwatch related incidents have been prepared since 6 April 2000 and which are publicly available.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The following reports, involving consideration of incidents that include activities undertaken by Coastwatch, have been prepared since 6 April 2000.

answer.para: The Senate Select Committee into a Certain Maritime Incident reported in October 2002. This report is publicly available.

A Western Australian coronial investigation report â Record of Investigation into Death - (Ref No 29/02) - Inquest into the death of Nurjan Husseini & Fatimeh Husseiniâ was handed down on 13 December 2002. This report is publicly available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) How many meetings of the Operations and Program Advisory Committee of Coastwatch occurred during calendar year 2003.
(2) Did the committee recommend revision of long term flight plans; if so, what recommendations were made and which have been implemented.
(3) Did the committee recommend revision of shorter term tactical tasking; if so, what recommendations were made and have those recommendations been acted upon.
(4) How many meetings of the Regional Operations and Program Advisory Committee occurred during calendar year 2003.
(5) What were the major decisions of that committee.
(6) How many meetings of the Planning Advisory Sub Committee occurred during the calendar year ending 2003.
(7) What determinations were made by that Committee in respect of the long term marine surface support requirements of Coastwatch clients during calendar year 2003.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Four

(2) No. The overall results of surveillance activities are presented at OPAC as a routine agenda item in the form of a Surveillance Operations and Planning Report. This provides an avenue for clients to provide feedback on the program.
(3) No: The OPAC does not consider short term tactical tasking.
(4) In 2003, there were four ROPAC meetings in Darwin, four in Fremantle, five in Broome, nine in Cairns one in Brisbane and eleven in Thursday Island.

(5) ROPAC meetings are forums that facilitate information exchange and discussion of operational activity between Coastwatch and Regional clients, rather than decision-making bodies. Regional clients do not have the authority to task Coastwatch without the prior approval of their Head Offices.
(6) Eleven PASC Meetings were conducted during 2003.

(7) Each PASC meeting reviews the Royal Australian Navy and the Customs National Marine Unit Planned Sailing Programs for the coming months. Client requests and coordination issues are discussed, then followed up in writing if appropriate by the relevant agency and coordinated through Coastwatch to the Navy or the NMU.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) How many vessels and what type of vessels were involved in each of the long term sailing plans developed by Coastwatch during calendar year ending 2003.
(2) For how many hours did each of the vessels operate.
(3) How many aircraft and what type of aircraft were involved in each of the long term flying programs developed by Coastwatch during calendar year ending 2003.
(4) For how many hours did each of the aircraft operate.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Long term sailing programs for the eight Bay class offshore patrol vessels are developed by the National Marine Unit in consultation with Coastwatch and client agencies.

The long-term sailing programs for the Fremantle Class Patrol Boat fleet are prepared and issued by the Department of Defence. Figures on deployment of Defence assets should be sought from that agency.

(2) Operational vessel days are used as the basis for sailing programs for Australian Customs Service Vessels (ACBs). The operational vessel days achieved by each vessel in the ACV fleet during the 2003 calendar year were:
Roebuck Bay - 309
Holdfast Bay - 270
Botany Bay - 305
Hervey Bay - 319
Corio Bay - 295
Arnhem Bay - 302
Dame Roma Mitchell - 301
Storm Bay - 295
(3) and (4) Seventeen Coastwatch contracted aircraft were involved in the 1993 long term flying programs developed by Coastwatch.
Long term flying programs were also developed during this period by Department of Defence. Figures on deployment of Defence assets should be sought from that agency.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) On how many occasions were tactical issue meetings conducted by Coastwatch during calendar year 2003.
(2) In respect of each meeting, what date was it held, which client agencies attended and what was the subject matter discussed.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Meetings in relation to tactical issues occur almost daily, and in the event of a tactical operation, can be conducted many times throughout each day.

(2) Details of all tactical issues meetings held in 2003 are not available. However, as a general comment, relevant client agencies would attend, depending on the nature of the issue and security implications. The subject matter discussed would relate to the tactical issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Has Coastwatch developed guidelines and outlined the roles and responsibilities of Coastwatch and its clients regarding Coastwatch activities.
(2) Are those guidelines publicly available; if not, will the Minister provide a copy.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) See my response to Question on Notice 3067. In addition, the Coastwatch Manual for Surveillance Units outlines the roles and responsibilities of Coastwatch and its clients in relation to Coastwatch activities.
(2) Not available for operational reasons.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Does Coastwatch have a common risk assessment process to rank various client requests; if so, how does it operate.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Coastwatch Client Common Risk Assessment Methodology (CRAM) has been developed in consultation with Coastwatch clients to provide a risk assessment process that allows all client threats to be considered against a common unit of measurement.

During the initial CRAM consultative processes, a number of high-level threats that covered the interests of most Coastwatch clients were identified. From each of the high-level threats, client agencies derived specific risks relevant to their areas of interest.

The severity assessment is a two-step process. First, each client-specific risk is assessed for consequence, according to the potential impact it would represent to Australia's economic, environmental and community interests. Weighting factors are assigned to each of these impact categories. The consequence figure for each threat is then modified by an assessment of the likelihood of that threat occurring in each location, thus producing a notional risk score. A similar process is followed for each threat identified by each client in each of the Coastwatch defined geographic areas.

The output of this process is a ranking of relative merit for each client task in each geographic area, rather than a set of absolute scores of assigned risk. The rankings are used to inform the nature and frequency of surveillance to be programmed; and to assist planners in the resolution of resource allocation conflicts if competing surveillance tasking requirements arise.
Preliminary CRAM scores have been distributed and are in use. Finalization of the CRAM implementation phase is expected by mid 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: What are the steps followed by Coastwatch upon receiving a strategic or tactical tasking from a client agency.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Coastwatch's strategic flying program is developed from surveillance tasks submitted by Coastwatch's client agencies. The outline program is planned two to three months in advance. Under the Coastwatch Risk Assessment Methodology, each client agency has developed a risk assessed score for the threats to its interests within each of the nominated Coastwatch operational areas and sub-areas.

The aim of the flying program is to meet the priority tasks while maximising economy of effort through the multi-tasking of aircraft. For example, in the normal course of events an aircraft programmed to conduct what is primarily a fisheries surveillance task would also fulfil other client agencies taskings above the risk assessed threshold.

The Civil Maritime Surveillance Planning Advisory Sub-Committee (PASC), comprising operational representatives from Coastwatch, its client agencies and public sector service providers, meets each month to consider the proposed flying program for the following two months and to review the outcomes of the program for the previous month.
In the lead-up to each flight, Coastwatch staff develop detailed briefings relevant to that mission. These briefings are provided on-line to aircrew through the Coastwatch Command and Support System.

The time critical nature of the great majority of requests for tactical surveillance does not allow for the forward planning available through the PASC system. Requests for tactical tasks are submitted to Coastwatch on an ad hoc basis and are assessed against the risk and priority of relevant programmed surveillance activity. If there is a conflict about the relative priority of tasks, the Director-General Coastwatch is the final arbiter in any decision to redeploy assets.
Both tactical and strategic operations are conducted according to the Coastwatch Standard Operating Procedures, which are detailed in the Coastwatch Manual for Surveillance Units.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: During calendar year 2003, did Coastwatch find it necessary to supplement existing fixed and rotary wing services with charter flights from other service providers; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Yes. Seven separate companies provided a total of 43.83 hours at a cost of $51,705.30.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) For how many days during the calendar year 2003 was radar used in coastal surveillance not in service.
(2) For each instance, what were the reasons for the lack of radar service.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Coastwatch was notified on 10 occasions during 2003 that the radar to be used in a contracted surveillance aircraft mission was unserviceable.
(2) The contract does not require the aircraft provider to give the specific reason for the radar's unserviceability.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: For calendar year (a) 2001, (b) 2002, and (c) 2003, how many suspect illegal entry vessels identified by aircraft attached to Coastwatch were followed by Coastwatch marine interception.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: For the calendar year 2001, 48 Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessels (SIEVs) were detected. Coastwatch aircraft sighted 14 SIEVs and the Australian Customs National Marine Unit (NMU) detected 11 SIEVs. The remainder of the detections were by Australian Defence Force assets, police personnel and a member of the public. There were marine interceptions for the 48 detections.
In 2002, there was one detection of a SIEV by a Customs NMU vessel.
In 2003, there were two sighting of SIEVs by members of the public. They were both followed by Defence marine interceptions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Would the Minister provide a list of the marine vessels in the National Marine Unit (NMU).

(2) In respect of each vessel, (a) how many crew does it require, (b) what is its patrolling, surveillance and interception capability, (c) what is its range, (d) for what period of time is it anticipated that the NMU will utilise it during 2004, (e) what are its dimensions, and (f) what is its running cost per day.
(3) To what extent are the services of the NMU utilised by Coastwatch.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The NMU operates the following Bay class Australian Customs Vessels (ACVs):
ACV Roebuck Bay
ACV Holdfast Bay
ACV Botany Bay
ACV Corio Bay
ACV Hervey Bay
ACV Arnhem Bay
ACV Storm Bay
ACV Dame Roma Mitchell
(2) (a) ACVs have a nominal crew of eight who are supplemented as required for specific activities/operations.

(b) ACVs are capable of patrolling out to, and sometimes beyond, the 200 nautical mile Exclusive Economic Zone anywhere around Australia's 37,000 kilometres of coastline. Joint patrols are also conducted within the territorial seas of some neighbouring countries. ACVs can deploy two 6.4 metre Pursuit 640) tenders capable of conducting intercepts at speeds in excess of 30 knots.
(c) The Bay Class vessel range is 1000 nautical miles at 20 knots (with a 25% reserve). In excess of 3000 nm at slower speed.
(d) The eight ACVs are anticipated to contribute in the order of 2400 seadays to the National Civil Maritime Surveillance and Response Program in 2004.
(e) Bay Class Vessel dimensions are:
Length Overall - 38.2 metres
Beam - 7.2 metres
Draught - 1.9 metres
Displacement - 128 Tonnes
(f) In the order of $19k per day.
(3) Coastwatch uses the NMU assets up to 2400 days per year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Has the Minister received a memorandum, statement, report or other document commenting on the comparative effectiveness of using (a) Bay class vessels, and (b) Fremantle class patrol boats for the towing of impounded vessels; if so, what were the contents of the document or documents.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) No; not applicable.
(b) No; not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) How many communication centres currently operate within the Coastwatch network, what are their titles and what are their responsibilities.
(2) Have any concerns been expressed about the Coastwatch communication network by aircraft or Fremantle class patrol boat communications operators; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Coastwatch National Surveillance Centre has two 24/7 watchkeeper roles - one dealing with operational communications, and one with intelligence communications and analysis. They are located within the Coastwatch National Surveillance Centre at the Operations Desk and in the Coastwatch Analysis Unit.
Additional communications are handled through the Customs National Monitoring Centre in Melbourne that deals with communications for Customs as a whole.

(2) ANAO Report No 38 of 1999-2000 referred to difficulties at the time in communicating between Coastwatch's marine and air assets. Satellite communication equipment was subsequently fitted to all fixed wing aircraft and the new Coastwatch helicopter facilitating communications with surface assets. Coastwatch aircraft are able to communicate directly with ACVs and Fremantle Class Patrol Boats by UHF, HF and VHF radio; and satellite phone.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) What was the expenditure by the Department of Defence on Coastwatch activities during the financial year ending 30 June 2003.
(2) What services were involved and covered by the operating costs, including the cost of Fremantle class patrol boats and P3-C Orion aircraft.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Defence commitment to Coastwatch is detailed in the Customs Service Annual Report 2002-03. The support provided is drawn from Defence's allocated resources, and represents no net additional cost to the Defence Budget.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Has the Minister's department raised the issue of using Defence vessels to tow impounded vessels with Coastwatch; if so, (a) what was the nature of those representations, and (b) what was the outcome.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Vessels are only impounded after legal processes are conducted ashore, resulting in a penalty of impounding a vessel. Defence, therefore, does not tow impounded vessels, except on rare occasions where impounded vessels are being moved in a harbour and naval assistance is required.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

question.para: (1) Which agencies within his portfolio have entered into a memorandum of understanding with Coastwatch and on what dates were those memoranda finalised.
(2) What is the nature of those memoranda.
(3) Are they publicly available; if not, will he provide a copy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Federal Police (AFP) has a service level agreement with Coastwatch. The SLA was signed on 29 January 2001. It was reviewed on its expiry in 2003, and was re-signed on 20 April 2004.

(2) The Service Agreement provides the AFP and Coastwatch with a clear understanding of their respective roles in relation to the provision of civil maritime surveillance and response services by Coastwatch to the AFP.
(3) Not available for operational reasons.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 February 2004:

quote.para: Did any agencies within the Minister's portfolio, during the course of calendar year 2003, have cause to correspond with a representative of Coastwatch about the tasking of aircraft or marine vessels for services provided by Coastwatch; if so, what was the nature of that correspondence.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Federal Police and the Border Enforcement area of the Australian Customs Service correspond regularly with Coastwatch about the tasking of aircraft and marine vessels that are allocated to the civil surveillance program. This is to ensure that surveillance and response needs are clearly and regularly expressed to Coastwatch so that they can be incorporated into Coastwatch's long-term planning processes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 March 2004:

question.para: (1) How much did the Minister's department spend during 2002-2003 on outsourced (a) barristers and (b) solicitors (including private firms, the Australian Government Solicitor, and any others).
(2) How much did the Minister's department spend on internal legal services.
(3) What is the Minister's department's projected expenditure on legal services for the 2003-2004 financial year.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs spent a total of approximately $7.9M for the purchase of external legal services (which includes disbursements) in the 2002-2003 financial year. It is not possible to separately distinguish between the legal costs spent on barristers and solicitors for a number of reasons including that:

(a) these costs often appear on the one invoice with the consequence that every individual invoice would need to be examined to accurately specify the amount that was paid directly to a barrister as separate from the other costs and disbursements included on that invoice; and
(b) AGS officers and other legal service providers can appear in a matter as both a barrister and a solicitor due to the fused nature of the legal profession in many jurisdictions.

(2) The Legal Services Group is the primary area in the Department for providing internal legal services on a wide range of matters (excluding MCRS matters which are dealt with by the Comcare external legal panel). The total budget for 2002-2003 for the Legal Services Group was approximately $2.2M (this is made up of salary and administrative costs but excludes desktop and voice costs and the costs of the SES Band 1 Manager). There are also other areas in the Department who undertake some work of a legal nature and may be capable of falling within the phrase âinternal legal servicesâ. For example, the Department of Veterans' Affairs uses APS employees who are not legally qualified or admitted to practice to undertake a range of tasks which could be described as involving work of a legal nature. Examples of this include:
(a) the development of legislation proposals; and
(b) appearances before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as advocates who represent the Repatriation Commission;

(c) in relation to the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Service (MRCS) undertaking the management of cases, the reconsideration of primary decisions and the supervision of the external legal panel; and
(d) the management and development of contracts.

For each of the above tasks, there are also APS employees who are legally qualified and admitted to practice who perform similar duties. It is not possible to fully identify and allocate costs to the individual components of legal work that are undertaken by these other areas of the Department.

(3) The expenditure for the 2003-2004 financial year in the Department of Veterans' Affairs is approximately $7.6M (which includes $2.3M for the Department and $5.3M for the MRCS) for the costs and disbursements of external legal providers and internal costs of approximately $2.0M for the total budget of the Legal Services Group (this is made up of salary and administrative costs of all APS employees but excludes desktop and voice costs and the costs of the SES Band 1 Manager).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 March 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of Defence Tender DSC 086, (a) when was it advertised, (b) how many responses were received, (c) what was the range of bids, (d) what was value of the winning bid, (e) who was selected as the preferred tenderer, and (f) when and on what basis was the preferred tenderer selected.

(2) In respect of the finding by his department's Management Audit Branch (MAB) that the process of awarding the tender was `flawed', (a) did the MAB conduct a review of the delegate's decision to award the contract to a company by the name of ATMA; if so, what was the outcome of this review, (b) did the MAB find that the delegate followed Defence purchasing policy in awarding the contract to ATMA; if not, (i) why not, and (ii) what was the finding of the MAB in this matter, (c) did the Inspector-General make a recommendation to halt the process and conduct a new tender process; if so, what was the reason given for this finding, (d) was a legal opinion sought in relation to the Inspector-General's recommendation; if so, what was the reason for seeking legal opinion and can the Minister provide a copy, and (e) why was the Inspector-General's recommendation not followed.

(3) What factors were taken into account when deciding to award the tender to ATMA and can the Minister confirm that ATMA was selected as the preferred tender as a result of the consideration of aspects explicitly excluded from the scope of Tender DSC 086.

(4) Did Defence try to withdraw preferred tenderer status from ATMA after it had been selected as the preferred tenderer; if so, (a) when, (b) was it successful, and (c) did ATMA sue or threaten to sue Defence.
(5) In respect of the re-evaluation of the tenders, (a) when did this occur, (b) what factors were taken into account, and (c) was ATMA's threat to sue Defence taken into consideration.

(6) Can the Minister confirm the existence of a letter dated 9 July 2002 in which his department states it was âassessing the liability cost and would choose the least cost pathâ; if so, does this refer to ATMA's threat to sue Defence.

(7) Were tenders re-evaluated strictly in accordance with the scope of work stated in the tender documentation which stated that the âcost of services disconnection and reinstatement of site to be done by othersâ; if so, what was the outcome of that evaluation.

(8) Is it the case that in selecting a preferred tender, consideration was made for a scope of work broader than that stated in the Tender DCS 086; if so, were all tenderers given an opportunity to tender for that broader scope of work; if not, why not.

(9) Did the Minister's department obtain legal advice that it could consider a broader scope of work because the tender contained âno express terms as to how the offers were to be evaluated other than an obligation to do so in the best interests of the departmentâ and can the Minister explain why his department did not follow the policy contained in the Defence Procurement Policy Manual which states that âas a general rule, only information requested in the request documentation can be used to evaluate tendersâ.
(10) Can the Minister confirm that the Alternative Offer tendered by ATMA and accepted by Defence was cost neutral or a zero sum offer for the two separate Requests for Tender.
(11) Were the two separate Requests of Tenders re-evaluated without consideration of the alternative offer but the result did not meet the Project Brief requirement of the works being cost neutral.
(12) Is it the case that the tender documentation did not refer to the Project Brief requirement that the works be cost neutral.

(13) Can the Minister explain why his department considered the Project Brief requirement for cost neutrality when this was not mentioned in the tender documentation and is it Defence policy that only information requested in the request documentation can be used to evaluate tenders.

(14) Is the Minister aware that (a) my office made specific request to the Corporate Services and Infrastructure Group (CSIG) about DSC 086 on 3 July 2003, (b) CSIG failed to inform my office, (c) the Parliamentary Secretary informed my office on 22 July 2003 while the contract was signed on 7 July 2003.

(15) Can the Minister explain (a) why CSIG did not inform me about the state of the contract, (b) who made the decision not to inform me, (c) what avenues are open to my constituent to seek redress, and (d) whether this was a factor in the decision to delay informing my office about the state of the contract.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Tuesday 7 August 2001.
(b) Seven.
(c) and (d) This information is Commercial in Confidence and cannot be released.
(e) ATMA.
(f) 2 October 2001. Best value for money.

(2) (a) Yes. The outcome of the review was that âMAB considers the most appropriate way forward is to halt, and later, restart the activity to provide all tenderers the opportunity to re-tender and ensure that the process is managed appropriatelyâ.
(b) No.
(i) MAB found that âthe Commonwealth breached its own advertised process and RFT conditions for the conduct of the evaluationâ.
(ii) MAB found that âa number of fundamental procurement requirements were breached in the Tender DSC-086 evaluation ... (and) ... MAB considers that the Defence process used was flawedâ.

(c) Yes. There appeared to be a strong basis that a particular tenderer was not treated fairly on its merits since â... a new evaluation criterion was introduced after tender closure. This was in contradiction of the advertised process. The Tender Evaluation Board also appears to have been unreasonably influenced in reaching the value for money judgement by the convenience of one contractor providing the whole requirementâ.
(d) Yes. MAB's first recommendation was to seek legal advice on the Department's options. A copy cannot be provided because legal advice received by the Department is in confidence.
(e) Legal advice differed from the findings of the Inspector-General's Report in that it found that there had been no unfairness to any of the tenderers.
(3) Value for money. No, it was not the cast that ATMA was selected as preferred tenderer because of aspects outside the scope of the tender.
(5) (a) 5 December 2001.
(b) Highest price per house, provision of an Australian Business Number and a Building Registration/Licence Number, and overall value for money.
(c) As at 5 December 2001, there had been no threats to sue Defence by ATMA.
(6) No. As at July 2002, there had been no threats to sue Defence by ATMA.
(7) Yes. The preferred tenderer offered best value for money based on the scope of Tender DCS 086.
(8) No. The evaluation criteria for DCS 086 were used in determining the preferred tenderer.
(9) Yes. The Defence Procurement Policy Manual was followed. Tender evaluation was based on the scope of works for Tender DCS 086.
(10) The alternative offer tendered by ATMA for DCS 086 offered a cost neutral solution that also included additional works.
(11) Cost neutrality was not an evaluation criteria for DCS 086.

(13) The Project Brief covered two projects and two Requests for Tender were issued. Cost neutrality was not an evaluation criterion for either individual project. Therefore, the tenders were not evaluated on cost neutrality. Defence policy is that tenders can only be evaluated on what is in the Request for Tender documentation.

(14) (a) The specific request made to Corporate Services Infrastructure Group - Infrastructure Division on the afternoon of Thursday 3 July 2003 was to `call Mr Danby's office and let them know where DSC 086 is up to'. As this was not the appropriate office to answer the enquiry, the query was faxed to CSIG - National Operations Division on Friday 4 July 2003. On Monday 7 July 2003, the Director of Estate Operations, the appropriate area to answer the query, requested information from the Office of Parliamentary Secretary on the protocol for answering a telephone query from a member of Parliament, and was advised to provide a response through the Office of the Parliamentary Secretary.

(b) CSIG followed accepted protocol and answered the query through the Parliamentary Secretary. On 7 July 2003, your office was informed of the manner of the reply. At no time was Defence or the Parliamentary Secretary informed of the full nature of the query or on whose behalf the query was made. Defence was not yet aware that the contracts had been signed on that day as an outsourced comprehensive maintenance contractor manages the project.
(c) CSIG followed accepted ministerial procedures.

(15) (a) Your office did not enquire about the state of the actual contract, but rather the status of the project. CSIG did inform you through the Office of the Parliamentary Secretary about the state of the project, which included when the contract was signed. This reply followed accepted ministerial protocol.
(b) No decision was made not to inform you.

(c) Your constituent has no redress in this matter. According to the Commonwealth Ombudsman and independent legal advice, your constituent was treated fairly and did not offer the best value to the Commonwealth.

(d) Your office did not specifically inquire about the contracts. There was no decision to delay informing your office about the state of the contract. The contracts that were signed by ATMA on 7 July 2003 had taken weeks to negotiate because the project had been stalled since December 2001. The contracts could not have been produced over the weekend after your call to CSIG on 3 July 2003. The delay in informing your office was because the area responsible was following acceptable ministerial protocol.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Can he confirm that over 1.3 million television viewers in Sydney access Community Television Sydney (CTS) Channel 31 every month; if not, why not.

(2) Is he aware that CTS Channel 31 broadcasts a variety of news programs featuring community issues and local stories not normally broadcast by the existing commercial or government networks; if not why not.

(3) Can he confirm that the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) has been investigating the granting of a permanent licence to CTS Channel 31 for over two years; if so can he say when the ABA will complete its investigation; if not , why not.
(4) Is he aware that the CTS Channel 31 has had a broadcasting licence for eleven years but that its licence will expire on 19 March 2004; if not, why not.
(5) Is he aware of the consternation being experienced by CTS staff, program providers, volunteer networks and other stakeholders by the ABA's delay in resolving this matter; if not, why not.
(6) Will he expedite the granting of permanent licence for CTS Channel 31 before 19 March 2004; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that there was a considerable number of viewers watching Community Television Sydney Channel 31 each month. However, I have not had access to the ratings information that would enable me to confirm exact numbers.

(2) Yes, I am aware that community television stations broadcast a variety of programs not normally found on commercial or national networks - that is why the Government supports the sector through the provision of access to spectrum at minimal cost.

(3) The Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) called for submissions for permanent licences in February 2003, and announced the allocation of licences in the Sydney and Perth markets on 18 March 2004. Television Sydney Ltd in Sydney, and Access 31 in Perth were allocated the permanent licences.

(4) Community Television Sydney Ltd was the triallist broadcasting on Channel 31 in Sydney, and I am advised that they began broadcasting in April 1994 and that the terms of their triallist licence required them to cease broadcasting on 19 March 2004. Community Television Sydney Ltd then obtained three separate Federal Court orders which enabled them to continue broadcasting until midnight on 23 April 2004. However, there is no guarantee that the triallist will be the best applicant for the long term licence - that is why the Broadcasting Services Act1992 requires the ABA to advertise for applicants for community television licences.
(5) Yes. I received a number of representations on their behalf.
(6) The ABA's decision to allocate the Sydney licence to Television Sydney Ltd was announced on 18 March 2004 and has since been upheld by the Federal Court

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

quote.para: For each month since 1 June 1996, what proportion of Coastwatch's activity has been directed towards suspect illegal entry vessels and what was the cost of that activity.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Coastwatch is not able to attribute its operational activity or its costs to individual threats. Coastwatch services are planned and delivered to best address the Government's collective needs and priorities, rather than as a discrete response to each operational threat.

In accordance with this concept, each Coastwatch mission is multi-tasked; that is, aircrews are briefed to identify, investigate and report on possible targets for all clients who have administrative interest in the surveillance area.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

quote.para: Has Coastwatch undertaken any program performance monitoring in respect of the detection of suspect illegal entry vessels since 1 June 1996; if so, what has that monitoring revealed; if not, which other agencies, if any, conducted that monitoring on behalf of Coastwatch.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Customs analyses operational data in relation to each detection of a Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessel to determine potential gaps in its coverage and the likelihood of further incidents happening in the future.
For security reasons, the products of these analyses are not available publicly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

quote.para: Has the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs established a time frame for receiving notice from Coastwatch of the arrival in port of suspect illegal entry vessels; if so, (a) what is it, (b) on how many occasions has the time frame been met, and (c) on how many occasions has the time frame not been met.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Coastwatch Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) is that the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs is notified immediately a Suspect Illegal Entry Vessels (SIEV) is detected. This SOP has been adhered to in each instance of a SIEV detection.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

quote.para: Has Coastwatch undertaken any post-task evaluations in respect of its operations since 1 June 1996; if so, (a) how many have been undertaken, and (b) what have they revealed.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Customs undertakes post-operation analysis in respect of each of its major operations. These evaluations are classified and are not publicly available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Who makes the decision on whether a boat detected by Coastwatch is to be regarded as a suspect illegal entry vessel (SIEV) and which departments and agencies are represented by that person or those persons.
(2) In respect of SIEVs sailing in the Timor Sea, (a) which agency or agencies is responsible for the initial response, and (b) what is the usual initial response.
(3) At what point is a decision made to engage a response vessel and which agency or agencies give directions to that response vessel.
(4) What are the protocols, general orders and or other directions that apply to the conduct of response vessels and those on board response vessels in respect of SIEVs.

(5) What arrangements have applied since 1995 for response teams to intercept and board suspect illegal entry vessels, in particular, (a) at what point is a decision to intercept and board such vessels made, (b) who makes that decision, (c) what is the usual composition of a boarding team, and (d) which departments and agencies are usually represented by members of a boarding team.
(6) What are the initial steps and processes taken by members of a boarding team when a SIEV is intercepted and boarded.
(7) Do any of the arrangements vary according to the location of a SIEV when the decision is made to intercept and board it; if so, how.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The aircrew that sight a target vessel make an initial assessment on whether that vessel is to be regarded as a SIEV. Within the Department of Defence (Defence) Operation RELEX II Area of Operations (AO), Defence would take the decision that further investigation of the vessel is warranted; outside the Defence AO, the Australian Customs Service (Customs) is the decision-making authority.

(2) The Timor Sea is in the Operation RELEX II AO. Defence is therefore responsible for coordinating Defence and Customs surveillance aircraft and surface vessels to detect and respond to a SIEV incursion.

(3) Defence determines when and whether a surface response vessel is to intercept a SIEV within the OP RELEX AO. Outside the OP RELEX II AO, Customs, in conjunction with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA), directs surface response actions.
(4), (5) and (6) The protocols and guidelines that apply to the conduct of response vessels are laid down in standard operating procedures, prepared by Defence in conjunction with DIMIA and Customs.
(7) SIEV response actions are determined on a case by case basis by the relevant operational command agency.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What was the initial reaction of Coastwatch to the recommendation in the Auditor-General's report `The Management of Boat People, Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Australian Protective Services and Australian Custom Service - Coastwatch' dated 17 February 1998 that a memorandum of understanding should be developed between the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Coastwatch incorporating a performance agreement setting out targets, indicators and respective responsibilities.
(2) Has that recommendation been acted upon; if so, how.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) See my answer to Question on Notice No 3067.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

question.para: (1) Has Coastwatch entered into a memorandum of understanding with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs about surveillance services provided by Coastwatch to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs; if so, (a) when, (b) what are its terms, and (c) does the memorandum include a performance agreement.

(2) Has an analysis been undertaken of Coastwatch operational data to determine the probability that suspect illegal entry vessels have arrived undetected carrying (a) illegal immigrants, (b) narcotics, (c) guns, and (d) other contraband; if so, (i) when, (ii) over what period was data provided, and (iii) what were the conclusions of any such analysis.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) See my answer to Question on Notice No 3067.

(2) Customs undertakes analyses of Coastwatch data in relation to Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessels (SIEVs) to determine potential gaps in its operational coverage and the likelihood of further incidents happening in the future. Customs does not undertake analysis specifically to arrive at a probability that a SIEV has landed undetected. It should be noted that there has been no credible evidence to support the notion that an undetected landing has occurred.
For security reasons, the products of these analyses are not available publicly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 March 2004:

quote.para: Has the Minister received advice on whether differing functional responsibilities between the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Coastwatch has inhibited the approach of the department or Coastwatch to the detection and apprehension of suspect illegal entry vessels; if so, (a) what was the advice, (b) when was it received, and (c) what action has been taken in response.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 25 March 2004:

question.para: (1) For each of the last three years, what was the Commonwealth's direct financial contribution toward the management of each of Australia's (a) World Heritage sites, (b) Biosphere Reserve sites, and (c) Wetlands of International Importance (excluding those sites that are World Heritage properties or Biosphere Reserves).

(2) What formal arrangements does the Commonwealth have in place with the respective State and Territory Governments regarding the management of these internationally recognised sites in order to ensure that Australia's obligations are being met.

(3) Are the (a) funding levels, and (b) management arrangements between the Commonwealth and State or Territory Governments for the three categories of internationally recognised sites the same; if not, will the Minister explain (i) how and why they differ, and (ii) whether he is confident that the existing funding and management arrangements are adequate to ensure Australia is meeting its international obligations in respect of management of these sites.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In providing the answer to the Honourable Member's question, I note that he refers to over 80 sites, the majority of which are not the management responsibility of the Australian Government. Funding for these sites also comes from a number of sources. As such, the level of detail requested is not readily available. I therefore provide the Honourable Member with the following figures.
The Commonwealth's direct financial contribution for each of the years 2001-2002, 2002-2003 and 2003-2004 (estimated) are respectively:

(a) (i) $13,540,806, $7,110,000 and $7,199,934 for State-managed World Heritage properties where these figures represent direct Commonwealth funding at the National level. I note that additional funding has also been made available to World Heritage areas from the State and Regional streams of the Natural Heritage Trust during 2002-03 and 2003-04,

(a) (ii) $62,517,277, $59,974,102, and $58,734,000 where these figures are the total management budgets for each of the four World Heritage properties managed by Commonwealth agencies (Kakadu National Park, Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park, the Great Barrier Reef, Heard and McDonald Islands).

I note that for Heard and McDonald Islands the figures do not include the costs of expeditions to the area, which are planned to take place at approximately three-yearly intervals.
