I also note that the Commonwealth agencies, with the exception of the Australian Antarctic Division, do not differentiate the funding of World Heritage from other management tasks and so the figures for Kakadu National Park, Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park and the Great Barrier Reef are the entire site management budgets of the properties rather than figures for World Heritage management only.
(c) $1,364,115, $1,072,574 and $224,672, where these figures encompass projects delivering both direct and indirect benefits to Ramsar sites.
(2) The World Heritage Convention

States Parties to the World Heritage Convention (the Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage) recognise that the sites located in their territory constitute a world heritage area `for whose protection it is the duty of the international community as a whole to cooperate' (Article 6, World Heritage Convention). Apart from the four Commonwealth properties, the States are the day-to-day land managers for Australia's World Heritage sites. Formal arrangements developed by the Australian Government and the States to implement Australia's management responsibilities under the Convention' include: Ministerial Councils; Scientific, Community and Indigenous Advisory Committees; Commonwealth/States officials Committees and the development of management plans and other management arrangements.
Biosphere Reserves

Biosphere Reserves are a voluntary and cooperative arrangement and are not covered by an international convention. They are an international designation made by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) on the basis of nominations submitted by countries participating in the Man and the Biosphere Program. The Department of the Environment and Heritage is the focal point for Biosphere Reserves in Australia (a facilitating role only) but does not have a statutory role in, for example, setting management standards or auditing compliance with the UNESCO Man and the Biosphere Seville Strategy and Statutory Framework of the World Network. Apart from Commonwealth properties and reserves, the States are the day-to-day land managers for Biosphere Reserves.'
The Ramsar Convention
'The Convention on Wetlands (more commonly known as the Ramsar Convention) is an intergovernmental treaty for the conservation and `wise use' of wetlands.

The Australian Government works cooperatively with the State and Territory governments (and other site managers) for the protection of Australia's Ramsar sites. A national committee, the Wetlands and Waterbirds Taskforce, operates under the Natural Resource Management Ministerial Council to coordinate the implementation of Australia's obligations under the Convention on Wetlands. Apart from Commonwealth properties and a small number of sites privately owned or managed by corporations, the States and Territories are responsible for the day-to-day management of many the majority of Australia's Ramsar sites.
The Australian Government's Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act1999 also has relevant sections relating to World Heritage properties, Ramsar sites and Biosphere Reserves.

(3) (a), (b), (i). The funding levels and management arrangements between the State or Territory Governments and the Australian Government are not the same because of differences in the international agreements.

(ii). The funding and management arrangements for the programs have been developed by the Australian Government to meet its international obligations. The Government considers that these are adequate to meet these international obligations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 31 March 2004:

question.para: (1) What sum was spent on the Government's citizenship promotion campaign in (a) 2001-2002, and (b) 2002-2003 and (c) what is the estimated expenditure in 2003-2004.

(2) Of the total expenditure in each (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004 to date, what sum was spent on (i) paid media advertising, (ii) promotional kits, and (iii) market research and other developmental costs.

(3) Can he confirm that a `further burst' to the campaign was planned for 2004; if so, (a) when is this scheduled to occur, (b) what is the proposed duration of the campaign, (c) what sum has been allocated for this purpose, and (d) is it proposed to continue to use the existing campaign materials.
(4) Why did the Portfolio Budget statement and Additional Estimates statement for 2003-2004 both fail to make any reference to a new citizenship promotional campaign.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) $5.1m (b) $2.4m (c) As at 31 March 2004 the estimated expenditure on the 2003-04 campaign was $1.9m.
(3) A campaign is being planned for 2004-05, funding for which was provided in the 2002-03 Portfolio Budget Statement (PBS).

(a) Advertising will commence before the end of 2003-04. Research conducted as part of the evaluation of the Citizenship Day 2003 campaign indicates that promotion of citizenship should continue throughout the year to maintain momentum as frequent exposure of the target groups to the campaign is more likely to achieve the desired result than concentrated promotion two or three times a year.

(b) The campaign will be formally launched approximately a month prior to Australian Citizenship Day (17 September), and will also have as a focus Australia Day 2005 and Harmony Day 2005. Other promotional opportunities will be considered as they arise.

(c) The 2002-2003 PBS (p84) included a Budget Measure of $1m per annum from 2002-03 to 2005-06, to encourage eligible permanent residents to take out citizenship and participate fully in Australian society, and to promote Australian Citizenship. The $1m budget will be supplemented by funds remaining from the 2001-02 allocation for implementation of the Government Response to the report by the Australian Citizenship Council (ACC). One of the recommendations of the ACC report highlighted the need for the promotion of Australian citizenship within the Australian community.
(d) Yes.
(4) The Portfolio Budget statement and the Additional Estimates statement for

2003-04 both failed to make any reference to a new citizenship promotional campaign because no new funding was allocated for citizenship promotion in 2003-04. Promotional activity in 2004-05 is a continuation of the activity which commenced in 2001-02, following the recommendation of the ACC, and for which additional funding of $1m per annum in each of four years was announced in the 2002-03 Budget.

Mr Anderson

answer.para: (1) and (2) The records kept for aircraft operations at Sydney Airport do not differentiate between commercial and non-commercial flights. Information on the numbers of landings and take-offs at the Airport between 11 pm and 6 am in 2003 can be found on the Airservices Australia website at:
http://www.airservicesaustralia.com/mediainfo/facts&stats/sydney/2003/2003.htm
(3) Records of such information are kept by Airport Coordination Australia. I would suggest the honourable member contact this body direct for an answer to his question.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 April 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the decision by the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to award the permanent Community Television Licence for Channel 31 to TV Sydney, can he confirm that a submission containing more than 200 letters of support for the current licence-holder for Channel 31 Community Television Sydney (CTS) was hand-delivered on 31 March to Mr Gary Dawson, Senior Policy Adviser (Communications) to the Prime Minister.

(2) Can he confirm that the letter included (a) a message from the Hon. Bob Carr, Premier of New South Wales, dated 29 April 2003, stating that he was confident that the people of New South Wales would benefit from a permanent community television licence operated by CTS, (b) a message from Mr John Brogden MLA, New South Wales Leader of the Opposition, dated 10 March 2004, calling on the ABA to consider the current and long term concerns of CTS and stating that CTS has demonstrated a record commitment to news, local issues and community stories, (c) a letter addressed to Professor David Flint, Chairman of the ABA, dated 31 March 2004, from the member for Wentworth Mr Peter King expressing his concern about the future of CTS and calling on the ABA to reconsider this important matter, (d) a letter from the Hon. Ross Cameron MP, Member for Parramatta, dated 10 March 2004, stating that for over ten years CTS has been providing quality and innovative television meeting the needs of his local community, (e) a letter from Mr Laurie Ferguson, MP, Member for Reid and Shadow Minister for Population, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs advising that he has received comments from his constituents about the admirable coverage by CTS of community events and requesting that application by CTS be sympathetically considered, (f) a reference from the Hon. Dr Meredith Burgmann, MLC, President of the NSW Legislative Council, saying that the CTS programs are a source of entertainment and education for each community and very often the only regular coverage of important events within these different communities, (g) a letter from the Member for Fairfield, Mr Joe Tripodi MLA, confirming that CTS provides an invaluable link for many residents within his electorate and the wider community and asking the ABA to consider its application favourably, (h) a letter of support from the Member for Bligh, Clover Moore MLA, dated 12 March 2004, stating that constituents within her electorate are concerned that âtheirâ community television has an uncertain future, (i) a letter of support from the then Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, the Hon. Phillip Ruddock MP, dated 1 May 2003, stating that he is aware of the contribution made by CTS to the viewing public through its various multicultural broadcasts, and (j) letters of support from the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council of Australia, the Ethnic Communities Council of NSW, the Chairman of the Community relations Commission for a Multicultural NSW, Mr Stephan Kerkyasharian, and several other community organisations and individuals in support of the application lodged by CTS for the permanent licence.

(3) Can he confirm that according to section 84(2) of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 the ABA, when deciding whether to allocate a community broadcasting licence to an applicant, is to have regard to (a) the extent to which the proposed service would meet the existing and future needs of the community within the licence area of the proposed licence, (b) the nature and diversity of the interests of that community, and (c) the capacity of the applicant to provide the proposed service; if, not why not.

(4) Can he confirm that the programming schedule proposed by the awarded licensee, TV Sydney, will reduce the amount of ethnic community broadcasting to 3.5 hours per week, down from the current 18 hours per week; if not, why not.
(5) Can he confirm that the awarded licensee, TV Sydney, will not be able to broadcast until 2005 at the earliest; if not, why not.

(6) Will he ensure that the community television broadcasting sector will continue to serve the 1.3 million monthly viewers in Sydney until such time as TV Sydney is able to broadcast; if so how; if not, why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am advised that the submission in support of Community Television Sydney Ltd's (CTS) Channel 31 was provided to Mr Gary Dawson, Senior Policy Adviser to the Prime Minister on 31 March 2004.
(2) (a) - (j) I am advised that letters of support were received from the nominated people and organisations.

(3) Section 84 of the Act provides that in deciding whether to allocate a community television broadcasting licence to an applicant, the ABA is to have regard to the following six criteria: (a) the extent to which the proposed service would meet the existing and perceived future needs of the community within the licence area of the proposed licence; (b) the nature and diversity of the interests of that community; (c) the nature and diversity of other broadcasting services (including national broadcasting services) available within that licence area; (d) the capacity of the applicant to provide the proposed service; (e) the undesirability of one person being in a position to exercise control of more than one community broadcasting licence that is a broadcasting services bands licence in the same licence area; and (f) the undesirability of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory or a political party being in a position to exercise control of a community broadcasting licence.
(4) The ABA has advised that the program schedule provided by Television Sydney Ltd (TVS) to the ABA indicates that it proposes to broadcast 11.5 hours per week of ethnic programs.

(5) Under clause 9(1)(h) of Part 5 of Schedule 2 to the Act, TVS is required to commence broadcasting within one year of being allocated the licence or within such longer period as it is notified in writing by the ABA. I am advised that TVS has notified the ABA that it proposes to commence broadcasting in early 2005.

(6) Once a licence has been allocated there is no provision under the Act for the ABA to make spectrum available for other purposes. Following its unsuccessful Federal Court challenge to the ABA's decision to allocate the licence to TVS, CTS' Channel 31 ceased transmission on 23 April 2004. Although the Act allows a new licensee a year in which to make the necessary arrangements to commence broadcasting, I understand that TVS has advised the ABA that it expects to commence broadcasting in early 2005. I am advised that the ABA has asked TVS to report regularly on its progress in the meantime.

subdebateinfo.title: Finance and Administration: Domestic and Overseas Air Travel
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3459)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 1 April 2004:

question.para: (1) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what sum was spent by the Minister's department on domestic and overseas air travel.

(2) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what proportion of domestic air travel by employees of the Minister's department was provided by (i) Ansett, (ii) Qantas, (iii) Regional Express, and (iv) Virgin Blue.

(3) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what was the actual expenditure by the Minister's department on domestic air travel provided by (i) Ansett, (ii) Qantas, (iii) Regional Express, and (iv) Virgin Blue.
(4) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what sum was spent by the Minister's department on business class travel on (i) domestic routes, and (ii) overseas routes.
(5) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what sum was spent by the Minister's department on economy class travel on (i) domestic routes, and (ii) overseas routes.

(6) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, what proportion of the expenditure on air travel by the Minister's department was on the domestic routes (i) Sydney to Canberra, (ii) Melbourne to Canberra, (iii) Sydney to Melbourne, (iv) Sydney to Brisbane, (v) Melbourne to Hobart or Launceston, and (vi) Sydney to Perth.

(7) For the financial year (a) 2000/2001, and (b) 2002/2003, how many employees of the Minister's department had membership of the (i) Qantas Chairman's Lounge, (ii) Qantas Club, (iii) Regional Express Membership Lounge, and (vi) Virgin Blue's Blue Room paid for by the department.
(8) Which company provides travel management services to the Minister's department.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (i) Ansett: 98.3%
(ii) Qantas: 1.7%
(iii) Regional Express - N/A Regional Express was not established until 2002.
(iv) Virgin Blue: None
(i) Ansett: N/A - Ansett collapsed in September 2001
(ii) Qantas: 99.6%
(iii) Regional Express: 0.14%
(iv) Virgin Blue: 0.26%
(iii) Regional Express - N/A Regional Express was not established until 2002.
(iv) Virgin Blue: None
(i) Ansett: N/A - Ansett collapsed in September 2001
(iii) Regional Express: $711.70
(iv) Virgin Blue: $1,321.73

(4) Preparation of a detailed answer for the 2000/2001 year is not possible because of incomplete records and the collapse of Ansett. To compile the information for the 2002/2003 year would involve a manual search of the details for each flight to determine the class of travel. This would be resource and time intensive and involve a disproportionate diversion of resources.
(5) Please refer to the answer to Question 4.

(6) Preparation of a detailed answer is not possible because of incomplete records, changed financial management information systems and reporting mechanisms and the collapse of Ansett. To compile this information would be a manual exercise requiring a review of the details of each flight for the periods. As over 2,000 trips were taken during these periods, it is considered that this would involve a disproportionate diversion of resources.
(i) Qantas Chairmans Lounge: 1
(ii) Qantas Club: 30
(iii) Regional Express Membership Lounge N/A - The Rex Lounge opened in 2003
(vi) Virgin Blue's Blue Room N/A - The Blue Room opened in 2003
(i) Qantas Chairmans Lounge: 1
(ii) Qantas Club: 90
(iii) Regional Express Membership Lounge 0

(vi) Virgin Blue's Blue Room: There are no memberships for the room which can be used on a pay-per-visit basis. To compile numbers of officials who use the room on this basis would require a manual search of all travel expenses since the opening of the Blue Room in 2003.
(8) Qantas Business Travel.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

quote.para: In respect of the claim in the article titled `The man who acts as Islam's Ruddock' on the front page of the Weekend Australian on 26 July 2003 that Mr Fouad Al Ashwah is a marriage celebrant, can he confirm whether Mr Al Ashwah is registered as a marriage celebrant with his department.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Mr Fouad El Ashwah was authorised as a marriage celebrant on 30 June 1995. He remains registered as a marriage celebrant with my Department.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Can he explain how the statements made at Senate Estimates hearings on the Employment Innovation Fund by Mr Hade (i.e. âthe idea of access to Job Network services by newly retrenched workers has already been tested, and we are looking at other developments for thatâ) and Ms Taylor (i.e. âwe have not done any specific research on early intervention with retrenched workersâ) who are employed by his department, can be reconciled.

(2) Can he explain on what basis the applications by Pathways Employment Services and Westlakes Training for funding under the Employment Innovation Fund to assist retrenched workers from Pasminco's Cockle Creek Smelter were refused.

(3) In respect of Mr Hade's statement that âthere is some work being managed by the state manager in New South Wales in relation to matters concerning the Pasminco workers and their families generallyâ, can he outline the details of this work and how it will assist Pasminco workers and their families.

(4) In respect of Mr Hade's statement in relation to the application lodged by Westlakes Training, that âthe application which it made for Employment Innovation Fund funding was not approvedâ, were there further applications for funding lodged, possibly under different funding programs in the Minister's portfolio, by Westlakes Training in respect of the Pasminco workers; if so, were any applications for funding approved or in line for approval prior to the winding up of Westlakes Training.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The statements made by Mr Hade and Ms Taylor are both correct. The Department has not conducted any internal research on the impact of early assistance for retrenched workers. Rather, the Department draws on a body of existing research that relates to this issue.

(2) The proposals provided by Pathways Employment Services and Westlakes Training were assessed by the Department and were deemed unsuccessful. The proponents were each notified by letter of the reasons why each proposal was not successful. It is not appropriate to disclose the advice given to proponents.
(3) There are 18 Job Network sites, four Community Work Coordinators (CWC) and one Transition to Work (TtW) provider operating in the Lower Hunter region.

All Pasminco workers were eligible for assistance from the Job Network as soon as they were officially advised by their employer that they were to be made redundant. All Pasminco workers had immediate access to Job Search Support and Job Placement services subject to them providing the registering Job Network member or Centrelink with a written redundancy notice, issued by their employer.
As a part of this service Job Network members were required to:
explain Job Network and Job Placement services available to the job seeker
create and lodge a vocational profile for the job seeker into the JobSearch database and provide a copy of the resulting resume
explain how JobSearch automatically matches profiles to available vacancies and provides notification of matches
establish a job seeker password for access to auto-matches through their personal page on JobSearch.

identify the job seeker's additional method of notification about job matches where appropriate, such as arranging for messages to go to an email, SMS or telephone message bank service for the job seeker
provide advice about the best ways to look for and find work
explain the use of touch-screen kiosks
show the job seeker how to search for job vacancies through JobSearch
provide the job seeker with an initial list of job matches

To address the needs of older retrenchees and partners of workers to enter the workforce the TtW provider is operating a pilot which places an emphasis on promotional activity with a view to attracting clients to this voluntary programme. The provider is marketing externally including undertaking a mail-out to residences of retrenchees targeting spouses, establishing a monitoring system, developing a vocational profile and assisting in connecting participants to Job Network services where appropriate. An additional 40 TtW places have been allocated to accommodate this measure and 15 have already started with 12 in training courses.

A number of new Work for the Dole (WfD) projects have been developed by the four CWCs to provide further work experience opportunities for the unemployed and provide community benefit in the Westlakes area.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

quote.para: Is the Minister aware that Telstra will not pay a dividend to a shareholder who does not provide bank account details; if so, can the Minister explain how Telstra is able to withhold dividend payments to shareholders who do not provide bank account details.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice provided by Telstra, is as follows:

quote.para: In April 2003, Telstra announced that it was planning to phase out the payment of dividends by paper cheque in favour of the more secure and cost effective option of paying dividends directly into shareholders' bank accounts, with effect from the interim dividend payment in April 2004.

Telstra's Board and management are responsible for the recommendation and payment of the Telstra dividend. Telstra can determine the method of payment of dividends in accordance with its Constitution, Australian Stock Exchange Listing Rules and the Corporations Act 2001. Telstra has written to shareholders on several occasions since April 2003 to advise shareholders of the change in policy, and where a shareholder had not yet provided bank account details, to seek those details.

At the payment of the interim dividend in April 2004, Telstra advised that where a shareholder has not yet provided bank account details, Telstra sent a form requesting those details with the dividend statement. Once the shareholder fills in the form, the dividend will be paid immediately. If this form is not completed, payment will be made by cheque in mid-June 2004.

Telstra has also indicated that where payment by direct credit can be demonstrated to cause âundue hardshipâ to the shareholder, Telstra will grant an exemption to the policy and continue to issue a dividend cheque.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) How many requests for a redress of grievance have been made since 1 June 2003 by personnel in the (a) Royal Australian Army, (b) Royal Australian Air Force, and (c) Royal Australian Navy.

(2) In respect of each request, (a) how long after it was made was a case officer appointed, (b) how long after it was made was a determination made, and (c) how many grievances were decided in favour of the person lodging the grievance.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Requests for a redress of grievance made in the period 1 June 2003 to 30 April 2004 inclusive:

(2) Legislation requires that all requests for redress be referred, in the first instance, to a member's Commanding Officer. Members who are dissatisfied with the outcome of a redress application may refer their complaint for review by their Service Chief. In such instances, redresses are referred initially to the Complaint Resolution Agency.
(a) The time taken to appoint a case officer at unit level is not a reportable statistic held by Defence.

(b) The time taken from when an application for redress of grievance was lodged at unit level until a determination was made by a unit commanding officer averaged 3.1 months. The time taken from when an application for redress of grievance was allocated to a Complaint Resolution Agency case officer to when a determination was made by a Service Chief averaged 2.3 months.
(c) Grievances decided in favour of the person lodging the grievance are:
Army - 21;
Air Force - 20; and
Navy - 14.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Have any studies been undertaken into the incidence of cancers, particularly pancreatic cancers, suffered by Korean Veterans; if so, by whom and what were the results.
(2) Has the incidence of cancer been linked to exposure to DDT; if so, when.
(3) Is it the case that the veterans of 3RAR experienced the most exposure to DDT and also suffer a higher incidence of cancers.
(4) Has action been taken to alert Korean War veterans and their medical advisers to the possibility that they may have contracted cancer; if so, when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes the Cancer Incidence Study 2003 - Australian Veterans of the Korean War was conducted to compare the incidence of cancer experienced by the 17,381 Australian male Korean War veterans with the cancer patterns experienced by a similarly aged section of the Australian community for the period 1982-1999. These cancer patterns were examined for all Korean War veterans and for each of the Services - Navy, Army and Air Force.

The comparisons are only made for the cancers diagnosed in the period 1982-1999 because complete data on cancer incidence in Australia are only available from 1982. This means that cancers developed in the period between the Korean War and 1982 are not considered in the Korean War Veterans Cancer Incidence Study.

The work was commissioned by the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) and undertaken by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW). The Scientific Advisory Committee and the Korean Veterans' Consultative Committee supervised the Study. Both the DVA and AIHW Ethics Committees approved the work.

The Study could not identify the live or death status of 5% of Korean War veterans. Including them or excluding them from the population `at risk' meant that the risk of cancer might have been either understated or overstated respectively. Therefore, two `at risk' Scenarios were derived to manage this issue. Scenario 1 excludes veterans whose status was unknown from the `at risk' population and Scenario 2 includes this group in the `at risk' population. The Cancer Incidence report presents findings under both Scenarios.

The findings demonstrated that Korean War veterans experienced a significantly greater overall cancer risk than the Australian community with the incidence of all cancers being 23% higher in Scenario 1 and 13% higher in Scenario 2 than what would be the expected Australian community rate.
The cancer incidence among Australian Korean War veterans was analysed further by the type of Service (Navy, Army and Airforce).

The results showed that the total incidence of cancer among those who served in the Navy was 25% higher (Scenario 1) and 17% higher (Scenario 2). The higher rates of cancer, by specific types of particular concern, are:
Prostate cancer 30% in Scenario 1 and 20% in Scenario 2;
Head and neck cancer 93% in Scenario 1 and 81% in Scenario 2;
Lung Cancer 25% in Scenario1 and 17% in Scenario 2.
Army veterans experienced 25% (Scenario 1) and 13% (Scenario 2) higher overall cancer incidence. All the following cancers showed significantly higher incidence among Army veterans:
Lung cancer 59% in Scenario 1 and 44% in Scenario 2;
Head and neck cancer 93% in Scenario 1 and 74% in Scenario 2;
Cancer of the larynx (105% in Scenario 1 and 87% in Scenario 2;
Liver cancer 78% in Scenario 1 and 61% in Scenario 2.

Under both Scenarios, the incidence of cancer amongst veterans who served in the Air Force showed no difference in the incidence of total cancer, but showed statistically significant higher rates of melanoma with 68% under Scenario 1 and 64% under Scenario 2.

The findings showed that pancreatic cancer was the 15th most common cancer and represented 1.7% of cancer incidence in Korean War veterans. Under both Scenarios, the rate of pancreatic cancer did not differ significantly from what would have been expected.

(2) Yes the instance of pancreatic cancer has been linked to DDT exposure in a small number of overseas studies. Although the link is not established beyond all doubt, there was enough evidence to allow the Repatriation Medical Authority in 1997 to include exposure to DDT as a factor in its Statement of Principles relating to pancreatic cancer.

(3) It is not known which unit had the highest exposure to DDT. The Cancer Incidence Study 2003: Australian Veterans of the Korean War did not analyse cancer rates by unit nor did it measure actual levels of exposure to DDT.

(4) An article appeared in the December 2003 Vetaffairs circular making it clear that cancer rates amongst Korean War veterans are significantly higher than those experienced by the comparable Australian male population. The article also announced the Korean War Veterans' General Health Survey in response to the findings of the Cancer Incidence Study. A further article in the March 2004 Vetaffairs also urged Korean War veterans to take part in the Health Survey. That article referred to cancer, amongst certain other conditions as being a cause of higher mortality amongst Australia's Korean war veterans.
Ministerial media releases have been issued, resulting in stories being published in the wider media.
Articles discussing the findings of the Korean War Veterans' Cancer Incidence Study are planned for a variety of both popular and peer-reviewed journals.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2002-2003 Budget measure âE-security national agendaâ, what sum has been spent by the National Office for the Information Economy (NOIE) during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 on improving e-security.
(2) On what e-security initiatives has funding been spent by the NOIE.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) In the 2002-2003 Budget, $24.9 million was allocated over a four-year period for a cross portfolio measure designed to improve security awareness and management of the national information infrastructure. As indicated in the Budget papers, the former National Office for the Information Economy (NOIE) was to contribute $1 million over four years ($250,000/year) to the initiative by absorbing the cost from within its existing resources.

In the 2003-2004 financial year to the end of May 2004, NOIE spent $580,000 on e-security activities and initiatives. That figure includes salaries and other employment expenses. Initiatives undertaken by NOIE during 2002-2003 and 2003-2004 towards the âE-Security National Agendaâ include:
Launch of an information kit entitled âTrusting the Internetâ on 16 July 2002, for small business and consumers, providing e-security information and advice;

Facilitating the work of the E-Security Coordination Group (ESCG). NOIE (now DCITA) chairs this group, which is comprised of key law enforcement and security agencies. The Group's work program focuses on e-security awareness raising, R&D and skills development. A number of projects and streams of work have been completed including a security portal developed with the Internet Industry Association which targets small business security needs; an online incident reporting initiative for Commonwealth agencies developed jointly by NOIE and the Defence Signals Directorate; a culture of security workshop for government employees; and awareness raising seminars on critical infrastructure protection issues;
Development of an ebusiness guide for small business which addressed their security needs;

Initiating discussions with institutions and industry bodies on addressing the shortage of e-security skilled personnel and to assist the development of a certification scheme for e-security professionals;
Sponsorship of the annual information technology security conference run by the Australian Computer Emergency Response Team (AusCERT) and for the provision of the AusCERT National Alerts Service;

Establishing the IT Security Experts Advisory Group (EAG) in February 2004 to provide advice to the Critical Infrastructure Advisory Council (CIAC) and work constructively with sector groups which report to the CIAC. The Group is made up of vendors of IT security systems, consultants and academic specialists, and some industry association representatives who are leaders in the information technology/e-security field;

Engaging in international fora which contribute to the development of the OECD's âculture of securityâ guidelines. In addition, NOIE (now DCITA) plays an active role in the APEC Telecommunications and Information Working Group (APEC TEL), particularly with respect to e-security issues. NOIE (now DCITA) currently Chairs the APEC TEL E-Security Task Group (ESTG). It is also joint chair (with the Attorney-General's Department) of the annual âbilateralâ discussions with the US on e-security/critical infrastructure protection issues. The latest discussions were held in Canberra from 21 - 23 April 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 May 2004:

quote.para: In respect of the 2003-2004 Budget measure âA Safer AustraliaâNational Security Hotlineâ, what sum has been spent on the National Security Hotline during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The National Security Hotline (NSH) commenced operations on 27 December 2002. The Cabinet decision of 15 April 2003 provided reimbursement up to $5.2m to the Department for expenditure involved in establishing the NSH and its running costs in 2002-03. Of this, approximately $4.577m was spent.

(b) The Cabinet decision of 15 April 2003 also provided an allocation of $6m for 2003-04. $3.5m was allocated to the NSH for employee expenses and supplier costs and $1.5m was provided to the Department's Public Affairs Unit, to enable additional market research and development of the National Security Campaign. $0.6m of the remainder has been allocated to the Information and Knowledge Services Division for IT and other technical support and $0.4m is allocated to corporate support and overheads. Expenditure as at 11 June 2004 is approximately $3.7m.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: E-Security National Agenda
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3502)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004.

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2002-2003 Budget measure âE-security national agendaâ, what sum has been spent by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 on improving e-security.
(2) On what e-security initiatives has funding been spent by the AFP.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The e-security national agenda measure has been allocated to the Australian High Tech Crime Centre (AHTCC) and AFP Computer Forensics for the provision of e-security initiatives. Due to the capacity building nature of the initiative and the AFP flexible teams model it is not practicable to capture costs incurred by other areas of the AFP on improving e-security. In respect to the AHTCC and Computer Forensics the AFP expended $2.0M in 2002-2003 and $2.4M in 2003-2004 (period ending 30 April 2004).

(2) The e-security initiative has allowed for the Australian Federal Police (AFP) to host the Australian High Tech Crime Centre (AHTCC) and to develop specific skills including computer forensics and electronic evidence retrieval. The development of these skills and the establishment of the AHTCC have given the AFP the capacity to investigate crimes such as denial of service attacks, phishing, hacking, and the use of technology to facilitate investigation of other crimes such as drug smuggling, terrorism and fraud.
The AHTCC was established by the Commissioners of the AFP and all State and Territory Police Services to:
provide a national coordinated approach to combating serious, complex and multi-jurisdictional high tech crimes, especially those beyond the capability of single jurisdictions;
assist in improving the capacity of all jurisdictions to deal with high tech crime; and
support efforts to protect the National Information Infrastructure.

The e-security initiative has also assisted the AFP in intelligence sharing relating to the management of operational responses to threats against the National Information Infrastructure (NII). The AFP has also established two High Tech Crime investigation teams based in Sydney and Melbourne which are co-located with the local police services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2002-2003 Budget measures titled âExpansion of the Law Enforcement Cooperation Programâ (LECP), what sum was spent during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 expanding the LECP.
(2) How many additional officers were deployed through the LECP during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The AFP expended $4.0M in operating funds and made $0.4 in capital purchases in expanding the Overseas Liaison Network (LECP) during financial year 2002-2003. With the expansion phase complete these funds have been incorporated into the ongoing Overseas Liaison Network budget and are no longer separately tracked. As at 30 April 2004 the AFP had expended $25.1 on the provision of the Overseas Liaison Network for financial year 2003-2004.
(2) The expansion of the Overseas Liaison Network (LECP) provided for an additional international presence of 16 AFP Officers in financial years 2002-2003 and 2003-2004.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Rapid Response Capability
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3506)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2002-2003 Budget measures titled âAustralian Federal Police (AFP) rapid response capabilityâ, what sum was spent during (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004 on providing the AFP with enhanced access to telecommunications infrastructure in remote locations.
(2) What equipment and services remain to be delivered.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The AFP expended $0.5M in operating funds and $1.5 in capital purchases during financial year 2002-2003 as part of the rapid response capability initiative. For the period ending 30 April 2004 the AFP had made $1.1M in capital purchases but with the initiative now under way these funds have been incorporated into the ongoing Technical Operations budget and are no longer separately tracked. In the case of the rapid response capability, AFP Technical Operations is responsible for the management of operational telecommunications in remote locations and contribute to AFP Outcome 1. Over the period 1 July 2003 to 30 April 2004 the AFP expended $13.5M on the provision of Technical Operations Services in support of AFP Outcome 1.
(2) All equipment and services have been delivered.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Federal Police: Strike Team Capacity
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3507)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2002-2003 Budget measures titled âDouble the strike team capacity of the Australian Federal Policeâ (AFP), what sum was spent during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 on increasing the strike team capacity of the AFP.
(2) How many additional officers were deployed to strike teams during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The AFP expended $5.3M in operating funds and $0.3 in capital purchases in doubling the strike team capacity during 2002-2003. With the expansion complete these funds have been incorporated into the ongoing investigation budget and are no longer separately tracked. Overall AFP National Operations are responsible for the delivery of strike team operations in support of AFP Output 1.1. Over the period 1 July 2003 to 30 April 2004 the AFP expended $27.9M in operating funding on provision of National Operations which is a component of AFP Output 1.1.
(2) The additional strike team capacity provided for an additional 116 AFP Officers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

quote.para: In respect of each court proceeding that has been commenced under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002, (a) what was the name of each party, (b) in which court was the matter conducted, (c) what was the matter number, (d) on what date was the matter commenced, (e) what was the value of the proceeds recovered in the matter, (f) what was the cost of conducting the matter, and (g) was there a grant of legal aid in the matter; if so, (i) to whom, and (ii) what sum in legal aid was granted.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (a)-(f) Answers (a)-(f) are in the attached table that has been provided by the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. Explanatory footnotes accompany the table. For privacy reasons, not all the names have been provided in answer to 3516(a). Only the names of parties in cases that have resulted in a final confiscation order have been provided, although all cases can be identified by their court file number. Where a matter is still ongoing or where it has been finalised but no confiscation orders were made, the names of parties have been withheld. This is to protect the privacy of those who may eventually be found to have not been involved in any wrongdoing or where they have had no confiscation order made against them.
(g) (i) (ii) Legal aid commissions, other than Victoria, advise that as at 10 June 2004 there have been five grants of legal aid for court proceedings under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 in 2003-04.

It has been the practice of successive Commonwealth Attorneys-General not to comment on applications for financial assistance in particular matters. Consistent with this practice, information collected by the Commonwealth from legal aid commissions for statistics collection and performance information purposes does not include information on the identity of legal aid clients. The information from legal aid commissions in relation to grants of aid for proceeds of crime matters has been provided in accordance with this practice.
Commissions advise that there has been no expenditure to date for any of these matters. Responses from individual commissions are as follows.

entry.para: Grants of legal aid in 2003-04 for court proceedings under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002
The expected total costs for the two matters is approx $10,000.
Three (two of the three grants relate to the same case)
Victoria Legal Aid advises that at this stage it does not collect separate data on cases under the Act.

quote.para: PoC Act 2002 Review List of CARS files with details of Orders and total CDPP expenses as at 20.05.2004
Footnotes:
The table counts a case as a matter if a court has made a restraining order under the PoC Act 2002, or a confiscation order without prior restraint.
In some cases restraining orders, or confiscation orders, have been made against more than one person, or against more than one item of property.
Column 2: Matter name

For privacy reasons, this Column only records the names of completed cases where a final order was made under the PoC Act 2002. It does not record the names of cases still in progress or cases that were completed without a final orders being made against any person. However, all cases are identified by a court file number.

The Column records the name against which the case is recorded on the DPP Criminal Assets Recording System. It is usually, but not always, the name of the primary defendant or primary suspect. In many cases other people are also named in the court proceedings, especially when property is owned by more than one person. The DPP does not record the names of all parties to litigation on the Criminal Assets Recording System and that information is not readily available.

Cases are recorded in the DPP information system under five categories: Corporations, Drugs, Fraud, Laundering, and Other. âLaunderingâ includes offences against the Financial Transaction Reports Act. âOtherâ includes offences against foreign law.
Unless otherwise indicated, the court is a court of the State named in Column 1.
An asterisk in this Column indicates that conviction based orders were made at sentence by a criminal court without the DPP commencing separate confiscation proceedings.
This column records payments made into the Confiscated Assets Account by the Official Trustee. There is a time lag between confiscation orders being made and being enforced.

This Column shows DPP disbursements. The disbursements include payments on filing fees, counsel's fees, transcript, costs orders and damages. The Column does not include staffing costs and overheads. The DPP does not record those cost against individual cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

(2) In respect of the integration cost, (a) what sum has been met by (i) the AFP, (ii) the Attorney-General's Department, and (iii) other agencies, and (b) how was the cost funded by each agency.

answer.para: (1) The integration of the Australian Protective Service into the AFP has been achieved using existing governance frameworks and resources and as such has been impractical to separately record the cost of integration.
(2) Costs for the AFP and APS have been met within existing resources.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

quote.para: In respect of the 2003-2004 Budget measure âA Safer Australia - continued funding for enhanced protective securityâ, what sum has been spent during 2003-2004 on enhanced security measures for Defence personnel and facilities, including increased guarding, patrolling and protective searches.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Of the $34.6 million in funding for enhanced protective security agreed in the 2003-04 Budget, $26.76 million had been spent as at 30 April 2004.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2002-2003 Budget measure âE-security national agendaâ, what sum has been spent by his department during (a) 2002-2003, and (b) 2003-2004 on improving e-security.
(2) On what e-security initiatives has funding been spent by his department.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (2) Funding has been spent, within the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD), on the following e-security initiatives:
(a) Equipment has been bought to:
(i) develop IT forensic and incident response capabilities; and
(ii) develop OnSecure, the online IT security and incident reporting website for government agencies.

(b) Development of a robust IT security incident response capability for the Government. The IT incident security response team assists government agencies to report IT security incidents to DSD under its incident-reporting scheme. The team also forms Defence's contribution to the Government's operational response capability, together with Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Federal Police, in the event of an incident involving the National Information Infrastructure.

(c) Provision of staff and funds to support Information Security Research and Development in the academic community, enhancing Defence's IT security product evaluation scheme (the Australasian Information Security Evaluation Program), and providing additional staff to support Defence's information security advice and assistance role with the Government.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3531)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the 2003-2004 Budget measures âA Safer Australiaâenhanced security for the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisationâ, what sum of additional funding has been spent in 2003-2004 to enhance security at the Lucas Heights Science and Technology Centre and the Replacement Research Reactor construction site;
(2) What was the (a) budgeted, and (b) actual cost of replacing the front gate.
(3) On what date did the new front gate become operational.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The 2003-2004 Budget measure âA Safer Australia - enhanced security for the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisationâ had two major components - funding for a new main entrance and for increased guarding costs.

The ANSTO new main entrance project was subject to consideration by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969. A submission was provided to the Committee in June 2003. An inspection and public hearing were held at ANSTO on 17 October 2003. On 26 November 2003, the Committee recommended that the project proceed. On 27 November 2003, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Hon Peter Slipper, moved the expediency motion for the project, and the motion received agreement. Details of the project can be found in the Committee's report at http://www.aph.gov.au/house/committee/pwc/lucas/report.htm.

The new front gate is part of a larger project consisting of a new formal entry zone with a gateway with a grille gate and an upgraded roadway; decommissioning of the existing entrance; and construction of the gatehouse zone (with a total area of 785 square meters) including new APS and ANSTO staff facilities with new offices, storage areas and staff amenities. A project of this nature requires extensive preliminary design activity before the commencement of construction. The principal design and security design consultancies are expected to be completed in early June. Actual project expenditure on this project to the end of April 2004 was $282,000.
The 2003-04 Budget also provided $1.7 million per annum for increased guarding costs. Those moneys will be expended this financial year.

The Budget measure also provided a further $749,000 for the installation of additional security devices across the facility, including the site of the current research reactor. These funds have been spent as foreshadowed.
(2) The budget for the new main entrance project is, as noted in the PWC report, $10.366 million. ANSTO does not foresee this budget being exceeded.
(3) As indicated in the PWC report, the new main entrance project is expected to be completed in 2005 and will become operational upon completion.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Customs Service: Southern Ocean Surveillance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3535)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) On how many days did marine patrols operate in the Southern Ocean during (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004.
(2) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, (i) which vessel or vessels conducted patrols in the Southern Ocean, and (ii) for how many days did each vessel conduct patrols.
(3) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, how many personnel undertook Southern Ocean patrol duties and which government agency employed them.

(4) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, what was the total cost to each agency of operating Southern Ocean patrols, and of this, what sum was attributable to (i) leasing or chartering costs, (ii) operating and maintenance costs, (iii) personnel costs, and (iv) other costs.
(5) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, which vessels in the Southern Ocean were (i) intercepted, (ii) subject to administrative seizure, and (iii) apprehended.

(6) For the year (a) 2001-2002, (b) 2002-2003, and (c) 2003-2004, in respect of each vessel intercepted in the Southern Ocean, (i) where was it registered, and (ii) what was the nature of the illegal activity it was engaged in.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: In respect of Australian Customs Service (Customs) activities only. Information on Southern Ocean surveillance and patrol activity undertaken by other agencies will be advised separately by those relevant Ministers.
(1) (a) Customs was not involved in any marine patrols in the Southern Ocean during 2001-2002.
(b) Customs marine patrols lasted 40 days during 2002-2003.
(c) Customs marine patrols lasted 127 days during 2003-2004.
(2) (a) Customs was not involved in any marine patrols in the Southern Ocean during 2001-2002.
(b) (i) During 2002-2003, Customs was involved in a Fisheries charter vessel, Aurora Australis; (ii) 40 days in 2003.
(c) (i) During 2003-2004, Customs chartered the vessel, Southern Supporter for two patrols which lasted a total of 109 days.
(3) (a) Customs personnel were not involved in any Southern Ocean patrol duties during 2001-2002.
(b) During 2002-2003, 22 Customs officers undertook Southern Ocean patrol duties. In addition, Customs paid for an Australian Antarctic Division (AAD) medical practitioner employed on contract.
(c) During 2003-2004, four Customs officers undertook Southern Ocean patrol duties. In addition, Customs paid for a paramedic employed on contract.
(4) (a) Customs was not involved in any marine patrols in the Southern Ocean during 2001-2002.
(b) (i) Customs leasing or chartering costs for 2002-2003: Nil
(ii) Customs operating and maintenance costs: Nil
(iii) Customs personnel costs: These costs were met by Fisheries
(iv) Other costs: $289,767
(c) (i) Customs leasing costs for 2003-2004: (See Note 1) below
(ii) Customs operating and maintenance costs: (See Note 1) below
(iii) Customs personnel costs: $58,646 plus $26,850 for the paramedic on contract.
(iv) Other costs: $1,956,035

(1) Information on the leasing, operating and maintenance costs, when put together with the number of patrol days, may reveal financial profit or loss on the provision of the service. Public disclosure of this Commercial-in-Confidence information may jeopardise current vessel charter contract negotiations between Customs and P&O. It could also provide P&O's competitors with unfair advantage in the tender process for a new vessel capability to undertake future Southern Ocean patrols.
(2) Personnel costs include the salaries and special allowances/ loadings paid to Customs officers participating in patrols. Time of Customs office staff is not included.
(3) Other costs include specialist equipment, training, communications gear, travel & accommodation.
(4) GST is not included in the figures provided above.
(5) Not all accounts for 2003-2004 have been received or finalised as at 16 June 2004.
(5) Customs was involved in the following interceptions and apprehensions in the Southern Ocean:
(a) 2001-2002: Not applicable.
(i) Viarsa I and Maya V.
(ii) Viarsa I and Maya V.
(iii) Viarsa I and Maya V.
(6) (a) 2001-2002: Not applicable.
(i) Both the Viarsa I and Maya V were registered in Uruguay.
(ii) Conducting fishing operations in contravention of the Fisheries Management Act 1991.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Customs Service: Southern Ocean Surveillance
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3538)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

quote.para: What number of days has the Government set as a target for marine patrols in the Southern Ocean in (a) 2004-2005, and (b) 2005-2006.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) As indicated in the Portfolio Budget Statements in support of the 2004 Budget for the Attorney-General's Portfolio, page 113, the target of 200 - 250 days has been set for marine patrols in the Southern Ocean during the financial year 2004-2005.
(b) For the financial year 2005-2006, the Government expects that a similar performance target will be met.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware of the plight of Mr Greg Martin in Adelaide in whose street three trees have been cut down to make way for a six-storey commercial building without plans to shield the building's west facing windows from the sun.
(2) Does he recall his statement in 1997 that the Government would implement mandatory energy efficiency standards within12 months if voluntary methods did not achieve results.
(3) What has the Government done about implementing mandatory energy efficiency standards.
(4) What does the Government intend to do about implementing mandatory energy efficiency standards.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Mr Martin wrote to me on this matter and Senator Macfarlane's office responded on 31 May 2004.

(2) The Safeguarding the Future: Australia's Response to Climate Change announced on 20 November 1997 stated that, if after twelve months the government assessed that the voluntary approach was not achieving acceptable progress towards higher standards of energy efficiency for housing and commercial buildings, the government would work with the States and industry to implement mandatory standards through amendment of the Building Code of Australia.

(3) and (4) The Government is actively supporting the development of minimum energy performance standards for commercial buildings that will reduce the current level of energy use, decrease the greenhouse impact of the building sector and improve Australia's economic performance.
Minimum energy efficiency standards for houses were introduced into the Building Code of Australia in January 2003.

Commencing in 2005, new energy performance requirements for all types of commercial buildings will be progressively introduced through the Building Code of Australia. These will become mandatory when implemented through State and Territory regulations. The performance standards to be applied will be subject to rigorous evaluation to ensure that the level is appropriate for our climatic conditions, will substantially reduce the greenhouse impact of each building class and are economically advantageous for the nation. The standards will be subject to periodic review to ensure that the Building Code reflects broader community expectations and facilitates economically viable solutions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 11 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the Internal Audit Review (IAR) of the Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee (ACC) referred to in Senate estimates Hearings on 19 February 2004, (a) when was the IAR conducted,
(b) why was the Northern Rivers ACC selected to be the subject of an IAR,
(c) were any complaints received by his department about the administration of operation of the ACC,
(d) what were the terms of reference of the review,
(e) what were (i) findings, and (ii) recommendations, of the review,
(f) can he provide a copy of the Internal Audit report, and
(g) what changes have been made to the administration and the operation of the ACC since the review was undertaken.
(2) What projects were approved for funding from the Regional Assistance Programme for the Northern Rivers region during 2002-2003.
(3) What projects have been approved for funding from the Regional partnerships Programme for the Northern Rivers region since 1 July 2003.
(4) For each of the projects identified in parts (2) and (3),
(a) who were the proponents of these projects, and
(b) are any of the proponents (i) members of the Northern Rivers ACC,
(ii) related to members of the Northern Rivers ACC,
(iii) employers of members of the Northern Rivers ACC.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The independent review of the ACC was conducted in October 2003.

(b) Concerns about the operations of the ACC were raised with Minister Anderson's office in June 2003. The ACC was audited as part of the Department's internal audit plan to ensure an independent review of the allegations made.
(c) Yes.

recruitment of staff, managing employees, workplace conditions including privacy issues, occupational health and safety issues, veracity of advice to staff and any other employment related issues;
staff expenses, including travel and accommodation;
vehicle management, use and expenses as per the funding contracts and the ACC Handbook; and
conflict of interest issues (real or perceived) and documentation of same, regarding all decision making by the ACC.
(e) (i) Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee - Key Findings

entry.para: The review did not identify any breaches of the ACC's funding contracts, the ACC Handbook or the ACC's constitution. However, operational weaknesses were noted in the following areas:Record Keeping;Documentation and review of financial journal entries; andPreparation of budget statements.

The following issues arose from the review:Some decisions were made by the Board / Executive Officer without the necessary reporting and accountability;The Chair and the Executive Officer made key operational decisions without Committee involvement eg. The recruitment of the Indigenous Employment Officer without a merit based selection process;Committee process and decision making was not always appropriately documented; andPotential conflicts of interest do not always appear to have been considered as part of the recruitment process eg. The Executive officer's relationship with one of the candidates during the recruitment of the Small Business Assistance Officer.

The review identified a lack of consistency in Human Resource practices at the ACC. In particular:There was no formal grievance process, leaving the ACC exposed to external criticism;Inconsistent recruitment procedures;No evidence of reference checking in some cases, which is in breach of Commonwealth guidelines;Poor record keeping on personnel files;Inconsistent performance appraisal process; andLack of transparency in the process of awarding salary increases.

The review identified a lack of evidence of control and review in a number of the areas tested. In particular:Key documents were not kept current including the asset register and bank signatory list;Staff expenses were not always supported by appropriate documentation eg. Invoices or evidenced as reviewed for personal use; andA number of invoices could not be located during the audit but were subsequently provided.

answer.para: (ii) Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee - Summary of the Audit Recommendations

entry.para: Documentation to support expenditure items should be up to date and on file.
A paper file should be set up to record all journal entries and these should be evidenced as reviewed by the Executive Officer
Budget statements should be up to date and on file.
All matters impacting on the operation of the NRACC should be referred to the whole Committee unless specific powers have been delegated to individual officers,
The appointment of new members should be recorded in Committee minutes in accordance with the NRACC Constitution.

The NRACC should ensure that all conflicts of interest are considered by the Committee as laid down in the ACC Handbook and that decisions and actions taken by the Committee to address any conflicts are formally documented in the minutes.
The NRACC Committee should develop and agree a grievance process, which should be clearly documented and accessible to staff.
The NRACC Committee should agree the general recruitment process in accordance with section 5.4 of the ACC Handbook, which should be documented and accessible to staff.
Employment contracts and related information should be current and held on personnel files.
Documented evidence of the recruitment process should be held on personnel files including evidence that references have been sought and reviewed.
The NRACC should provide evidence of the agreement with DEWR that the selection of the Indigenous Employment Officer could be made outside normal recruitment procedures.
The recruitment of the Indigenous Employment Officer should be reviewed by the DEWR to ensure due process has been followed.
Procedures for performance appraisals and salary awards should be clearly documented and accessible to staff.
Performance appraisals should be held on a regular basis and the appropriate documentation held on personnel files.
The procedure, agreed by the Committee for awarding salary increases should be transparent and should be clearly linked to the performance appraisal process.
All staff expense claims should be supported by the appropriate documentation and retained on file.
All staff expense claims should be evidenced as reviewed for personal use and any personal reimbursement obtained from officers clearly documented.
The process for obtaining the best price for vehicle leases should be documented and held on file.
All vehicle files should contain a copy of the lease agreement.
Log books should be maintained for all NRACC vehicles in accordance with ATO requirements and consistent with the requirements of the ACC Handbook.
The asset register should be updated on a regular basis and amendments made to the NRACC insurance policy as necessary.
All asset purchases should be supported by an invoice and an appropriate documented approval as required by the ACC Handbook.
The bank signatory list should be updated to reflect the changes to the NRACC Committee membership.
The NRACC should consider keeping one file for cheque requisitions and EFT transactions so that information can be filed in sequential order.
All NRACC computers should have appropriate password controls.
Back-up disks should be held off-site at all times.

answer.para: (f) Yes.
(g) Northern Rivers Area Consultative Committee - Summary of the Audit Recommendations

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 12 May 2004:

question.para: (1) What will the Australian delegation report to the United Nations (UN) Commission for Sustainable Development when it meets in New York next month about actions and resources that the Australian Government has committed towards meeting the water and sanitation targets of the UN Millenium Development Goals.
(2) What action is the Government taking to build momentum and contribute to the international effort to meet these targets.
(3) Will the Australian Government announce any initiatives to the Commission; if not, why not.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Commission on Sustainable Development requests written reports from countries against a set of predetermined questions. Information on actions and resources committed towards meeting the water and sanitation targets of the UN Millenium Development Goals was not sought for the 2004 session of the Commission held in New York in April 2004.

(2) As indicated in the response to your question on notice number 3561, tabled by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Australia's total water-related development cooperation for 2004-05 is estimated at $135 million. A new package of assistance focusing on water quality, valued at $5 million, was announced in the 2004-05 budget. This package will support training, awareness raising and research on water quality in the Asia- Pacific region, particularly the growing problem of arsenic contamination of drinking water. In collaboration with the World Health Organisation, Australia will develop a Water Quality Risk Management Framework to assist implementing agencies. The Framework will focus on providing guidance for Non Government Organisations (NGO) that implement water initiatives.

(3) The twelfth session of the Commission on Sustainable Development was a review session, focused on assessing progress made against international agreements, such as the 2002 Johannesburg Plan of Implementation in the areas of water, sanitation and human settlements. In this context, the Government appropriately focused on contributing Australia's significant policy and technical expertise in the management of freshwater resources.

subdebateinfo.title: Education: Full-Time Equivalent Male Teaching Staff
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3566)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 12 May 2004:

question.para: (1) What proportion of all school teachers in Australia is male.
(2) What proportion of all primary school teachers in Australia is male.
(3) What proportion of all high school teachers in Australia is male.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Based on published data available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), in 2003 there were 229,575 full-time equivalent (FTE) teaching staff, comprising 74,872 males (32.6 per cent) and 154,703 females (67.4 per cent).
(2) Based on published data available from ABS, in 2003 there were 116,568 FTE teaching staff at the primary level, comprising 24,362 males (20.9 per cent) and 92,206 females (79.1 per cent).
(3) Based on published data available from ABS, in 2003 there were 113,008 FTE teaching staff at the secondary level, comprising 50,510 males (44.7 per cent) and 62,497 females (55.3 per cent).
