talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 May 2004:

question.para: (1) In the period since 1 January 2003 to date, how many foreign vessels engaged in illegal fishing in Australia's exclusive economic zone have been identified by Australian Customs, the Royal Australian Navy, Coastwatch, or any other Government agency.
(2) How many vessels have been detained, which vessels were detained and how many crew were arrested in respect of each vessel.
(3) In respect of the vessels that were identified and inspected but not detained, how many were there and was a bond or other security requested or provided.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Between 1 January 2003 and 31 March 2004, there were 1588 sightings of vessels in Australia's exclusive economic zone, suspected of being in breach of fisheries laws. Of these 1588 sightings, 253 vessels were subsequently identified as fishing illegally.
(2) Of the 253 vessels, 168 vessels were apprehended and 1154 crew were detained. The remaining 85 vessels were subject to legislative forfeiture of their catch and equipment.
(3) Of the 168 vessels that were apprehended, 92 were subsequently released on the payment of bonds (to Australian Fisheries Management Authority).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 445 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, page 5015) which stated that âas part of the new investigation, the Department of Defence has agreed to re-examine the possibility of assisting with the collection of DNA samplesâ, what was the outcome of the new investigation.
(2) Is the Minister aware of a private expedition in July 2002 to the location where Lance Corporal Parker and Private Gillson went missing.
(3) Has the Department of Defence taken any action in response to the findings of that expedition; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
(4) Is the Government contributing any resources to the search for these missing servicemen; if so, what are the details; if not, why not.
(5) What cooperation has taken place over the last two years between the Australian Government and relevant authorities of the United States of America in respect of the missing servicemen.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) In November 2003, I directed the Army and Air Force Headquarters to contact the families of the missing personnel and ask if they wished to provide Family Reference Samples to the United States authorities. The following advice is provided:
two Army families had already provided Family Reference Samples in 2002;
two Army families were not interested in providing Family Reference Samples; and
both Air Force families advised that they did not wish to provide Family Reference Samples.
Until the families indicate otherwise, or strong circumstantial evidence surfaces, the families of the six MIA personnel in Vietnam would not be approached again.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes. Army Headquarters is reviewing the report of the July 2002 expedition.
(4) No. At present the above report is being reviewed for enough evidence to initiate a physical search for the MIA's.

(5) Defence has forwarded reports and sought confirmation of continued support from the United States Government in the event that their investigations uncover new information regarding the six Australian Defence Force MIA personnel.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 May 2004:

question.para: (1) What evidence is there to support the view that a significant number of Australians do not understand the health services available under Medicare.
(2) What is the cost of the Government's (a) electronic media, (b) print media, and (c) pamphlet campaign titled âStrengthening Medicareâ.
(3) How will the effectiveness of the campaign be measured.
(4) Will details of this evaluation be made available to the public before the next federal election; if not why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The decision to include information about the health services available under Medicare was made because research conducted for the Strengthening Medicare campaign showed that this was needed to assist in understanding the role of the new Medicare Safety Net.
(2) (a), (b) and (c) Final costs of the campaign are not yet available.
(3) The campaign's effectiveness will be measured using tracking research and through an evaluation.
(4) No decision has been made yet on when the evaluation of the campaign would be publicly released. No advice is available on when the federal election is to be held.

subdebateinfo.title: Magistrates Court and the Family Court
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3584)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he aware that regional litigants are unable to place reverse charge telephone calls to the Family Court because of the telephone menu and queuing system used by the Family Court and the refusal of Telstra's operators to wait longer than a minute or operate the menu selection system.
(2) Is there any additional funding in the Budget for regional litigants involved in Family Court cases for purposes such as the provision of local call dialling.
(3) Does the Budget provide additional funds for the Magistrates Court and the Family Court.

(4) Is there any provision in the Budget for implementing the recommendations of the inquiry into child custody arrangements in the event of family separation undertaken last year by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs.
(5) Is there any provision in the Budget for funding targeting specific policy objectives for the Family Court.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of a complaint by a constituent of the honourable member about problems making reverse charge telephone calls to the Family Court. However, the Family Court of Australia is responsible for its own administration. The Chief Justice is responsible for the operation and management of the court, including the telephone system and the court's policy regarding the acceptance of reverse charge phone calls. The Family Court has advised my Department that all Registries have procedures in place to respond to reverse charge requests.

(2) As with (1), the Family Court is responsible for its own policies in relation to local call dialling. The Australian Government has provided $52.7m in additional legal aid funding over four years in the 2004-05 Budget. This includes new funding to provide a duty lawyer service to assist those people who seek to represent themselves in family law matters before the Family Court and Federal Magistrates Court. Some of this funding will be used in providing assistance for regional litigants in Family Court matters.

(3) The 2004-05 Budget provided for indexation for general price increases. It also provided an additional $34.2m over four years (including $4.2m capital funding) to the Federal Magistrates Court for the appointment of eight additional federal magistrates and to fit out accommodation for the new magistrates. These appointments will reduce the time taken to consider migration matters in the Federal Magistrates Court and deal with a backlog of migration cases. This complements other legislative and administrative reforms, such as streamlining the availability of judicial review of migration decisions, to reduce delays in handling migration matters.
(4) As the Government response to the recommendations of the inquiry is still under consideration there was no provision in the 2004-05 Budget for this matter.

(5) The 2004-05 Budget provides $114.8 million in appropriations to the Family Court to allow it to serve âthe interests of the Australian community by ensuring families and children in need can access effective and high quality servicesâ. Further information on how the Family Court allocates this funding can be found in the Family Court Budget Statements in the Attorney-General's 2004-05 Portfolio Budget Statements (available online at http://law.gov.au/budget).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 2004:

question.para: (1) What role did the Australian Defence Science and Technology Organisation have in developing the Strategic Maritime Information System (SMIS).

(2) In respect of this database, (a) what was its nature, (b) what geographical areas did it include, and (c) did it include (i) maps, (ii) maritime boundaries, (iii) reports of incidents at sea, and (iv) port details.
(3) Did the database contain data on merchant ships; if so, (a) how many merchant ships were included, and (b) what were the criteria under which they were included.
(4) Is the SMIS still operational; if not, (a) when did it cease to be operational, and (b) has it been replaced by any other system; if so, what are the details of the new system.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Strategic Maritime Information System software development was undertaken entirely within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.
(2) (a) The database comprised representative open source maritime data.
(b) The area of interest was originally 90?East to 135?East by 15?North to 15?South. This area was later extended to include some specific adjacent areas of interest.
(c) (i) Yes.
(ii) Yes.
(iii) Yes.
(iv) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(a) Approximately 2,000 non-military ships.

(b) The ship details were sourced from a database from Lloyds of London, which included: identification, number of vessels, together with details of ownership, flag, tonnage, draught, length, ship port arrival and departure reports, and some port information.
(b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 26 May 2004:

question.para: (1) What is the impact of the intellectual property provisions associated with the Australia-US Free Trade Agreement (AUSFTA) on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
(2) Does the AUSFTA impact on patent licences such as patents extensions; if so, how; if not, why not.
(3) Could the AUSFTA delay the entry onto the market of generic drugs; if so, how; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The intellectual property provisions of the Australia-United States Free Trade Agreement will have no impact on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
(2) No, the AUSFTA does not impact on patent licences or patent extensions. The AUSFTA does not require any changes to Australian law with respect to these issues.
(3) No, the Government will implement Australia's AUSFTA obligations to ensure that delays in the entry onto the market of generic drugs do not occur.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 2004:

quote.para: In respect of the development of the Army's sustainability model, (a) when was the need to develop it identified, (b) when was the proposal developed and formally adopted as an authorised project, (c) was a timeline set; if so, how much time was allowed; if not, why not, (d) how many personnel at what rank have been dedicated to the project, (e) how many man-hours have been expended to date, (f) how many hours are required to complete the project, and (g) when will Army's sustainability model be completed.

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
Fran Bailey
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (a) The need for an Army Sustainment Model was first identified as a result of the development of the Combat Force Sustainment Model in 2001-02.
(b) In early 2004.

(c) The intention is to develop the Army Sustainment Model during 2004. The Director-General Preparedness and Plans - Army has made a commitment to brief the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade - Defence Sub-Committee on the progress of the Army Sustainment Model at the end of the year.

(d) The Director-General Preparedness and Plans - Army has been assigned the task and has a number of his staff involved as well as the Army's Scientific Adviser and staff from the Defence Science and Technology Organisation.
(e) and (f) No specific data is available as the project is being undertaken as part of a broader examination of the Army's structure.
(g) The Defence Sub-Committee is to be advised by the end of the year on the progress of the Army Sustainment Model.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 May 2004:

quote.para: Is the Army's sustainability model predicated on guidance provided in the White Paper that the Army should be capable of deploying a brigade and a concurrent battalion group; if so, (a) how many months can the Army sustain such deployments, and (b) are the deployments predicated on a rotational system of two's; one deployed and one training up.

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
Fran Bailey
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Yes.

answer.para: (a) The model is currently being developed and the information requested covering the model cannot be provided at this stage. However, the Army's ability to meet the range of tasks required by the Government is not dependent on the model. The intent of the model is to add clarity to existing tools and provide the most accurate advice to the Government that is possible regarding force sustainment.
(b) In some cases, yes depending on the capability being rotated.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 27 May 2004:

quote.para: How many reports of illegal activity have been made to the Australian High Tech Crime Centre since its inception and what has been the nature of those reports.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Australian High Tech Crime Centre (AHTCC) has received approximately 2600 referrals since its inception on 2 July 2003. Of these referrals;

answer.para: many did not contain criminal offences and were not investigated,
a number were accepted for investigation by the AHTCC, and
a number related to offences in other jurisdictions, and were referred to those jurisdictions.

quote.para: Examples of matters referred to the AHTCC include;

answer.para: online fraud (for example, âphishingâ and online auction frauds),
online child sexual abuse,
information communication technology enabled crime such as computer intrusions, denial of service, maleficent code and theft of telecommunications services, and
various matters relating to criminal use of technology, such as the use of the internet to facilitate the commission of other crimes.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports that al-Qaeda may have invested in companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX).
(2) Which Commonwealth laws apply to the Australian assets and investments of listed terrorist organisations and individuals.
(3) Is any agency in the Minister's portfolio investigating these allegations; if so (a) which agency, and (b) when did the investigations commence; if not, why not.

(4) Has any agency in the Minister's portfolio contacted British intelligence agencies about these allegations; if so (i) which agency, (ii) when, (iii) who was contacted, and (iv) what was the response.

(5) Does the Government have any information on al-Qaeda backed investments in Australia; if so, is the Minister able to say (a) how much has been invested, (b) when the investments were made, (c) in which companies the investments were made, (d) which front organisations, companies or individuals are being used, and (f) whether any accounts or assets have been frozen following investigations.
(6) How many accounts or assets have been frozen under the UN requirement that assets of terrorists and terrorist organisations be frozen.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: As the same questions were asked of the Attorney-General, I refer the honourable member to the Attorney-General's response to Question No 3595.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 May 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports that al-Qa'ida may have invested in companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX).
(2) Which Commonwealth laws apply to the Australian assets and investments of listed terrorist organisations and individuals.
(3) Is any agency in the Minister's portfolio investigating these allegations; if so, (a) which agency, and (b) when did the investigations commence; if not, why not.

(4) Has any agency in the Minister's portfolio contacted British intelligence agencies about these allegations; if so, (i) which agency, (ii) when, (iii) who was contacted, and (iv) what was the response.

(5) Does the Government have any information on al-Qa'ida backed investments in Australia; if so, is the Minister able to say (a) how much has been invested, (b) when the investments were made, (c) in which companies the investments were made, (d) which front organisations, companies or individuals are being used, and (f) whether any accounts or assets have been frozen following investigations.
(6) How many accounts or assets have been frozen under the UN requirement that assets of terrorists and terrorist organisations be frozen.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) On the basis of the information currently available to ASIO, ASIO is not aware of any al- Qa'ida investment in companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange.

(2) The Minister for Foreign Affairs administers the Charter of the United Nations Act 1945 and the Charter of the United Nations (Terrorism and Dealings with Assets) Regulations 2002 for the purposes of the freezing of assets of listed individuals or terrorist organisations.
(3) I will not be commenting on the specifics of what is, or is not, being investigated by Commonwealth authorities.
(4) I will not be providing specific comment on Government agencies' relationships and work with British, or other, intelligence services.

(5) On the basis of the information currently available to ASIO, it is not aware of any al-Qa'ida investments in Australia. Should ASIO become aware of such investments it would refer the matter to and work jointly with, the Australian Federal Police, for action under the relevant legislation.

(6) There is one current case of assets frozen under the Charter of the United Nations (Terrorism and Dealings with Assets) Regulations 2002. On 27 August 2002, relevant agencies took steps to freeze three accounts held by the International Sikh Youth Federation, totalling $2196.99.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 June 2004:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 2763 (Hansard, 11 February 2004, page 24555) are the amendments to the Family Law Act 1975 introduced into the House of Representatives on 5 December 2003 retrospective enabling relief for the creditors of Mr Jodee Rich and Mrs Maxine Rich; if so, which of the amendments provides retrospectivity; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The amendments apply to financial agreements made at any time, whether before or after the commencement of Schedule 4A.

Therefore anyone who has entered into financial agreements to defeat or defraud creditors, or with reckless disregard for the interests of creditors, may find their arrangements open to scrutiny by the courts.

The retrospective application of these amendments is justified given that the purposes to which the amendments are directed are ones which involve defeating or defrauding creditors or acting with reckless disregard for the interests of creditors.
I understand from press reports at the time that the financial agreement between Mr Jodee Rich and Mrs Maxine Rich was rescinded.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Contracted Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3606)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister's Department contracted the services of a (a) business adviser, (b) financial adviser, (c) probity adviser, (d) legal adviser, and (e) probity auditor to assist with the next tender round for the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy.
(2) What is the estimated cost of this advice.
(3) Which firms have been contracted to provide this advice and what is the precise nature of the services to be provided by each.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) has contracted the services of a (a) business adviser, (b) financial adviser, (c) probity adviser, (d) legal adviser, and (e) probity auditor to assist with the next tender round for the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy.
(2) The estimated cost of this advice is:
(a) Business adviser: $70,000
(b) Financial adviser: $50,000
(c) Probity adviser: $50,000
(d) Legal adviser: $72,000
(e) Probity auditor: $50,000
(3) The firms contracted to provide these services and the nature of the services to be provided by each are as follows:
(a) Business adviser: Cogent Solutions Pty Ltd.

Services to be provided: Ad hoc advice and guidance on business issues, either in written or oral form, as required by the Department. Advice may be required in relation to any or all activities involved in the competitive tender processes for the IHSS services including, but not limited to:
(i) providing advice on the complete procurement cycle including tendering advice, procurement evaluation, contract development, contract management, using DIMIA policy, procedures and templates;
(ii) providing advice relating to developing and reviewing service delivery models;
(iii) assisting with developing performance standards and monitoring methods; and
(iv) assisting in the provision of advice to key stakeholders.
(b) Financial adviser: Cogent Solutions Pty Ltd.

Services to be provided: Ad hoc financial advice and guidance, either in written or oral form, as required by the Department. Advice may be required in relation to any or all activities involved in the competitive tender processes for the IHSS services including, but not limited to:
(i) assessing financial risks and developing strategies for managing the financial risks in a tender process;
(ii) developing pricing strategies to cost tenderer's services and appropriate structuring and development of pricing schedules in relation to the tender documentation;
(iii) contributing to the development of evaluation methodology relating to financial aspects of the tender;
(iv) evaluating financial aspects of tenders, including normalisation of prices, assessing financial viability of tenderers and capacity to deliver the contracted services for the tendered price;
(v) providing broad commercial advice to assist in the development of the financial aspects of the contract; and
(vi) providing advice on financial issues arising in contract negotiations and assessing the impact of accepting suggested changes.
(c) Probity adviser: Acumen Alliance (ACT) Pty Ltd.

Services to be provided: Ad hoc probity advice and guidance, either in written or oral form, as required by the Department. Advice may be required in relation to any or all activities involved in the competitive tender processes for the IHSS services including, but not limited to:
(i) establishing the foundations for the tendering process including developing probity plans, protocols and strategies for overcoming potential problems;
(ii) providing risk management strategies for probity aspects of the tender process;
(iii) developing and assessing the procurement process recommending appropriate tendering methods;
(iv) reviewing and checking the procurement documentation for completeness and appropriateness in regards to probity issues;
(v) monitoring the tender process to ensure compliance of the process to probity requirements including advertising tenders, enquiries from tenderers, amendments to tenders, handling late tenders;

(vi) reviewing the evaluation process including checking evaluation plans, clarifying tenders, recommending tools and models to use in assisting evaluation (eg. evaluation software) , and debriefing tenderers;
(vii) conducting probity checks of tenderers;
(viii) probity advice during contract negotiations with the preferred tenderer; and
(ix) probity issues that may arise in managing the contract.
(d) Legal adviser: Clayton Utz

Services to be provided: Ad hoc legal advice and guidance, either in written or oral form, as required by the Department. Advice may be required in relation to any or all activities involved in the competitive tender processes for the IHSS services including, but not limited to:

(i) reviewing and providing comment on documents as required by the Department. These documents may include, but are not limited to, the Statement of Requirement, the Request for Tender, evaluation criteria and evaluation plans; and
(ii) developing contracts for IHSS service delivery.
(e) Probity auditor: PSI Consulting Pty Ltd

Services to be provided: Independent audits to monitor the tender processes and to report in written form to the Department. The Contractor will review and assess how well the Department has met its probity obligations in developing, monitoring, reviewing and managing the tender processes. The Contractor may be expected to comment on each step of the competitive tendering process, or at the end of the complete process, and provide appropriate written advice.

subdebateinfo.title: Paterson Electorate: Gan Gan Army Camp
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3609)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 June 2004:

quote.para: Has the Government sold land formerly known as Gan Gan Army Camp in the electoral division of Paterson; if so, (a) at what price, (b) to whom, and (c) has the transaction reached settlement.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (a), (b), and (c) Yes. See my answer to Senate Question on Notice 1670, published in the Senate Hansard on 8 September 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Has he allocated Roads to Recovery Program funding to a one kilometre section of road known as Gan Gan Road in the electoral division of Paterson; if so, what sum has been allocated.
(2) Will the Port Stephens Council make a financial contribution to the roadworks; if so, is he able to say whether the funds will be raised under Section 94 of the NSW Local Government Act.
(3) Will any landholder(s) on or around Gan Gan Road contribute to the cost of the road; if so (a) who, and (b) what sum(s).

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the Roads to Recovery programme, councils are free to allocate funds to road projects of their own choosing. The Australian Government is not involved in the selection of projects for funding under this programme. Port Stephens Council has allocated $548,000 of Roads to Recovery funding for works on Gan Gan Road with stage two scheduled to be completed by April 2005 and to date has claimed $435,800.
(2) and (3) I cannot advise the source of funding for this road other than what the Australian Government has provided. That is a matter for council.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Departmental Library
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3618)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2490 (Hansard, 24 November 2003, page 22669), will the Minister clarify the current stage of negotiations with the (a) National Library, (b) Victoria University, (c) Maritime Museum of Sydney, (d) Migration Museum in South Australia, and (e) Migration Museum in Melbourne regarding the offer and acceptance of culled departmental library resources.
(2) Will the Minister account for the current location of the departmental library resources which have already been culled.
(3) Is there a centralised system for members of the public to locate and access former departmental library resources which are now scattered around Australia.

(4) Has the Minister or the department considered establishing a committee of former immigration officials from the era of the culled resources to advise upon the ongoing relevance of particular departmental library resources and to decide upon their retention or relocation; if so, (a) was a committee established, and (b) what is its current status; if not, why not.

(5) Can the Minister explain how information used to develop immigration policies can be adequately delivered by electronic means to officers of the department while maintaining their access to precedents established and recorded before electronic records were commonplace.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The National Library has advised that they are only interested in Australian material held by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) Library. As an item is removed from the DIMIA catalogue, the National Library of Australia's holdings are checked. The item is then offered to the National Library if it is not already held there and it is an Australian item. To date the National Library has accepted approximately 179 culled items.

(b), (c), (d) and (e) The Victorian University, the Maritime Museum of Sydney, the Migration Museum in South Australia, and the Migration Museum in Melbourne were contacted to seek expressions of interest for the culled material. Each organisation advised that their space was very limited and therefore they would need to be very selective in regard to the items on offer. They also advised that they would require complete lists of the items on offer before they could make a decision on acceptance or otherwise.

Subsequent to contacting the above organisations DIMIA became aware that the ACT Government was planning to establish a multicultural centre in Civic, ACT. DIMIA offered the culled material to the ACT Government. They were pleased to accept all the material on offer.
(2) The items that have been culled are with the National Library and the ACT Government.
(3) Any significant items that relate to the history of the Department, government immigration policy or are of historical importance have been retained in the DIMIA library. This includes:
all reports by or for the Department or the government of the day relating to portfolio responsibilities, regardless of date of publication;
reports by such bodies as the National Population Council, the Bureau of Immigration Research and the Immigration Advisory Council; and
immigration conference papers, works by former Ministers and relevant academic works.
This material continues to be available via the DIMIA library.
Most of the material culled from the library was:
material easily available on-line (eg Hansard);
duplicate copies of little used material;
parliamentary papers unrelated to the portfolio; and
non-immigration related material eg self help books, and outdated computer books.

The culled material held by the National Library can be located and accessed through their catalogue system. Material held by the ACT Government will be accessible via the multicultural centre when it is established.

(4) The Department has not considered establishing a committee of former immigration officials from the era of the culled resources to advise of the ongoing relevance of particular departmental library resources. The cull was undertaken by a professional librarian employing standard library practices using a set of standard criteria including date of publication, currency of information, usage rates and relevance to DIMIA's history and core responsibilities.

(5) Information that might be useful to officers of the Department to conduct their work is held by the DIMIA library. The cull criteria explicitly excluded from the cull any significant material relating to the history of the Department and the immigration policies of this and previous governments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) currently researching systems for use on (a) military, and (b) civilian aircraft to protect against surface-to-air missiles; if so, (i) when was the research started, (ii) how advanced is the research, and (iii) when is it expected that systems will be ready for installation.

(2) Has the DSTO previously researched systems for use on (a) military, and (b) civilian aircraft to protect against surface-to-air missiles; if so, when was the research (i) started, (ii) finished, and (iii) why was it terminated.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Yes.
(i) The research has been ongoing for as long as surface-to-air missiles have been seen as a threat to Australian Defence Force (ADF) aircraft.
(ii) and (iii) Many ADF aircraft are currently fitted with defensive systems, but research continues.
(b) No.
(2) (a) Yes.
(i) The research has been ongoing for as long as surface-to-air missiles have been seen as a threat to ADF aircraft.
(ii) It has not finished.
(iii) It has not been terminated. The research is continuous, as the threat evolves, so the defensive measures must also evolve.
(b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 3 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports that Israel is planning to install `Flight Guard' on civilian aircraft to protect against shoulder-fired surface to air missiles.
(2) Is the Minister aware of the `Flight Guard' system; if so, is he able to say (a) who developed it, (b) how it works, (c) what it protects against, and (d) what it costs per aircraft.
(3) Has the Minister or his Department evaluated this system for possible use in Australia; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether any commercial airlines in Australia have expressed interest in the system or evaluated it.
(5) Is the Government evaluating anti-missile systems for civilian aircraft and has it provided advice to Qantas on the installations of anti-missile systems.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) This question should be directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence.
(3) No. Assessment of such equipment is a commercial decision for the airlines based on their respective risk assessment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of reports that Israel in planning to install `Flight Guard' on civilian aircraft to protect against shoulder-fired surface to air missiles.
(2) Is the Minister aware of the `Flight Guard' system; if so, is he able to say (a) who developed it, (b) how it works, (c) what it protects against, and (d) what it costs per aircraft.
(3) Has the Minister or his Department evaluated this system for possible use in Australia; if so, what was the outcome; if not, why not.
(4) Is the Minister able to say whether any commercial airlines in Australia have expressed interest in the system or evaluated it.
(5) Is the Government evaluating anti-missile systems for civilian aircraft and has it provided advice to Qantas on the installations of anti-missile systems.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(a) Flight Guard is a joint venture between Israeli Aircraft Industries' subsidiary Elta and Israeli Military Systems.

(b) Flight Guard comprises two main components: a radar system that detects the launch of surface-to-air missiles, and a countermeasures dispensing system that jams and diverts heat-seeking missiles. The sensors automatically detect a missile, confirm a threat, and deploy some or all of the phosphorous flares.
(c) Flight Guard is used to protect against Man Portable Air Defence Systems by using high-temperature flares to attract heat-seeking missiles and defeat an attack on an aircraft.
(d) The cost of Flight Guard is approximately US$750,000 to US$1 million per system.
(3) (4) and (5) This question should be directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

subdebateinfo.title: House of Representatives Family and Community Services Committee: Recommendations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3626)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 June 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Services titled Every Picture Tells a Story, which recommendations impact on the Minister's portfolio responsibilities.
(2) What steps were taken to consider the recommendations and how many officers, at which levels, were engaged in preparing the Government's response.
(3) When was consideration of the Government's response (a) commenced, and (b) completed; and, if it is not completed, when will it be completed.
(4) Has a cabinet submission been prepared; if so, when was it lodged and when was it considered.
(5) What sum was allocated in the Budget for 2004-2005 to implement the recommendations of the report.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The following table sets out the recommendations that impact on my portfolio responsibilities.

Responsibility for some of the recommendations is shared between my Department and the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS). In particular, the Departments share responsibility for the Family Relationships Services Program. My Department generally funds services for separated families and FaCS funds pre-separation services. FaCS administers the program on behalf of both departments.

entry.para: Responsibility shared between Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Family and Community Services

answer.para: (2) Consultation between officers of my Department, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Family and Community Services on the Government's response to the report has been ongoing.
In my Department, the following officers have been involved in preparing the Government's response to the report:
(3) (a) 2 January 2004 - the first working day my Department resumed work following the Christmas period.
(b) Consideration of the report is continuing.
(4) Cabinet processes are confidential.
(5) As the report is still under consideration, no funding was provided in the 2004-05 Budget to implement the report's recommendations.

subdebateinfo.title: House of Representatives Family and Community Services Committee: Recommendations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3629)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, on notice, on 3 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Has his department considered the proposal to establish a tribunal as recommended in the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Services titled Every Picture Tells a Story presented out of session in December 2003.
(2) Has he sought legal advice on the constitutionality of the proposed tribunal; if so, (a) when, (b) when was it received, and (c) what was the advice.
(3) Has he sought an estimate of the cost of the tribunal from his department; if so, (a) when, (b) when was it received, and (c) what is it.
(4) Has he seen newspaper reports suggesting that the cost would be $650 million and is this estimate consistent with the estimate of his department.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. It would not be appropriate to provide details concerning the legal advice that the Government has received to assist it in considering its response to the issues raised in the Committee's report.
(3) Yes. It would not be appropriate to provide details concerning the advice the Government has received about the estimated cost of the Tribunal.

(4) Yes I have seen the newspaper reports. As stated in the answer to question 3, it would not be appropriate to provide details concerning the advice the Government has received about the estimated cost of the Tribunal. I cannot comment on media speculation about the estimated cost of the Tribunal.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Is his department aware of claims of human rights abuses in Bangladesh and that there is a degree of government tolerance of violence towards minorities and the non government organisation (NGO) sector.

(2) Is the Australian Government aware that (a) the Human Rights Congress for Bangladesh Minorities has relayed accounts of beatings, extortion and looting in minority areas of the Kalia municipality during the period 6 to 8 May; if so, has the Australian High Commission received an account of these events, (b) the British High Commissioner was injured in a bombing in Sylhet on May 21, (c) Awami League MP, Robbani Ahshan Ullah, was murdered two months ago and that despite eye witness accounts no arrests have eventuated, (d) Dr Kazi Faruq Ahmed and David William Biswas of the NGO, Proshika, were arrested on 21 May and that the latter was refused bail despite suffering from diabetes and high blood pressure, and (e) at least ten people have been killed in District 17, seemingly on political, sectarian grounds in the past few months.
(3) Has Australia made any representations to the Bangladesh Government in regards to the perceived climate of fear in the country.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) My department is aware of claims of human rights abuses in Bangladesh. It is not evident that there is a degree of government tolerance of violence towards minorities and the non-government organisation sector.
(2) (a) Yes. The Human Rights Congress for Bangladesh Minorities forwarded a copy of the accounts referred to in the honourable member's question to the Australian High Commission in Dhaka on 27 May.
(b) Yes.
(c) Yes , although the Government understands that three persons are in custody in connection with Mr Robbani Ahshan Ullah's death.
(d) Yes, although the Government understands that Mr Biswas has since been released on bail. Dr Ahmed remains in custody.
(e) No.
(3) The Australian High Commission in Dhaka has made a number of representations to the Bangladesh government on human rights issues including the rights of minorities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 15 June 2004:

question.para: (1) To which Members and Senators has he issued a standing delegation to preside at Australian citizenship ceremonies.

(2) Does a standing delegation entitle a Member or Senator to preside, without further approval, at (a) a ceremony conducted under the auspices of a Local Council, (b) a ceremony conducted under the auspices of a community group or service club, (c) a public ceremony organised by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, and (d) a private ceremony.
(3) Does anything prevent a Member or Senator from conducting a ceremony at (a) their electorate office, (b) a private residence or farm, or (c) a place of business.

(4) Since the release of the revised Australian Citizenship Ceremonies Code in August 2003, how many community organisations and service clubs have received approval to conduct a citizenship ceremony.

(5) Which community organisations and service clubs have received approval to conduct a citizenship ceremony and, in respect of each ceremony, (a) when was it conducted, (b) in which electoral division was it conducted, (c) how many applicants were conferred citizenship, and (d) which federal and state Members of parliament were in attendance.
(6) Did officers of the department attend all the ceremonies referred to in part (5); if not, for which ceremonies were they not in attendance.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) As at 2 July 2004, the following Members of the House of Representatives had been given a standing delegation to preside at Australian citizenship ceremonies:
Mr Phillip Barresi MP, Member for Deakin;
Mr Bob Baldwin MP, Member for Paterson;
Mr Joel Fitzgibbon MP, Member for Hunter;
Mr Luke Hartsuyker MP, Member for Cowper;
Ms Kelly Hoare MP, Member for Charlton;
Mr Michael Johnson MP, Member for Ryan;
Mr Peter Lindsay MP, Member for Herbert;
Mr Jim Lloyd MP, Member for Robertson;
Mrs Margaret May MP, Member for McPherson;
Ms Sophie Panopoulos MP, Member for Indi;
Mr Chris Pearce MP, Member for Aston;
The Hon Philip Ruddock MP, Member for Berowra;
Mr Alby Schultz MP, Member for Hume;
The Hon Peter Costello MP, Member for Higgins;
The Hon Warren Entsch MP, Member for Leichhardt;
Mrs Kay Hull MP, Member for Riverina; and
Mr Barry Wakelin MP, Member for Grey.
A standing delegation has not been given to any Senator.
(2) (a) to (d) Yes.

(3) (a) to (c) The delegation to confer citizenship does not prescribe a location. All Members provided with a standing delegation have signed an agreement to abide by the Australian Citizenship Ceremonies Code. The Code outlines the expectation that new citizens will generally be conferred with citizenship in public ceremonies conducted by local government or community groups. The Code also outlines the circumstances in which a private ceremony may be appropriate.
(4) and (5)(a), (b) and (d) Answers to these questions will be included in the response to Question No. 3597.

(5) (c) The number of conferees at each ceremony is not readily available without an unreasonable diversion of resources. However, as a result of recent changes to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs data system, there will be a record of the number of conferees at each ceremony held on or after 1 July 2004.
(6) Records of departmental officers' attendance at the ceremonies are not readily available without an unreasonable diversion of resources.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 June 2004:

question.para: (1) As a consequence of resolution 1544 of 2004 by the United Nations Security Council, will the Australian Government join in condemning the demolition of homes and the attacks on unarmed protestors and others by the Israeli military.
(2) Will the Australian Government join in condemning the continued occupation by the Israeli military of the West Bank and Gaza and East Jerusalem.
(3) Since January 2000, what were the (a) form, (b) extent and (c) occasions of co-operation between the Israeli and Australian Defence forces.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) UNSCR 1544 was passed in response to Israeli military actions in the Gaza Strip in May. The Australian Government supports Israel's right to defend itself from attack, but is deeply concerned at the impact of military operations which have resulted in civilian deaths and the demolition of a substantial number of homes in Rafah. The Government has consistently urged Israel, most recently on 20 May through our Ambassador in Tel Aviv, to ensure that its defensive measures do not unnecessarily increase Palestinian hardship.

(2) Australia will continue to support a negotiated, peaceful resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict that respects the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people and the right of Israel to exist within secure and recognised borders in accordance with UN Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338.

(3) Since January 2000 there have been no occasions of cooperation between the Israeli and Australian Defence forces. Contacts between the ADF and IDF have been limited to liaison, visits and dialogue on naval issues, including submarine escape and rescue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 16 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Is the trademark `Postinor-2' registered by IP Australia as belonging to the Hungarian firm, Richter Gedeon Vegyeszeti Gyar Rt.

(2) Can he confirm that `Postinor-2' is registered as a `Trademark Class 5: Pharmaceutical preparations and agents for gynaecological use'; if so, can he explain why this classification was made in preference to other possible classifications.
(3) What is the relationship between Richter Gedeon Vegyeszeti Gyar Rt and Postinor-2 sponsor Intensive Care Products Pty Limited.
(4) Is Schering Pty Limited the manufacturer of Postinor-2; if not, who is the manufacturer.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: â The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I can confirm that âPOSTINOR - 2â has not been registered as a trade mark in Australia nor is an application in process. However, I am advised that âPOSTINORâ is currently registered as a trade mark in the name of Richter Gedeon Vegyeszeti Gyar Rt and has been given the registration number 902580 by IP Australia.

(2) Trade mark number 902580 is registered for âpharmaceutical preparations and agents for gynaecological useâ in Class 5. IP Australia follows an international trade mark classification system known as the NICE Classification system. Under this system âpharmaceutical preparations and agents for gynaecological useâ fall into Class 5. The applicant claimed âpharmaceutical preparations and agents for gynaecological useâ in their application.
(3) I am not aware of the relationship between Richter Gedeon Vegyeszeti Gyar Rt and Postinor-2 sponsor Intensive Care Products Pty Limited.
(4) I am not aware of who manufactures âPostinor - 2â or âPostinorâ.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Can he confirm that it is the intention of the Government to strike campaign medals to recognise service in Afghanistan and Iraq; if so, when will the campaign medals be available.
(2) What will be the eligibility criteria for the campaign medals.

(3) Will the medals be available to those posted to the various operations or will the medals be restricted to those members of the ADF who actually served in the area of the operations, in particular, will the members of the ADF posted to operations in Afghanistan but who served in Tampa, Florida, be eligible for the campaign medals.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The campaign medals will be available when Her Majesty The Queen has formally approved their Letters Patent and Regulations, and production has commenced.
(2) This is currently being finalised. Once known, eligibility criteria will be promulgated in a media release.

(3) The medals will be awarded for warlike service in the operational areas of Afghanistan and Iraq with the particular operations pertaining to those areas. They will not be awarded for service in Tampa, Florida.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 16 June 2004:

quote.para: For the most recent year for which data is available, what was the average cost to the Translating and Interpreting Service (TIS) for each (a) eligible document translated, (b) interpreting call handled, and (c) on-site interpreting session.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The average cost to the Translating and Interpreting Service (TIS) for each service in 2002-2003 was as follows:

answer.para: (a) the average cost for the translation of an eligible document into English was $65.47;
(b) the average cost for an interpreting call handled was $30.52;
(c) the average cost for an on-site interpreting session was $117.38.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 16 June 2004:

question.para: (1) In respect of the $10.5 million appropriation for 2004-2005 for departmental output 2.4 (Promoting the Benefits of Cultural Diversity), what sum is expected to be spent on (a) administering grants under the Living in Harmony program, (b) organising Harmony Day, (c) implementing the Government's access and equity strategy, (d) implementing the Productive Diversity Program, and (e) meeting and other expenses associated with the Council for Multicultural Australia.
(2) Are there any other activities under this output item; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Administering grants under the Living in Harmony program: $0.5m,
(b) Organising Harmony Day: $0.9m,
(c) Implementing the Government's access and equity strategy: $0.36m,
(d) Implementing the Productive Diversity Program: $0.72, and
(e) Meeting and other expenses associated with the Council for Multicultural Australia: $0.32m.

(2) Other activities funded under Output 2.4 include: the partnership element of the Living in Harmony initiative and general administration of the initiative; community liaison activities; policy development; engagement with State, Territory and local government, rural and regional Australia and Australian youth; and multicultural affairs and cultural diversity activities carried out by the State and Territory Offices of the Department. This amounts to approximately $4.5m.
Corporate overheads relating to Output 2.4 are also funded from this appropriation, estimated at approximately $3.2m, including:
property,
human resources,
financial management and reporting, and
IT systems and support.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 16 June 2004:

question.para: (1) What sum has the Commonwealth committed (a) in total to the Child Migrants' Trust, (b) to the operation of the Trust, and (c) to the reunion travel administered by the Trust for (i) 2004-2005, and (ii) subsequent financial years.
(2) Will funding of the Trust beyond 2004-2005 be indexed.
(3) Will funding for the Trust be continued; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In response to the recommendations of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee Report on Child Migration, August 2001, the Commonwealth committed a total of $125,000 per year for three years to the Child Migrants Trust. This funding commitment covers the period 2002-03 to 2004-05 and is for the provision of counselling and family tracing services. The Child Migrants Trust does not administer the $1 million per year, which has been allocated over the same period for reunion travel.
(2) and (3) Funding beyond 2004-05 will be considered nearer to the end of the current funding commitment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Have concerns been raised with the Australian Government about human rights in the Maldives; if so, have there been any recent discussions with the Maldivian authorities on this issue.
(2) In the two years to 31 May 2004, how many applications for asylum have been received from citizens of the Maldives.
(3) Does the Government provide scholarships through Ausaid for citizens of the Maldives to study in Australia; if so, what processes ensure that the scholarships are awarded on merit.
(4) What current training programs and other relationships exist between the Australian Defence Forces and Australian police services and the defence and security services of the Maldives.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Yes.
(2) None.

(3) Yes. Scholarship candidates are assessed by an independent panel that includes government representatives from Australia and the Maldives. Candidates are ranked under a points system that addresses their academic performance, the potential benefit to the Maldives from their intended course of study and their performance in an interview.

(4) The question of Australia's defence relations with the Maldives should be directed to my colleague the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. The Australian Federal Police has irregular contact with counterpart agencies in the Maldives. These contacts do not include training.

subdebateinfo.title: Immigration: Migration Agents and Agencies Audits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3665)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 17 June 2004:

question.para: (1) How many audits of migration agents and agencies are conducted each year.

(2) Is there a process of pre-assessment by the department of visa applications prepared by (a) agents, and (b) principal applicants prior to the applications being formally lodged; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In 2002-03, 143 agents were audited and in 2003-04, 153 agents were audited.
(b) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 21 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Which airports in Australia are required to develop Master Plans and submit them for approval under the Airports Act 1996.
(2) In respect of each airport, when was its Master Plan last approved and when will it expire.
(3) For which airports is he reviewing a draft Master Plan at 17 June 2004.
(4) In respect of each airport, on what date is its next draft Master Plan due to be submitted for approval.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Sydney, Brisbane, Perth, Moorabbin, Parafield, Canberra, Hobart, Adelaide, Townsville, Darwin, Alice Springs, Launceston, Archerfield, Jandakot, Coolangatta, Essendon, Melbourne, Bankstown, Camden and Hoxton Park. Pursuant to Regulation 5.01A of the Airports Regulations 1997, Mount Isa and Tennant Creek are not required to have Master Plans.

(2) The dates the airports last had their Master Plans approved are as follows: Sydney 22 March 2004; Brisbane 7 May 2004; Perth 18 May 1999; Moorabbin 21 May 1999; Parafield 11 August 1999; Canberra 23 August 1999; Hobart 23 August 1999; Adelaide 24 August 1999; Townsville 1 September 1999; Darwin 15 September 1999; Alice Springs 20 September 1999; Launceston 13 October 1999; Archerfield 17 August 2000; Jandakot 24 October 2000; Coolangatta 14 August 2001; Essendon 27 March 2003 and Melbourne 7 September 2003.

The Sydney basin airports comprising Bankstown, Camden and Hoxton Park have not previously been required to submit Master Plans, although all three are required to submit Master Plans to the Minister by 15 December 2004.
Nominally, all Master Plans expire 5 years after they are approved. However, under Section 77 of the Airports Act 1996, the original plan remains in force until a fresh plan comes into force.
(3) Moorabbin and Perth.

(4) The dates the airports are to have their next Master Plans approved are as follows: Sydney 22 March 2009; Brisbane 7 May 2009; Parafield 11 August 2004; Canberra 23 August 2004; Hobart 23 August 2004; Adelaide 24 August 2004; Townsville 1 September 2004; Darwin 15 September 2004; Alice Springs 20 September 2004; Launceston 13 October 2004; Archerfield 17 August 2005; Jandakot 24 October 2005; Coolangatta 14 August 2006; Essendon 27 March 2008; Melbourne 7 September 2008; Bankstown 15 December 2004; Camden 15 December 2004 and Hoxton Park 15 December. The next draft Master Plans for Perth and Moorabbin should be submitted five years from the date of the approval of the draft Master Plans currently under consideration.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 22 June 2004:

quote.para: Does he intend to accredit the (a) Eastern Tuna and Billfish Fishery, and (b) Southern and Western Tuna and Billfish Fishery in advance of the development of the Threat Abatement Plans for Long line Fisheries; if so, can he explain why it is not more appropriate to develop Threat Abatement Plans prior to accrediting fisheries.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Eastern Tuna and Billfish Fishery and the Southern and Western Tuna and Billfish Fishery are currently under assessment to determine if the management arrangements for these fisheries will ensure that they are ecologically sustainable and can therefore be accredited under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, 1999.
The Threat Abatement Plan for the Incidental catch (or bycatch) of seabirds during oceanic longline fishing operations became effective on 16 July 2000 and is currently under review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice, on 22 June 2004:

question.para: (1) What is the name and position of each minister and official from Australia who attended or observed the 92nd Annual Conference of the ILO which concluded its work in Geneva on 17 June 2004.
(2) What matters concerning Australia were considered at the conference and with what result.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No Australian Ministers or Parliamentarians attended the 92nd Session of the International Labour Conference, Geneva, 1-17 June 2004. The following officials attended the Conference:
Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR):
Mr John LLOYD, Deputy Secretary (Leader of the delegation)
Ms Linda LIPP, Assistant Secretary, Safety, Compensation and International Branch
Mr Scott MATHESON, Assistant Secretary, Economic and Labour Market Analysis Branch
Mr Denis HART, Director, Occupational and Skills Analysis Section.
Australian Permanent Mission to the United Nations, Geneva:
Mr Mark SAWERS, Counsellor
Ms Vicki PARKER, Counsellor (Immigration)

The Government also invited the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to send two representatives each to the Conference. Their attendees were:
Mr Bryan NOAKES, Adviser - International Labour Affairs, ACCI
Mr Peter ANDERSON, Director - Workplace Policy, ACCI
Ms Sharan BURROW, President, ACTU
Mr Alan MATHESON, International Officer, ACTU.

(2) A Government representative appeared before the Conference Committee on the Application of Standards in relation to the application of ILO Convention 29, Forced Labour, 1930 and work in privately-managed prisons in several Australian States. The Applications Committee expressed the hope that Australia would continue the dialogue with the ILO and that a detailed report would be supplied to the Committee of Experts.

Government representatives also participated in work of three technical Committees, which adopted a new Recommendation on human resources development and training, held a first discussion on the fishing sector, and a general discussion on migrant workers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 2004:

question.para: (1) How many applications for asylum have been received from citizens of the Republic of Maldives and how many were approved.
(2) How many citizens of the Republic of Maldives are living in Australia.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) records as at 31 May 2004 show that since 1 July 1999, one application for a protection visa was received from a citizen of the Maldives and that application was not approved.
(2) Information on people resident in Australia is not collected by country of citizenship, only by country of birth. In the 2001 Census, 180 persons are recorded as being born in the Maldives.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 2004:

quote.para: What assistance has the Government provided to the Tamils Rehabilitation Organisation, a non-government organisation that provides and coordinates a range of emergency relief and rehabilitation services in the northeast of Sri Lanka?

talk.start.para: â The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Nil, the Australian government does not fund the Tamils Rehabilitation Organisation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 June 2004:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the Chinese internet activist Du Daobin has been convicted of `subverting state power' as a result of posting essays critical of the Chinese government on the internet; if so, can he confirm that (a) Du Daobin was tried in a closed court without legal representation, and (b) he received a suspended sentence of three years.

(2) Can he confirm that the prosecution of Du Daobin is one of a number of prosecutions on similar charges of up to 30 Chinese citizens who have done no more than exercise on the internet the right of free speech.
(3) Has he seen reports that the `Democracy and Freedom' website of the Chinese internet activist, Wu Wei, has been shut down or otherwise incapacitated 38 times in the past three years.

(4) Can he say whether the persecution of Wu Wei is part of a pattern of repression of Chinese internet activists who seek to use their constitutional right of free speech to post accurate information and free discussion on the internet.

(5) Can he confirm that (a) Article 35 of the Chinese Constitution reads âCitizens of the People's Republic of China enjoy freedom of speech, of the press, of assembly, of association, of procession, and of demonstrationâ, and (b) Article 41 reads âCitizens of the People's Republic of China have the right to criticize and make suggestions to any state organ or functionary. Citizens have the right to make to relevant state organs complaints and charges against, or exposures of, any state organ or functionary for violation of the law or dereliction of dutyâ.
(6) Is he able to say whether Amnesty International reported that other Chinese citizens have been prosecuted and imprisoned for disseminating accurate information about the SARS epidemic.

(7) What steps has he taken to convey to the Government of the People's Republic of China Australia's condemnation of the persecution of Chinese citizens who exercise their right to free speech on the internet.

(8) Has the issue of free speech for Chinese citizens on the internet been raised at the Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue; if so, what was the response of the Chinese government; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of reports that Du Daobin was tried on 18 May in a closed court. I am not able to confirm reports of his conviction or the questions of whether he had legal representation or the sentence passed. We made representations to the Chinese in April 2004 about Du Daobin but as yet have received no substantive response.
(2) I am not able to confirm the number of Chinese citizens prosecuted on similar charges.
(3) I am aware of such reports.

(5) Yes, however, the text in full of the first paragraph of Article 41 reads âCitizens of the People's Republic of China have the right to criticize and make suggestions to any state organ or functionary. Citizens have the right to make to relevant state organs complaints and charges against, or exposures of; any state organ or functionary for violation of the law or dereliction of duty, but fabrication or distortion of facts for purposes of libel or false incrimination is prohibitedâ.
(6) Yes.

(7) We make regular and high level representations to the Chinese authorities about our concerns about restrictions on freedom of expression and use of the internet, and also make representations about individual internet activists. We carry out representations not only during the annual Human Rights Dialogue but throughout the year.
(8) Yes. The Chinese Government did not provide a substantive response to our representations. We will continue to raise this matter with the Chinese authorities.
